text:
This recipe was an excellent starter but I modified it to my taste.  I was afraid that this recipe was too spicy and reduced some of the spiciness.  It still has a kick to it. I made this for a Chili Cookoff and it won 2nd place(pretty good for getting there late).  Here are my changes:  1)  3 (15 ounce) cans chili beans in mild sauce, NOT drained.  2)  1 (15 oz) can chili beans in medium sauce, 3) I omitted the celery and tabasco sauce, 4)1 jalapeno instead of chile peppers, 5) 3 tablespoons of bacon bits, 6) 1 cup of beer 7) Instead of using 2 (28oz) cans of diced tomatoes with juice, I used 3 (14 1/2 oz) can of diced tomatoes and 1 (14 1/2 oz) can of diced tomatoes with basil/oregano/garlic. 8) I cooked this in a slow cooker for 8 hours the day before, let it sit overnight and heated it up and served it the next day with cheese on top.  I also froze the left overs and it taste even better!!

text:
I can't praise this chili enough!  The meat melted in your mouth, the flavors tingled nicely all the way to your toes.  I just won a chili cookoff with it so that might be a large part of the reason.  The judges and the crowd loved it.  I ran out within 30 minutes of it being opened to the public to taste. I did make a few changes: I used 3 lbs of cubed chuck steak in place of the ground chuck because I really like a meaty chili (obvisously so did the judges), I cooked 4 slices of bacon, then crumbled for the bacon bits and sauted the celery, onion and garlic in the drippings.  My biggest piece of advice is prepare it the day before, let cool overnight, degrease really well and then reheat; the chili really developes a great flavor by doing this. I used my crockpot on low to keep it warm the day I served it.

This is an excellent chili recipe.  Tons of intresting flavors.  Just a few changes because I didn't have everything.  I used roasted red peppers enstead of fresh.  Used chicken broth enstead of beer.  At first it was too spicy(not for me but for my husband and kids) so I went online for a quick fix.  Turns out you just need to puree a can of pineapple to tone down the spice.  I was pretty leary about this so I added it slowly, tasting it each time.  I did end up using the whole can and it was perfect.  All the flavors without the burn.  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
My husband loved this chili.  I will definitely make again.  I used 1 lb ground HOT italian turkey sausage, 1 lb HOT italian pork sausage and 1 lb ground round.  It turned out to be a wonderful flavor combination and much more healthy than 3 lbs of beef.  Since there were so many spices already in my HOT sausage blends I omitted the extra peppers and tabasco.  It was still quite spicy. I cut the chili powder down to 3 Tablespoons.  I was worried the full 4 T (=1/4 cup) would be too overpowering and mask the other flavors.  I also used a whole can of beer.  I didn't have any tomato paste so I used 2 small cans of tomato sauce. For the diced tomatoes I used 4 of the regular 14 oz cans - 1 petite diced and 3 regular size diced with chili spices included.  I also added a fifth can of petite diced which had lime juice and cilantro in it. I did not drain any of them.  Turned out wonderfully.  The flavors were great and the tomatoes of different sizes cooked up for great texture.  You can cetainly modify this recipe for your own tastes as far as spiceyness and heat.  We like spicey chili but for my 5 year to eat it I have to go a little lighter on the spice.  This recipe is difinitely worth the time and trouble.  Will make again....and again!  Thanks for sharing.

text:
This is my new 'go-to' chili recipe!  Between the recipe and other reviews, I ended up with a great pot of chili that we completely demolished, even all the leftovers (which just got better)!  I took a few notes from other reviews, however.  Instead of ground beef, I used a mix of cubed chuck steak and stew meat.  I started the entire process in a skillet:  I fried the bacon, cooked the veggies (omitted the green bell pepper) in the bacon fat, then used the pan to brown the meat in stages.  Between each pan of meat, I used the beer to deglaze the pan (ended up using an entire bottle of beer).  Everything went into my slow cooker.  I used a mix of beans (black, kidney, and chili beans in spicy sauce) - and all the cans I used were either 'low sodium' or 'no salt'.  Like other reviewers, I left out the Tabasco and used brown instead of white sugar.  Yummy and perfect spicy for us!

I'm using my wife's login.  First off, I make recipes from allrecipes all the time but this is the first review I have ever left.  Secondly, I never follow directions to the letter because I HAVE TO TINKER with things -- add a little here, remove a little here, etc.  Thirdly, I'm a Texan so I know a good chili when I taste one.  This is without a doubt the best chili I have ever had.  It pains me to admit that, but it's true.  As instructed, I made it the night before.  Thank God I did because it made all the difference.  Read on and you'll see why.  Based on other reviews, I omitted the bacon bits and put in 4 slices of bacon.  I cut the 3 cans of chili beans to 1 can, and I drained it before putting in the pot.  I also drained the can of spicy beans.  I cut the ground beef from 2 pounds to 1, and I added 2.5 pounds of a rump roast that I cubed.  Instead of the 2 green chilis, i put in a small can of green chilis.  As I previously stated, I prepared it the night before.  As I was putting the chili in the fridge for the night I was shocked by the fact that there was hardly any liquid at all in the pot and it tasted rather bland.  I was ticked because it was a bit of a pain to make.  The next day morning I put it on the stove to simmer all day.  Once again, not much liquid and not much taste.  For lunch I grabbed a small bowl of the chili, and while it had plenty of liquid, it was still a bit bland.  Well, the final 6 hours did the trick.  It was incredible!

text:
This is an excellent recipe, delicious, easy and makes a large pot that can serve many. It's also spicy hot and if you have others in your family (like mine) that only like very mild spiciness, here are some useful modifications to make it milder and still has amazing flavor like the original.

1) Don't put in any cayenne, chili, paprika, cumin or hot sauce until then end. Even then, put in a very small amount of these starting with 1/8 increments (seriously) until you've reached the spicy hotness that works. (For some, 1/8 will work but I like it at about 3/8 or 1/2 of the original amounts).

2) Consider using 2 pounds of ground turkey instead of ground beef. This doesn't change the spiciness of course, but it's an easy substitute for a bit more healthy dish. Double the amount of beef bullion and double the Worcestershire sauce and you won't miss the beef or even notice. Don't substitute on the Italian sausage, though!

3) Skip the celery and double the onions and garlic used. It's adds more flavor and aroma that's lost when you reduce the chili spices.

4) Substitute another bell pepper for the 2 green chile peppers. At my store I can get a package of 3 bell peppers that works well, one each of red, green and yellow. (The yellow adds nice color, too!)

5) Substitute another can of chili beans for the spicy chili beans.

That's it. Enjoy!

text:
Won 1st place in local community chili cook off! I intended to use real bacon instead of bits, but accidentally burned it. Too many beans, recommend only 3 cans. To get a nice consistent mixture, chop veggies (except chilies) into bean-sized pieces and saute them with garlic before adding to pot.  Also break up meat to bean size. To improve texture, I used crushed tomatoes (pureed works too) for one of the cans. And after it's cooked for a while, scoop out some of the liquid that comes to the top before stirring, otherwise it's too runny. Add Tabasco last, 1/2tsp at a time, tasting until desired spicyness is achieved.

text:
This was an amazing chili as the recipe is stated but it was too spicy for my 20 year old and 8 year old daughter so I made a few changes.  I did not add in the hot sauce or the cayenne pepper and instead of the 1/4 cup chili powder, I added just half that (2 Tbsp. chili powder) and then added in just under a Tbsp. of unsweetened cocoa powder.  The cocoa still gives it a depth of flavor but without the heat.  

The result was an amazingly deep flavored chili with no heat although it almost seemed like there would be some there.  I would take a bit and definitely taste the wonderful flavor and expect the heat to come but it never did!  This is an 11 on a scale of 1-10 according to my family.  A DEFINITE keeper!

text:
GREAT recipe!  To make things easier, the night before I made this I sat down in front of my spice cabinet, measured out everything I needed, dumped it in the bowl and put all the spices back. That took care of 10 of the 28 ingredients called for, so once that was done everything else was a breeze (and I wasn't drowning in spice bottles all over the counter while I was trying to cook). The only changes I made were adding 2 t. cocoa to add a little more depth and "darkness" of flavor. I also used 2 cans of pinto beans and 2 cans of black beans (drained the black beans but not the pintos) b/c I didn't have any "chili beans".  It was plenty hot enough even without spiced beans... in fact if you are serving this to kids I would cut the cheyenne pepper back to 1/2 t.  I also used a full cup of beer.  I liked the celery in it, next time I'll add more.

I hate buying seasoning packets and loved the flavors of these but next time will cut back on cayenne and chile powder. This is probably one of the best chili's I've ever made.  I made very few modifications to it and it was fabulous.    First, not sure what a boilermaker is, so I used my slow cooker.  I browned the meat (including 3 strips of real bacon.  Don't do bacon bits!) and then threw everything into a slow cooker on low for 8-9 hours.      I used a bean mix (whcih I drained and rinsed) and serrano peppers instead of green chile's as I like the flavor a bit better.  I also cut the recipe in half (there's only two of us) which was good because my slow cooker couldn't fit anything more than what I made.        Freaking Deee-lish!

text:
so far so good.  the 2 hour taste test is a success.  some things i had to change due to materials on hand: used Killian's Irish Red Lager, 1/2 a bottle (what kind of beer you use makes a difference!), used fresh bacon, 4 slices.  Omitted celery.  Browned other veggies in bacon drippings.  Substituted Kielbasa for the Italian sausage, also browned in bacon drippings.  Used 1 lb gr.chuck and 1 lb gr.turkey, again, in the bacon drippings.  Used 1 can each of dark red kidney beans, light red kidney beans and great northern beans (had no regular chili beans on hand).  All spices stayed the same.  I have to say, this was surprisingly easy to prepare, considering the rather imposing list of ingredients.  I will make this again, hopefully with the ingredients the recipe calls for, just to try it.  But the way its turning out now.... Delicious, thick, hearty, loaded with meat and veggies, with a nice solid kick to it.  I'm impressed.  And I'm a chili critic.

text:
This is the best chili ever. I did tweak a little. I used hot sausage so I didn't need the 2 teaspoons hot sauce. I used 1 can pink beans drained, 1 can dark kidney beans drained, 1 can red beans drained. I will add another can of kidney beans if too much liquid. Most important I put all the dry ingredients and bouillon cubes in a small bowl and keep adding until I felt it was to my liking. Only used about 1/2 the dry ingredients and only  2 of bouillion cubes. You can always put in more as needed. Now I have all the dry ingredients for another batch. Love this recipe I bet it will get better tomorrow

text:
Very good for thick chili. I ended up adding some water to the recipe to make it somewhat less thick; however, it still ended up thickier than I personally like.  My husband loved it (he's a Boilermaker Alumni so that may have something to do with it, too)!!  I cooked the chili overnight in the crockpot, so as it was ready for football at lunchtime! It was a  little time consuming b/c of all of the ingredients - but it was certainly good.  I also used fresh bacon - instead of bacon bits.  My husband wished I had added even more bacon b/c he liked the flavor it added.  I prefer this chili without frito's b/c of it's thickness(but it would be fine for dipping as a snack) but the cheese was wonderful on top.  I only made half of this recipe and it made so much chili - we had alot of leftovers!  If you're expecting a big crowd - definetly this is a chili worth fixing!!

             BOILER UP!!

text:
OMG - can we say awesome???  I prepared this stovetop, then threw it in the crock pot to simmer.  I did make some changes, but none were drastic, just me cooking :) 
For those curious, I used dried celery flakes (i/o stalks), crushed red pepper (i/o chili peppers), and about half the onion, adding diced green onions to make up for it.  i actually cooked a whole package of thick cut bacon, diced it set aside, and used half the drippings to saute my onion, garlic and meats in, adding the bacon after i cooked the meats.  I did use deer meat in place of ground chuck, because thats what was on hand.  I added some fennel seeds too, because my sausage was a mild blend.  I did change the chili beans a bit, but just for presentation.  I used a can of pinto, light and dark kidney, and one chili bean.  I didn't add as much diced tomatoes, but next time i will.  It can handle it.  I truly think the flavors came out beautifuly.  I dont actually measure my spices, just sprinkle till I think that's about right.  So my concoction maybe a lil diff each time, but this is simple the best chili I've ever made.  Thank you soooo much for sharing!

This has pretty much everything I put in my own chili.  I'm a kind of "throw everyting in the pot" kind of cook and usually don't measure anything. text:
Great chili!  I doubled the recipe.  Doubling this recipe made two large crock pots of chili.  I cooked it yesterday, cooled overnight and re-heated today on low in the crock for dinner.  Friends raved. I have made it to the letter in the past and loved it.  This time, I substituted (for a double batch) 6 lbs. cubed sirloin instead of the ground chuck for tender, meaty servings and 3 lbs. ground turkey with Italian seasoning instead of the bulk Italian sausage (again, for a doubled volume).  I added 3-3 ounce jars of crumbled bacon to the turkey as it browned because I like the smokey flavor of the bacon.  Oh, and because of my Scandinavian family, I used only half of the chili powder (1/4 c. for a double batch).  Still spicy enough, but not over the top for these native Minnesota taste buds.  All other ingredients were included to the letter.  Served with sour cream and shredded cheddar atop and fresh sourdough bread, this made a wonderful, hearty meal.  Quite a time-intensive process, but well worth it!

text:
I tried to stay as close to the recipe as possible. I didn't have chili beans, so I used black. I left out the chili peppers because I need to feed little mouths and I also used california chili powder, which gives you all the flavor of chili powder but less heat. (You can find california chili powder in the "ethnic" section of your grocery store hanging from a j-hook in a cellophane package and it costs under a dollar.) I also used brown sugar in place of the granulated, because I like a richer flavor rather than just sweet. I try to use all organic ingredients and a quality beer because the flavor and quality of what you make just turns out so much better. Those were the only changes I made. This recipe looks complicated, but it's really not. I can't tell you how wonderful it smells already. I layered all the ingredients in the crockpot so it'll be able to simmer on low most of the day. I'll update how everyone liked it later today. EDITED: This is the best chili I've ever had. Real beefy. This will replace my own recipe for chili as of today. Best chili EVER. And honestly, the longer it sits, the better it gets. Really.

This chili was pretty good, but I didn't win my chili cook-off with it.  It was beefy and spicy, but otherwise didn't really have any special pizazz.  I did make a few changes: 1) used 4 slices bacon, fried & crumbled. 2) sauteed the onions, peppers and garlic in the bacon grease 3) used 2 cloves fresh garlic.  4) omitted the celery and substituted 1 can of chopped green chilis for the green chili pepper, 5) used a whole can of beer, and 6) cut the tabasco and cayenne pepper in half--it was still spicey enough.  After browning the meat and sauteeing the vegetables, I threw everything in my large crock pot (which was completely filled) and cooked on low for 8 hours, then refrigerated overnight and warmed up again the next day.  Being a Boilermaker, I had high hopes for this recipe, and while it was good, it's not the BEST chili I've ever had.

text:
Basically followed the recipe, but toned down all the heat...and it was still plenty hot and spicy. Omitted the "spicy" can of chili beans. Added an extra can of regular chili beans instead. Instead of two green chili peppers, I only added @1/2 of one green chili pepper. (Pasilla Chili pepper) Other reductions: 2 Tbsp of chili powder, 1 tsp Tabasco, 1/2 tsp pepper, 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper. If you are concerned at all about this chili being too spicy, follow the reductions that I am suggesting. The quality of this chili is amazing...just figure out how spicy you want it and you can't miss!!

text:
Not bad.  It is spicy, and I cut back on the cayenne, but not the hot sauce.  This makes a ton--I halved it and still filled up our biggest crockpot, so keep that in mind.  It's a good thing we liked it or we'd have a problem!  I used canned green chiles (all I had) and used a full bottle of beer.  I also didn't find spicy chili beans so just used regular.  I have to say, though, that I'm not sure the point of buying chili beans for this recipe if they are just going to be drained.  Chili beans are just pinto beans with water, tomato paste and seasonings, so I left them undrained.  This recipe calls for a ton of ingredients, so it is a bit daunting, but I would think most people have most of the spices in their cupboards and might just have to get a few things to round out the recipe.  Plus, if you don't like spicy at all leave out the hot sauce and cayenne.  I popped this in the crockpot overnight, cooked it for 10 hours on low, then reheated it today for lunch.  Worked wonderfully so I didn't have to keep it on the stove for a while.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I loved this recipe and so did those who ate it.  I made a couple of preparation step changes.  First, I addedd salt and pepper to the ground beef and sausage when I was browning it.  If you don't, you'll have a hard time getting it properly seasoned.  Second, I waited to add the beans and tomatoes until after the vegetables.  I sauteed the vegetables and spices in the some of the meat drippings, waited for them to soften, then added the beans, tomatoes and beer.  This layers the flavors better.

text:
This is a really good recipe.  I've made it a few times and folks always love it.  Of course like many others, I've won a chili cook-off with a variation on this recipe and will continue to use it in the future.  A couple of things I always change on this recipe is: Add 1 tbsp ground coriander to brighten the flavor, Use extra bacon (about 3x the recommended amount, leave out the celery, and add about 30% more tomato in the form of additional diced tomato or crushed tomato with puree.  I've also made this recipe vegetarian by omitting the meat and beef bouillon and adding italian seasoning, vegetable bouillon, 50% more beans (and diversifying the types), a little more sugar to cut the tartness of the tomatoes, and 1 cup of bulgar wheat toward the end for heartiness.  The result is a very good vegetarian (maybe even vegan?) chili.

text:
Great recipe. I did modify it for my lack of eating beef (used 95% lean ground turkey and hot turkey Italian sausage). Also tried different kinds of beans (1 can light kidney, 1 can dark kidney, 1 can white, 1 can chili in chili sauce) just to get some color variation in there. I've also played around with different kinds of bell peppers, again just for color, as well as using Italian diced tomatoes to add even more flavor. Try some Sriracha instead of regular hot sauce, adds a different kind of kick to it! Using the turkey modification, it also cuts the calories down to about 340/serving (before chips/sour cream/cheese), so it's a healthier option. But great base recipe!

Best chili I have ever made/tasted ever! Fantastic chili!! Anyone who doesn't like this recipe must be doing something wrong! I changed a few things-only added 1 can of beans, about 2 lbs of chopped sirloin, 2 lbs of ground hamburger, lb sausage and about a lb of bacon. Browned all meat before adding it to pot. This chili is time consuming and not cheap, so if you're on the hunt for quick/inexpensive, this is not for you.

text:
Good, solid chili recipe to base off of, personally I use black beans instead of pinto or kidney, not only are they more flavorful, but also more nutritious. I also like a more tomato based chili, so I tend to use more tomato paste (also thickens it up more...I don't like chili with liquid). I have seen a few reviews which ppl say they are a bit disappointed, I have one thing to say...

ANY 'stewing' recipe like this with so many flavors takes several hours to slow cook, PLUS refrigeration overnight for the flavors to really blend and come to their full potential.

When I made this recipe, I chose to use some shiraz (a dry red wine) instead of the beer, did out iwth the sugar, and added a spice in a few different flavors...using different types of spice gives it more dimension (for example, I left some of the jalapeno seeds in, added some red pepper flakes, used some cayenne and also sirracha (asian type of hot sauce) all in small amounts. I also used a it of ground mustard, and went for variety on peppers (jalapeno, anaheim, green bell, red bell and yellow bell) lastly, I prefer bermuda onions in this type of a dish. 

Okay, so I have changed it a bit, but it really is a solid recipe to start wit to suit your own personal taste, style and sensibilities

With all the great reviews, I thought this could compare with chili made with ham on the bone. It was not as good though. I did give it 4 stars, but it really should be around 3.5. I made a few changes. First, I omitted the Tabasco sauce and added 1 habanero pepper. I couldn't find spicy chili beans so I used 2 cans of regular. I also let it simmer for about an hour or so longer than it says to, just because I wanted all the flavors to stand out. The reason I didn't love this chili was because it was not thick enough. If I made this recipe again I will try draining some of the liquid from the tomatoes. I also think the chili would be better with meet chunks added instead of all ground meet. Overall, good but not the great "home cooked" goodness I was looking for.

This chili was good. I did change up a few things. It was not spicy at all despite my using about 6 cored and seeded jalapenos. So I added 1 more tbl of hot sauce and about 1 tbl of red pepper flakes and more cayenne. Even with all this there  was just barely a kick. I also added slivered garlic and about 1/4 cup of chocolate chips. Yes, sounds strange, but adds just a hint of that *something*. 
Also took out on of the cans of chili beans and subbed in a can of white beans that were mashed - helps add some thickness to the texture. Definitely a good recipe and I will make it with these changes again!

I made this for super bowl Sunday, and it was a big hit, I made it leaner by cutting the meat back to 1# of ground beef, and 1/2# of Italian sausage. I also added 2T of chipotle peppers in adobo sauce for a smoky heat, and cut the chili powder back to 1 T. I used kidney, black, and chili beans. I made it the day before the game , and reheated in a big crockpot. It was a little thick, so I added two small cans of tomato juice to thin..I also omitted the green chiles and the bacon, did'nt miss them at all.Instead of bouillon, which is loaded with salt, I added a can of campbells french onion soup.We topped it with diced white onion, shredded cheddar, sour cream and fritos..Awesome!

text:
Don't know how anyone could call this disappointing...I've been making it for 6 years now and it is to die for...especially as leftovers...last time we made it we ate ours every night for a week and did not get tired of it (that's saying something for me).

Changes that helped:
-You pretty much always need more beer...add to taste and make sure its a strong beer. I usually end up using a full cup
-Its never very spicy prepared as directed...but I never use chili beans in spicy sauce (can't find) but it tastes delish when you use about one chopped jalapeno (instead of 2 green chlis) and about 2 chipotle peppers in adobo sauce (in can) this gives it a smoky chipotle like flavor...
-mix the types o beans...we often use both kideny and white beans....makes it prettier (and tastier I think) 
-I usually don't bother with bacon bits and it doesn't need them...its such a complex tasting chili as it is!!
-Don't waste this by putting it on fritos...but do get an AMAZING VERY SHARP cheddar to put on top...compliments it amazingly...
-Make sure you season to taste...I always add a little bit more salt, pepper or sugar etc to get the perfect balance...trust your taste buds but also know that after 1 day in the fridge the flavors will meld and be much much better than the day you made it...

You can also make this with ground turkey and turkey sausage which tastes the same to me and is healthier!

Serve this with Cornbread, beer and sharp sharp cheddar...it's TO DIE FOR...

text:
this was a great recipe.  A few tweaks that knocked it out of the park for us:  use dark beer, bock style. Like several reviewers, i added more chopped bacon, but used smoked/cured bacon which gave the chili a complex, smoky taste.  We used a mix of sweet red peppers, anaheim peppers and fresh jalapenos, which added both hot and sweet flavors.  We  added half a bottle of beer and drank the rest, and added some red wine and leftover coffee, and molasses instead of sugar. Finally, i added some epizote, a natural herb that cuts down on gas from bean dishes.

text:
If I could give this TEN stars - I would!!!  NOT kidding!! My husband LOVES this chili - and boy is he normally picky about his chili!!  I gotta tell you though - each time I make this, it is different.  It always depends on the hot peppers that we get from the fresh produce - depending on what is in stock at that time of the year.  Took some of the suggestions and here is what we did: we followed most of the recipe to a T - with the exception of:  ~we used a lb of spicy Italian sausage and 1 lb of ground beef (if you want it EXTRA meaty like my husband does - you can do sp.it sausage, gr beef AND beef chuck! - of course all three means more expensive) ~the only chili beans at our grocery store were mild - so we get 3 mild and one texan style - the only other variation.   ~Chili peppers are different each time ~instead of oregano and basil - we just use a italian seasoning spice/mix ~we cook the bacon first, leaving all the fat in and then sautee the veggies in the bacon fat ~to reduce the amount of liquid - we drain one can of the diced tomatoes and one can of the mild chili beans ~we also simmer for 2 1/2 hours on the stove and then the next day I put it in the crock pot for about 5-6 hours.  (THIS makes a huge difference!!)  The best thing about this chili is that it gets BETTER AND BETTER each day that passes!!    A little pricey but Huge Hit and makes a LARGE amount so it's worth it!!!

text:
Very good chili.  I slow cooked on stove for several hours.  I used 1/2 lb. bacon instead of bacon bits; would probably reduce salt next time.  Also, to reduce heat I omitted cayenne, surprised no one else mentionned doing that.  Was still medium hot even with no cayenne, 1/2 of chili peppers (I used jalapenos), 1/2 of chili powder and 1/2 of hot pepper sauce.  I made a double batch for 20.  Need 12 quart stock pot for that much in case anyone else was wondering.  Probably only made 8 quarts but it would spill over in 8 qt. stock pot.  Served with hot dogs and all the accoutrements to 15-18 high school construction guys and had plenty leftover.  Also for beans I used 1 can medium hot chili beans, 1 can plain chili beans, 2 cans dark red kidney, 1 can light red kidney, 1 can pinto.  Will definitely make again, will probably add 1/2 of cayenne next time.

text:
I made this chili before and loved it.  This time I tripled the batch so I could put some in the freezer and I also wanted to do a majority of the recipe can-free.  My personal changes?  1) Rather than canned beans - dried beans soaked overnight and cooked the next day.   2) Rather than ground beef - an inexpensive cut of lean beef cubed.  3) Rather than bulk Italian Sausage  Chorizo (1lb for triple batch) and no Italian Sausage.  4) Rather than canned tomatoes  Tomatoes from the farmer blanched and skinned.  I did use canned tomato paste.  5) Rather than canned green chile peppers  Anaheim chilies from the farmer grilled and skins removed. 6) No bacon bits.  It is a bit more work to make it from fresh veggies but when you are making a batch this large it is worth the trouble for a healthier version (except for the Chorizo).  It was considerably spicier this time, guessing it was from the Chorizo; I wont do that again.

text:
I really wanted to like this recipe, as a fellow Boilermaker, but do not put italian sausage in your chile. It was like eating spaghetti sauce -- the sausage overwhelmed everything else.

But the good news is that the spice combination is good. I substituted texas smoked sausage from Famous Dave's for the itialian sausage and it was excellent. If you can get authetic Texas hot smoked sausage from Kreiz's market(Lockhart TX), for example, it'd probably be even better. Cook the chili and at the very end add some cubed smoked sausage to taste. Add it a bit at a time because it can overwhelm the chili flavor, too.

text:
Love it!  Perfect for a winter day in New England.  I have experimented with other recipes and although this has a lot of ingredients it was definitely a winner today.  I did make a couple adjustments. I used 1 lb. hot sausage and added 1/2 lb. sweet sausage (because I needed to use it up in the fridge). I only used 3 cans of chili beans total, (I like more meat then beans). I added a jalapeno pepper just for fun.  I browned the meat and added all the stuff in the pot on the stove (use an extra large one). I let it all cook on the stove while I was chopping and just added as I got things done. Then when I had it all together and every ingredient in the pot, I transferred it to a crock pot and cooked on low for 8 hours overnight. Then turned the crock pot off for 3 hours to let it thicken up. Then about half an hour before out guests came we turned the crock pot on warm.  It was the perfect consistency and tasted great!   I'll definitely make it again. And probably add a few different hot peppers to experiment.

text:
This is by far the best chili recipe I've ever used.  The first time I made it, I didn't have bell peppers, so I just added extra paprika.  I also substituted New York strip steak for the sausage, since we like a chunkier, beefier chili.  I also used chicken stock instead of beer and left out the bouillon cubes (they tend to make things too salty for my taste).  I used fresh (very spicy) peppers from my dad's garden, which probably kicked it up a notch higher than the recipe as written.  The spice combination is perfection.  

I used to be a loyal fan of the  Carroll Shelby seasoning packets, but this chili recipe blows that out of the water.  Goodbye, Mr. Shelby, I'm leaving you forever!  It's obviously a bit more work to have all your own spices on hand and measure them out, but it is worth the minimal effort.

If you like chili, you need to make this recipe.  And if you make this recipe and don't like it, you need to go to a Chinese accupuncturist to adjust your taste buds, because something is wrong.

text:
I should have rated this recipe years ago because it is fantastic as is.  It is wonderful on a cool, football Sunday although I sometimes crave it even in the middle of our hot Indiana summers.  It is wonderful as is, but sometimes I substitute the Italian sausage with chorizo for an extra kick (we like our chili nice and spicy and chorizo makes it perfect).  Just make sure that if you make the substitution to be very careful with adding the 1 tsp of salt.... chorizo is pretty salty on its own, so make sure and taste test the chili before adding the 1 tsp.  Try this recipe, you will not be disappointed!

So, great chili, but leave out the sausage if you want a traditional chili flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Classic chili flavor with an excellent blending of spices and a subtle under tone of heat that builds over time.  I prepared this chili for a neighborhood competition and hands down everyone thought this was the best tasting chili of the day and a couple of people asked for the recipe.  I cooked it for 2 hours the day prior to the competition, refrigerated it over night, and then reheated it for the competition.  I used an 8 quart stock pot which was perfect, leaving about 2 inches of room from the top of the rim.  The beer of choice for me was Fat Tire amber ale and would highly recommend since it pairs nicely with the beef and Italian sausage.  I used a chuck roast and asked the butcher to do a coarse chili grind (once through the grinder rather than the standard 2 times).  I followed the recipe exactly but left out the salt with intentions of salting to taste prior to the competition, but in the end it didnt need it.  For the chili powder I used Gebhardts to give it that classic chili flavor that most people know and love.  I also used Mexican oregano instead of the standard oregano and ground it to a powder with a mortar and pestle to help release more of the flavor.

This was AWESOME. My neighbor and her 5 kids helped me make this one and oh my gosh did we make some chili. We ended up tripling the original recipe. What I changed: subbed out the chili peppers for one habanero (GREAT idea BTW), nix the sugar, and one of the kids accidently opened 2 cans of black beans. Well, we threw them in, great for the texture as the black beans hold a little firm. Honestly, my neighbor was wary of bullion and worcestershire but it turned out perfect! This and some Southern cornbread is heaven on a 'chilly' day! I brought some in to work and coworkers think it's a family recipe, this recipe is a total hit. Oh, and if you like things spicy (I do, the kids didn't so I omitted it for their 2 pots) try using a habanero based hot sauce in addition to the tabasco and a habanero. Just make sure you can tell the spicy pot apart! ;)

text:
UPDATE: Today's batch of this chili was made using ground turkey instead of beef (still added the sausage) and I used about 4 chipotle peppers in adobo sauce (canned variety, 4 individual peppers) to add the kick my family enjoys. I inevitably end up making it slightly different than the recipe. I've made this several times now - each time with dry beans instead of canned. I soak them overnight and then use beef broth instead of bullion cubes (not 4 cans though, only 1 can) I never have bacon bits so I use real bacon, cooked and chopped up. I also like a bit more kick so I use jalapenos (either fresh or canned) instead of "green chili" peppers. If red bell peppers aren't on sale I just double the green. Other than that - I follow exactly and it turns out very delicious. This recipe makes a lot and we are just a family of 4 so I usually invite friends over. They don't like spice so I make a small pot without cayenne or hot pepper sauce or chili peppers. Both taste good though I much prefer the hot and spicy version I create. Thanks for a great recipe! Last time I made way to much and forgot to freeze the difference which I will do this time so it doesn't go to waste.

text:
Awesome recipe! I made the following changes: used 4 slices of real bacon rather than the bacon bits, added a dash of liquid smoke, used 2 cans mild chili beans, one can hot chili beans, and 1 can kidney beans (drained). Used 3 (14 oz) cans of diced tomatoes. Did not use the green chilis, red bell pepper (just because I didn't have one), celery, or tobasco sauce. Used only 2 lb of ground beef (no sausage just because I didn't have any). It was plenty of meat and plenty spicy, and makes PLENTY to go around (freeze the leftovers!). Cooked 6 hrs in the crock pot on high the day before. Put in fridge overnight and reheat before serving. Serve with sour cream and shredded cheese. awesome!

My husband will not stay out of the crock pot!  He is usually a little hesitant of crock pot meals, but he has eaten almost the entire thing- which means he may have a heart attack in the near future. This is delicious, I just wish it wasn't so fattening- so I used italian turkey sausage instead of pork and used lean ground beef instead of ground chuck.  I followed another's suggestion and allowed this to cool and then skimmed off the excess fat.  So, I don't feel so guilty for feeding this to my family. During the cooking process, I added a little water and chicken broth (instead of beer) and next time, I won't use 4 buillon cubes- it seemed a little too salty for me.  I also used 3 cans of spicy undrained chili beans, one large can of tomatoes and no tomato paste as this thickens during the cooking process. It is a success.... What would I do without this website?  We would all probably starve.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
BRAVO! This is about the best chili recipe I've come across in years! Not sure what the Tbsp. of Bacon Bits was for though... I did add it in, but still not sure why. One small Tbsp. got lost in all the rest of the great flavors! I also went ahead and added a whole bottle of beer rather than the 1/2 cup. (I used Amberbock.) I also added a couple of diced jalapenos...the taste was perfection! We didn't even add hot sauce in our plates because it was just right, and we are the type to ALWAYS add more Tabasco. Thanks for this fabulous recipe! We LOVE, LOVE, LOVE it! UPDATE AS OF 2/2/09: After making this several times now, I have figured out the bacon bit theory! For the quantity this makes, I fry up 5 or 6 thick slices of bacon, set it aside and crumble it into the mix later. Then use the bacon drippings to saute the onion, celery and garlic. Adds wonderful background flavor!!! This always gets rave reviews, as you can tell from the vast number of excellent ratings it's gotten.

I made this for my daughter, whose boyfriend was having a beer tasting party.  She is not really one to pass out compliments, but made sure to let me know that everyone made a fuss over the chili. Best Chili Ever.  I have made this twice.  The first time I didn't have some of the ingredients but made it anyway.  It was delicious.  The second time I made an effort to get more of the ingredients this recipe calls for and it was even better.  I did make some modifications to suit my own taste.  I sauteed the onions, green peppers, red peppers, and celery before adding to the beans and ground beef.  Instead of bacon bits I used regular bacon.  I cooked the bacon, cut it up and put it in the pot.  It's such a nice treat to run in to Italian sausage and bacon when eating it.  I did not add beer because I don't drink it and did not want to buy a six pack to get one can.  It didn't need it anyway, the chili is fabulous.  To add spicyness without it being hot I added a can of Rotel tomatoes and "Red Hot" hot sauce.  Red Hot adds heat and it has a great flavor.  All hot sauces do not taste good.  My chili can out mild but the flavor is incredible!  Thanks a lot!

text:
I made this recipe for a chili cookoff where I work and won first place. I used hot Italian sausage, jalepeno peppers instead of all the other peppers, two large cans of tomato puree instead of diced tomatoes and tomato paste and omitted the celery and bacon bits.  When I browned the ground beef and sausage, I added the jalepeno peppers and onions. What a wonderful smell in the kitchen! I put all of the ingredients in the crock pot to simmer all night. Then when I went to work, I reheated the chili. There was plenty of time for all of the ingredients to blend into wonderful flavor. The judges of the competition were local firemen. The "heat" of this chili did not hit them right away, but after about twenty or thirty seconds, they were looking for milk! The entire pot of chili was devoured by all who attended and I was the envy of the competition. Thanks for a great recipe. Don and Sharon Evans

text:
This chili is amazing. I made it for a party that a friend and I were throwing. She made a Barefoot Contessa chicken chili and I made this one. Everyone preferred the Boilermaker chili and my friend asked for the recipe :) I made a few changes so it wouldn't be too spicy for a big crowd which worked perfectly - 3 Tablespoons of chili powder, no Tabasco (I figured people could add it after the fact if they wanted more spice) and no chili peppers. I also decided to use 3 lbs of beef chuck and no sausage. I just like the consistency better. I served the chili in a buffet with things they could add in - avocado slices, sliced jalapenos, sour cream, shredded cheese and diced onions. We had chili left over and ate it the next day. It was even better so I suggest making a day ahead.

text:
I made this as my first homeade chili, and followed the recipe exactly. I've made this about 4 times now, and I dont even look at other chili recipies, because I dont think chili can get any better than this. I usually put the chili in a slow cooker and cook on low for about 8-10 hours, until the veggies get soft. I also followed one review, and sauted onion, celery, and garlic in bacon grease. I always use about 5-6 slices of fried bacon, and I definately think this adds to the flavor. Also, I also follow other reviews (If I have the time, and plan ahead accordingly haha) and cook the day before, let cool, and reheat the next day. Seems like it helps the flavors all blend toghether this way. Again, I don't think Ill ever change too much about this recipe, it is awesome. Gives me a reason to throw parties, or get toghethers, just so other people can experience this stuff haha...

text:
SO YUMMY.

These are the changes I've made over time: leave out the beer; use 1 or no chili peppers (d/o mood); replace two of the chili bean cans with 2 cans of black beans (I like the change-up in colors w/ black beans). I'm sure it would be great without these changes, but I don't care for beer and I reduce the qty of chili peppers to reduce the heat. This chili punched me in the face the first time I made it with all the peppers. Besides, there is plenty of heat w/o the peppers so I figure it's fine. IMPORTANT NOTE: Wash beneath your nails (or wear gloves) after preparing everything, and again after putting all the spices in the pot. I neglected to wash the pepper juice out well enough one time when making this, and the internal burning nearly reached my elbows. Seems like a little common sense, yes, but sometimes I don't think. Also, use your biggest pot. I tried this out in my 6qt slow cooker the first time and it doesn't fit. I use a stock pot and it fits nicely.

In the end this will be probably be the best chili you've ever eaten. All these ingredients, and the cost, is totally worth the effort.

text:
A fantastic chili recipe!! Everyone that tried my chili raved about how it was the best they'd ever had. You could actually see the reaction on their faces as they ate it. I did make a few additions/substitutions. I liked what 1 reviewer said about not using bacon bits and instead crisping up 4 slices of bacon. Btw, bacon bits is not real bacon at all. Why not have the real thing? Anyway, I also followed the same reviewers advice, and sauteed the celery, garlic and onion in a 1/2 tbsp of bacon grease until the onion is translucent. I also added 1 mexican (red) jalapeno, hoping it would add to the spiciness, but I don't think it did. I may add a couple more next time. I also didn't have cayenne pepper on had, so I used 2 teaspoons of chipotle chili powder, and I also added an extra teaspoon of chili powder as well. It really went well with the Fritos, I used the lightly salted Fritos, because I didn't want to add to the salt content too much. I also used shredded sharp cheddar cheese as well. It was fantastic!!!

text:
Really great chili recipe.  I made the following (minor) modifications -- 1) substituted 1 pound ground pork for one of the 2 pounds of ground chuck, and used 1/2 pound andouille sausage and 1/2 pound chorizo in lieu of the italian sausage 2) used 4 cubes of "Not beef" bouillon rather than beef bouillon (can find these at Whole Foods) since I'm not a fan of the various unnatural ingredients found in typical beef bouillon), 3) added a tablespoon of cocoa as some other reviewers suggested for flavor depth, 4) used 3 cans of beans instead of 4 and 5) fried up black forest bacon (also found at Whole Foods) instead of bacon bits.

I made this a day ahead, simmered on the crock pot for a couple hours, and then the next day re-warmed in the crock and simmered for a couple hours before eating.  Will definitely make it again!

text:
I turned this into a slow cooker chili & am so glad I did!  Here's what I did: Cook the ground beef and Italian sausage in a frying pan.  While it's cooking, dice the onions and a few cloves of garlic.  Once the meat is almost done, drain the fat, then toss in the onions & garlic and cook until browned, several minutes.  Throw that in the crockpot with the rest of the ingredients & voila!  It was ready (& delicious!) after only 2 hours on low, but I am sure will be even better when it simmers longer so I've left it on low for a few more hours.  

I also halved this recipe and it turned out great.  I used a little more beer (and still a full onion) and the flavor was just right - a good amount of heat but not "make me cry" hot!  Thanks for sharing, this is wonderful!

text:
This is a great standard chili recipe that can be adapted based on what you have on hand/need to use up/etc..  I used a can of chili beans and a can of pinto beans, also used all ground beef.  I halved the recipe and used beef broth instead of bullion and used a decent amount because I wanted a slightly soupy/less thick chili.  I also didn't add the beer (didn't want to waste one for only a 1/4 cup).  I ran out to run some errands and just put the pot of chili (in a dutch oven pot) into the oven at 350 for 2 hours. Easy as can be!

text:
this recipe is a keeper. 

I followed the recipe exact in regards to the spices/seasonings, but instead of the ground beef chuck I used a 60/40 version of ground beef, ground pork. I also used some chorizo, a package of bacon cut into 2" chunks that I browned lightly in the frying pan then added to the pot .. for the beans I added 2 cans of a '6 bean medley' that I found at the grocery store.. then I pureed some jalapenos with some hot red chili peppers and put that in there with the red hot sauce and omitted the 1/4 C. chili powder.. the spice was perfect. used a 'aged oak ale' that has a real nutty/honey flavor, and monterey jack cheese with the tortilla chips for the finale... did let it sit over night, it thickens and is perfect. makes alot for leftovers/in the freezer..

text:
I also felt this was a good base recipe. I omitted the bouillon, additional salt, hot sauce, bacon bits, the peppers, beef chuck, italian sausage,tomato paste,beer, fritos and rinsed my beans. I also added mushrooms for more "heartiness", some liq. smoke and 24oz of some basil tomato spaghetti sauce (i ran out of tomato sauce) along with 2 (28 oz) cans of diced tomatoes with basil/oregano/garlic, 1.5-2 T of celery seeds(since I didn't have celery) and I used ground turkey and ground turkey sausage which I added within the last hour. I cook it about 2.5 to 3 hrs stirring every 20-30 min. And tweak it as needed towards the end. I'm no expert but my family and I like it. I serve with some simple buttery crackers, a melted slice of cheese and a sprinkle of some parm.

text:
I actually won a chili cook-off with this recipe recently.  I substitued cured salt pork for the bacon bits, wine for the beer, honey for the sugar, and fresh herbs from my garden for all the dried ones recommended.  I also used hot peppers from my own garden, which nearly got me in trouble - at first taste the chili was distractingly spicy with an uninspiring after taste.  With advice from a friend this was improved by adding a few dollops of yogurt and a two squares of dark chocolate.   I let the chili sit for a day, then warmed it up again ever so slowly.  It was fun to watch everyone go back for seconds.

text:
If you REALLY want to make a GREAT chili, PLEASE do yourself a favor and make this one!! Being a person who does not like alot of heat in dishes I prepare  I did not use the 2 green chile peppers or the Tabasco. I minced four large cloves of garlic for the minced garlic it called for, and I used 3 cans of Bushes MILD chili beans WITH all the liquid. I omitted the red bell pepper, because I felt $2.00 was too much to pay for 1 pepper, I used beef boullion granules, and for the bacon I fried 3 pieces of good thick bacon and chopped it up rather than use the imitation bacon bits. I felt it needed a touch more of a sweet taste, so I put in about 1/8 cup of brown sugar!  YUM!!

Oh my  goodness! This was the best chili I've ever had. I'm rating it based on some of the alterations that others had suggested, and what I had used based on availability. But wow! This is so easy to tweak to your own personal tastes. 
I used 1 lb of Bob Evan's Zesty sausage instead of the italian sausage, kept the ground chuck the same, increased the amount of beer as others stated, only used one can of chili beans because no one in my house is a big fan of heavily beaned chili, and didn't use red or green peppers because I'm not a big fan of them and didn't have any but the Zesty Sausage already has a pretty decent kick to it anyway...YUM!
This chili is so hearty and delicious and just explodes with flavor! I will be using this recipe over and over again.

text:
STOP LOOKING! This is the best chili recipe! The modifications I made were only because I didn't have a couple ingredients so I substituted, and personally I think it turned out to my advantage!! I fried 4 strips of hickory smoked bacon and crumbled it up, instead of using bacon bits. I used chunks of steak meat, cut in thin strips instead of 2lbs of ground, because I only had steak/stew meat. I will always use steak meat anyways- it was delicious, the meat was falling apart, and it made the chili chunkier! Instead of Italian sausage I used a yummy hot sausage, cut into chunks. I fried each of the meats separately before throwing them in the crock pot, draining the fats. I tossed the steak meat in garlic powder, salt, and flour and browned it in a pan. Then, I used wine instead of beer to clean up the pan of all the flour and spices that were stuck and poured it into the crock pot. I also added at the very end, 2 tablespoons of cornmeal, because I like my chili thick, and it looked a little soupy before I did that. My husband came home from work, tried a spoonful and said, "I want this for dinner tonight!" I tried telling him we're supposed to eat it the next day, but it was so delicious he wanted it right away!! Still, we have plenty leftovers for tomorrow, and by all the reviews it's supposed to be even better!! I can't imagine that! My husband says it's a keeper and he wants me to enter it in this years chili cookoff! Thank you so much for sharing this wonderful recipe!

text:
This is a wonderful chili recipe. I chopped up 2 lbs of steak tips rather than ground beef chuck because that was what I had on hand. I substituted MorningStar Farms vegetarian sausage patties, chopped, for the bulk Italian sausage. I used 2 cans of mild chili beans with sauce, 1 can of garbanzo beans and 1 can of black beans. I did not use celery or beer. Instead of 2 chili peppers, I used one serano pepper, chopped with seeds removed. I left out the bacon bits. I substited one 14.5 oz can of beef broth for the 4 bouillon cubes. I cut down on the chili powder just a smidge and added 3 teaspoons of hot sauce rather than 2. I used Sriracha Hot Chili Sauce. I substituted 1 teaspoon of maple syrup for the sugar because I am a big fan of maple syrup. I sauteed the vegetables and spices in some bacon fat in a stock pot first, browned the beef in a separate pan, tossed everything in with the vegetables and cooked it over medium heat for 20 minutes. Doing it this way cut down on the overall cooking time and developed the flavor of the spices. I would make this again with these adjustments, except I might try using ground chuck or ground beef, which would be more cost effective. Thanks for the recipe.

I just made this chili today and it was pretty good, but probably not worth the trouble.

I did omit a few things; the worcestershire sauce because I didn't have any; the 1 tbsp of bacon bits because I didn't see how that could possibly make a difference; and one can of beans because I ran out of room in my large crockpot.

Love this chili!  Made it while my family was here for the holidays, and everyone enjoyed it.  All the different peppers and hot sauce made me a little nervous, but put them all in, and it was perfect.  We aren't beer drinkers, so left that out and added a little water, but think I'll add it next time ... and there will be a next time!  Leftovers froze well, and I'm enjoying the last bowl as I type!  Thanks for sharing this one.  (Update 2 years later:  Have made this several times and always turns out great.  Made a double batch today in my turkey roaster ... perfect size! 16 people finished off all but 3 bowls, which were scarfed up as "doggy bags".  Just thought it was worth noting that this does not look like typical chili at first! Without the usual heavy tomato sauce/paste base many people are used to, what you see, initially, is just a big pot of tomatoes, peppers and ground meat!  As the tomatoes and beans begin to break down during the long cooking time, it begins to look less like ground beef soup and more like chili should look, so don't let the initial "look" concern you.  And I do add the beer now, which does add to the complex flavor, although I have yet to add those bacon bits!  I will try real bacon some time.

text:
I have made this probably 8-10 times. I started out exactly as stated and it was excellent. I like to experiment a little with other suggestions here and tried many most did not taste as good as the original recipe. This last batch was by far the best I have made. It was close to the main recipe but here is what I did. I used a little less than 3lbs ground chuck and 1 pound Kroger brand Hot Sausage. I used 3 cans beans not 4: 1 can chili beans, 1 can pinto beans and 1 can black beans all drained. 6 stalks medium sized celery, I didn't have any chili peppers so I added 1TB crushed red pepper (like you put on pizza), 2TB Hormel Real bacon bits, no beer but substituted 1 can chicken broth, 3TB Worcestershire sauce, 4TB Franks Hot Sauce, 2 tsp cayenne, 2 tsp sugar. Then added 2TB Hershey's Dark Cocoa for coloring.  After cooking in slow cooker for 8 hours on low I put in refrigerator overnight.Then made some sweet cornbread with jalapeno in the iron skillet with added 1/4 cup good grade syrup to the batter and melted bacon grease in skillet before adding batter. FOLKS...this was the best and everyone in the family agreed...it was gone in less than an hour. I will do this exact recipe again.

text:
More like 4.5 stars, as I've got pretty high chili standards. We make and eat a lot of chili, and have made this several times. This is one of our favorites...especially when we have time to make it. It has really good, complex flavor and like all chili, tastes even better the 2nd day after the flavors have a chance to meld together. It does take some time to make, with all the chopping and prep, but have fun and enjoy the process! I Made this along with Wazzu Tailgate Chili, and we kept flip-flopping as to which one we preferred. This will stay in the rotation. I admit this next statement isn't a news flash, but really, the quality/brand of the ingredients makes a huge difference as to the flavor. Chili Powder is a BIG one. I use Morton's and Bassett and Penzy's mostly. I get Italian sausage from an Italian market where it's made fresh. Canned tomatoes are really affect final outcome and I've found Muir Glen Organic and Hunt's have the best flavor (to our taste buds). If you like big chunks, the MG is the way to go. For people who prefer a smoother, less chunky texture, Hunt's petite diced is a good option. "Heat", is a personal thing, so adjust accordingly. I can't to a lot of heat, so I cut the proportions of the hot ingredients accordingly and omitted the hot sauce, otherwise, I could tell from the recipe, it would've been too hot for me.  Really a great chili, beans and all.

text:
Best chili recipe I've tried so far. I really like the flavor added from the beer-- we used a full cup of Yeungling amber lager. There are many ingredients, but getting a pre-chopped bell pepper blend and using a can of green chiles removed some of the chopping work for me. I sauteed my peppers and onions after cooking the meat, and I omitted the celery. After browning the meat and vegetables, everything cooked in my crockpot for a few hours, went into the fridge overnight, then heated in the crockpot again the next day until it was time for dinner. I worried it would be too spicy based on some reviews, but it wasn't at all. I might even add more cayenne or Tobasco next time. My husband has never loved the chili I've made before, but he and our dinner guest both thought this batch was great.  This will be my standard chili recipe now.

text:
Awesome chili!  I can see why it won so many chili cook-offs.  The beer imparts a great flavor.  I used half a can of Yuengling.  Don't waste your time with light beer or you'll miss the flavor.  I followed the recipe exactly with regard to the seasonings, but used stew beef which I chopped into small bits.  I also changed the cooking order a bit. Start out in a large dutch oven.  I sauteed five slices of bacon, cut into small pieces and removed from the pan  when crispy.  Then brown the beef in the bacon fat in batches, removing it to the same plate with the bacon. My beef was so lean that it absorbed all the fat.  Next brown the sausage and add the chopped vegetables.  The fat rendered from the sausage will allow the vegetables to soften. I used just one large green pepper and two large hot chili peppers (one green & one red) which I unseeded but did not remove the membranes in order to preserve the heat. Add your dry spices next and sautee a bit so they have a chance to bloom. Instead of two large cans of tomatoes, I used one can plus two cans of petite diced tomatoes with green chilis.  Then add the boullion, beer and Worcestershire sauce.  Last are the beans--one can of chili beans in sauce (undrained), one can of dark red kidney beans and one can of pintos, both drained and rinsed.  Transfer the chili to a slow cooker and cook on high for about 5 hours.  Excellent!  Thanks for sharing!

text:
This was my first attempt at making chili, but since we were having a chili cook off for our annual Memorial Day cook out, I thought it would be fun to make and this recipe appealed to me. I made a few changes: I thought the use of Italian sausage was strange and substituted 1lb of cubed Andouille sausage instead and 1lb of cubed chuck roast. I fried 4 large strips of bacon, softened the vegetables in the bacon fat, then browned the chuck roast in the same pan and followed by the Andouille just to heat it up a bit. I started with about 1/4 of the chili powder and pepper sauce and increased the amount at the end as needed. Also used brown sugar instead of white and a bottle of IPA, 1 can of black beans, 1 can of kidney beans,and 1 can of chili beans. Stirred it up and placed in a slow cooker for 8 hrs. Let it cool down for a few hours and then back in the base let it reheat while adjusting the spiciness. I didn't tell anyone I had made chili and after a blind taste test by the crowd my chili was chosen the winner! I declined the prize however since as the host I thought it seemed a bit tacky to one up my guests. But thanks for the recipe. Definitely a keeper and people were asking for the recipe.

text:
This is an excellent chili recipe and I won 1st place out of ten contestants. I made it the night before, cooked (simmered) it for about 2.5 hours, let it cool and then placed it in the fridge.  It is more flavorful the next day - trust me as I made it for superbowl weekend to test on my wife and we both agree it was much better the next day.  I modified it a bit and used real bacon as others recommended and sautd the onions, celery and garlic in the bacon grease.  I used 1 lb Black Angus cube steak, 2lbs ground beef and 1 lb spicy Italian sausage. I browned the cube steak then added the ground beef and Italian sausage.  Drained the grease then added the rest of the ingredients. I also substituted the sugar with brown sugar. This is so easy and so flavorful and I won 1st place the second time making it... Enough said.

text:
Followed to a "T" except for one simple sub:  I used 1lb Italian Sausage, 1lb Ground Chuck, and 1lb Ground Turkey Breast.  Let it simmer all day (about 8 hours) stirring every hour or so.  FANTASTIC!  We make a great chili, but this bests it for sure!  It is a bunch of prep/ingredients but I just did all my chopping, put in a bowl, then measured out all the spices and put into another bowl, then finally measured the liquid ingredients and put them in a bowl.  Brown/drain the meat, open cans and dump (draining the non-spicy beans first) then pour the bowls in, and mix well.  Really not that difficult if you have all this stuff on hand.  I used Heinekin beer (2/3 of a bottle (don't ask where the 1st third went at 10am while chopping))  :)  My new go-to recipe for chili!  OH, and this makes about 4-5 quarts - so be prepared for an army or lots of leftovers!    (Next time I will add a bit of dark chocolate to the concoction).   THANK YOU FOR SHARING!

text:
I used this recipe as a sort of guideline to make chili that was catered more to my taste. It came out flippin' fantastic. Here are some of the changes I made: first and foremost, I used ground turkey instead of beef. No you can't tell the difference, yes it is way healthier for you and will skim a bunch of calories off of that terrifying 600 number. Second, I bypassed the sausage (also skimming a ton of unnecessary calories) and got a little inventive to pick up the texture; I used, bear with me, 20 oz of sweet potato! I know, but trust me on this, it's not only healthy, but absolutely delicious. Also, I used 2 medium chili beans and 2 mild, because I don't like crying while I eat. Ha. Anyway, it still had kick. I skipped the celery (didn't have any) and bacon (for health) and used one yellow pepper instead of red and green (didn't have any of those either). I only used one green chile pepper (I have a plant, so they're more potent) and got the diced tomatoes with chile peppers in them to make up for it. I used four beef bouillon cubes, but added a fifth, somewhat larger cube which I assume was chicken bouillon (don't ask). I think I only put 1/4 cup chili powder, but the container sort of slipped and.. oh well. I like thick chili, so I skipped the beer and added one can each of black beans and corn to make it chunkier. I didn't have cayenne, so skipped that and added about 1/4 cup brown sugar to the white for taste. I topped it with cornbread, cheese, AND sour cream. YUMMM

text:
I have made this recipe 4 times now, once for a fundraiser and it got rave reviews.  My husband is a traditional chili fan and he did not find any taste difference with or without italian sausage.  Other changes that I have made (not all at the same time): used 3 cans rotel tomatoes with habaneros, and there was absolutely no need to put in any chili powder, or tabasco, or cayenne.  It was medium towards hot spicy with just the tomatoes. I always add a full can/bottle of beer.  I omitted the beef bouillons twice and no change in taste. I have omitted Tabasco even when not using rotel tomatoes and still no change in taste.  I used liquid smoke once and came out delicious (1-2 tsp), used sliced jalapenos instead of chopped chile peppers and no change in taste; also completely omitted them with spicy tomatoes and never noticed.  I have used just 2 lbs beef and no more meat and it was great.

text:
This is a great recipe, everytime I make it I get rave reviews from everyone.  This is probably the only recipe that I actually use every spice, and measure them out exactly!!! The only things I chaged were using real bacon (4 slices) , then sautee the onion, celery, and peppers in the bacon fat. Also, for one of the cans of "chili beans" I substitued a can of "tri-colored beans" (black beans, pinto beans, and kidney beans) just to give some extra flavors and colors to the pot.

Made this superbowl sunday and it was a big hit! I prepared it the day before and it was great after spending a day in the fridge! I was afraid it might be too spicy, but in fact turned out to be not that spicy at all. I added extra hot sauce to the crock pot on Sunday. Flavors were excellent, everyone loved it. text:
I have used this recipe as my basis of my chili for the past 3 years and have heard many great reviews.  I tweak the seasoning ratio by the way it smells and add dash of clove and cinnamon along with the rest of them but I use it super sparingly because you can really kill a recipe by going overboard.  I feel like it empasizes the sweetness of the chili this way.  I love to use Chipotle Tobasco sauce along with Tapatio and Habenero sauce.  Instead regular bacon bits I also use canadian bacon.  I feel like you should go big or go home when it comes to bacon and it seems to taste better especially as far as texture goes.  Some beer can really make a difference when cooking with it so be careful what you dump in and don't use a really strong beer, although malty beer can make it seem to taste sweeter, more of a molases undertone. Definitely a grat reipe alone but if you tweak it to your taste it can be the most amazing staple you keep in  your freezer!

text:
First, let me say I never rank and comment, so you know this chili must be to die for... 
Made this chili last weekend.  It was without question the best chili I've ever made.  I made only slight modifications, as follows:  used cubed chuck beef cut in large chunks, used slightly less chili powder and lightly chipole hot sauce.  I was worried about the heat, but it was perfect.  I could probably have used the specified amounts with no problem.  I brought in to a night simmer on top of the stove in a cast iron casserole, then baked it for 3 hours (grate at the lowest level in the overn) at 300 for 1 1/5 hours, the 275 for the remaining).  Truly, you won't be disappointed.

text:
I've made a few chili recipes over the years and this is by far the best chili I've ever made. In fact we're going to enter it into a local chili contest, because it was better than any we tried at the most recent cook off. I did make a few changes to the recipe. I used regular ground beef instead of ground chuck. I also used hot italian sausage instead of regular. I used two cans of chili in spicy sauce and two cans of regular chili beans. I substituted beef demi glace for the bouillon cubes and jalapeno peppers for the green chili peppers. And because my wife doesn't like green bell peppers I used an orange one instead. I also used a regular lager for the beer (Yuengling). Simmered it for 3 hours and served it with a dolop of sour cream and shredded mexican cheese on top. Instead of corn chips, we served it with beer bread that we made from a Pampered Chef recipe. It was awesome!! Not too spicy, not too sweet, just perfect!

text:
A++++ for this recipe. I got rave review from my family and friends. I halved the recipe, and used all ground beef instead of bulk pork, since I couldn't find any at the store. Because of that, I added a tsp of ground fennel seeds. I left out the cayenne pepper and used only 1 tbsp of chili powder to cut down on spice. It still had a kick and bold flavor. The only thing I would change for next time is omit the extra salt (it's plenty salty enough with all the other ingredients), and put less cooked onion and add raw chopped red onion as a topping (suggestion of a friend who's a chili fanatic). Definitely making this again!!!

I havnt made to much chili in my 21 years but this one tops it all! I LOVE the different types of veggies (red/green peppers and Celery) Adds alot of color to it...I did make a few changes of course--- --Was running out of room in my crock pot so put 2 cans of dark kidney beans and 1 can of spicy chili beans --Took another reviewers suggestion, cooked my own bacon then sauteed HALF of the onions and celery in the grease along with the garlic --The meat I browned all together in a large pot using mild italian sausage squeezed out of its casing, drained well then I rinsed extra well in warm water (I dont like a greasy chili) Next time I think I will also add a little water once drained and rinsed and season for a while with some chili spices ---I also left out Tabasco and any other spicy pepper (I do not like spicy foods!)  ---A very flavorful chili, I served with homemade cornbread muffins as well  I plan on making this Chili again doubling the recipe to make a very spicy version and my mild one for my baby shower in a month.

text:
I think this turned out really well!  It is a long list of ingredients, but I put the spices together the day before just to save time and energy.  I'm also a fan of mise en place, so I gathered EVERYTHING together before getting started so as to not have to fall over a cat or dog while scurrying around.  Changes include:  1) Used 3 cans of plain old red kidney beans, drained and rinsed (don't like tinny flavor). 2) Added red pepper flakes to make up for lack of "spicy sauce" in beans. 3) No bacon 4) No bouillon 5) Full bottle of beer (corsenbach) 6) Saute onion separately in small skillet. 6.5) Softened peppers and celery, then added meat to brown. 7) Moved meat mixture and everything else to slow cooker and cooked on low for about 6 hours. Awesome!

I did not put the cayenne pepper or the can of spicy beans in this chili because I was scared that it was too hot.  I also used brown sugar instead of white sugar and I added in way more than what the recipe said.  The secret to this chili is to let it simmer for a while. This recipe is too big for 2 people, so I ended up freezing a bunch of it.

Um... Only the BEST chili EVER! I wish I could give it 10 stars! Seriously it really is so good! I followed the recipe almost exactly. The only thing I had to change was the meat. I used 2 lbs cubed chuck roast instead of ground.(that's what my butcher had. He cut a roast in small cubes) but I still also used 1 lb of Italian sausage. And another thing, I used 4 slices cooked bacon instead of bacon bits. I also cooked everthing in my crockpot. I first browned the cubed chuck in a skillet just to sear the outsides enough to keep the juices in.     Then cooked the sausage and bacon and threw everything in the crockpot and put it on low. I let it cook pretty much all day then warmed it up the next day! Its SO yummy! The chuck cubes just fall apart in your mouth! I will never use another recipe again!! Thank you SO much for this fabulous chili! Yay!

Wow, this chili was good! It had a mild, gentle heat, so the kids could eat it too. Like some other reviewers, I cooked my own bacon, and then sauteed the veggies in some of the drippings. I also cut up my own chuck roast instead of using ground, and browned that first too. I put everything in a crock pot (mine is 7 quarts, and it was FULL), and cooked on low for 8 hours. I used one can each of kidney, pinto, and black beans for the "chili beans", and one can of "ranch-style beans" for the beans with chili sauce. I also didn't know I was so low on cumin, so I didn't have very much in there, but with all the other flavors going on, I didn't miss it! I will definitely make this one again.

It does seem like alot of ingredients but definitely well worth it..  if you want to make a great chili that will be everyones favorite.. then make this chili.. the best!!!! Yum!

Another 5 star review!  1st Place out of 8 in a friendly chili cook-off yesterday.  Only changes I made:  I used actual bacon (about 6 strips).  1 large habanero pepper (instead of 2 chiles), 3 cloves of garlic. Common comment was: it was the most balanced.  I cooked it the night before, refrigerated and reheated.  It lost much of its heat, but a slight tingle in the aftertaste.  I thought it was a tiny bit strong with the chili powder flavor.  Next time I will back the chili powder down to 3 tblspn and kick up the heat from another source (another habanero or other chili peppers - maybe spicy italian sausage - maybe wasabe!).  Awesome recipe >>  make it your own.

text:
BEST CHILI I HAVE EVER HAD! That's saying a lot, since I've eaten a lot of chilis. This is so much better than the chilis that you order at restaurants boasting "best chili in _insert city name here_" This chili packs a punch, so if you have GERD, this is not for you... I cut down the chili powder to 3 tablespoons and 1 teaspoon of hot sauce and it was still spicy, but tolerable. I added 1 cup of beer, omitted Worcestershire (didn't have it) and paprika (in my opinion, paprika adds only color and no flavor). This is probably the most complete chili recipe you'll ever come across. This is really, truly excellent. Perfect over rice, on buns, on noodles... the possibility is endless. I'm sure it freezes well and will still retain its heavenly taste reheated, but I have a feeling you won't have leftovers for long.

text:
This is the BEST chili recipe out there!  The number of ingredients might steer some people away, but all of them bring the flavors together.  I've been making this for years and can't agree more with other reviewers who suggest refrigerating overnight and then heating the next day.  The flavors really meld together.  I've modified the recipe just a bit and wanted to share - I substitute ground beef with cube steak, use 2-3 slices of real bacon and saut all of the vegetables in the leftover grease.  I also tone down the spices of the beans to medium and mild and add spice at the end.  I also add a little dark chocolate in there, which is a trick  my mom always did growing up!  Can't say enough good things about this recipe - enjoy!!!

text:
Great recipe! I followed some of the adjustments recommended by other reviewers, and I got tons of compliments on it tonight. Here they are: 1 lb ground beef, 1 lb ground hot pork Italian sausage, and 1 lb sweet Italian turkey sausage. I did 2 cans of mild chili beans instead of 3, and one hot. I omitted the Tabasco sauce since I added the spicy sausage, and did one seeded jalapeo instead of the green chilies. I crumbled in 4 strips of bacon instead of bacon bits, and cooked the veggies in the bacon grease before adding them to the meat. Oh, and I used brown sugar instead of white. This was a huge hit, most people had second, if not third helpings. I will definitely make it again, and recommend making this recipe. It's kind of a long process with a lot of ingredients, but it's totally worth it. Yum!

text:
This chili is rather good.  I don't know that it is the best chili I've ever had but it is right up there with the best I've ever made and I've experimented quite a bit.  It would be very spicy if made as written.  I cut down the spice by leaving out the Tabasco, using a can of medium beans and cutting the chili powder down to 3 tablespoons and it still had quite a kick.  Other changes I made:  3 cans of total beans versus 4, real bacon instead of bits, the entire can of beer (just cuz it was too early to drink the rest) and for the meat I used, 1 lb of stew meat, 1 lb lean ground beef and 1 lb of chicken thighs (don't wrinkle your nose - it's good!).  After browning and sauting where appropriate, I simmered for 2 1/2 hours on the stove, poured into my slow cooker and refrigerated all night.  I put the slow cooker on low heat about 6 hours before dinner the next day and like I said it was very good.  I thought it was going to be too soupy and it could have been a little thicker but it was fine.  Probably more of a 4 1/2 star but since I've eaten better chili, I can't give it 5.  Next time I make this and I will, I will cut the cayenne back to 1/2 a teaspoon and add 14 ounces less tomatoes.  Depending on the time I might take a couple swigs of the beer before I pour it in.

I am only giving it 4 stars because there were a couple of draw backs: First, it took a really long time to prep.  Second, you NEED to use an extra large stew pot. text:
Last summer, my husband and I planted way too many tomato plants and I had to find things to do with all of them (I would rather freeze than can)- I skinned some tomatoes (a minute in boiling water to remove skins), cut them up, then used this recipe subbing 28 oz fresh tomatoes for the canned tomatoes. I chopped up the veggies and combined every ingredient (using beef base instead of cubes), EXCEPT beans and meat (and obviously the chips and cheese), in a large mixing bowl. I split the veggie mix in 3 freezer bags and froze them. When I was ready to try it out, it went from the freezer to the crock pot with 1 lb of cooked ground meat (think we just used beef) and 1 can (or more) of beans for 1 bag of veggie mix. I let it cook on low 6-8 hours, stirring occasionally. Yummy! I made another batch and gave the frozen bags with directions to my family and they all agreed that it was incredible! Awesome recipe. Now, the tomatoes are here again, so I came back to grab the recipe and do it again...mmmmmm

country:
None
text:
A really good chili base.  I made the following adjustments: 1lb cubed chuck steak in place of 1lb ground chuck, 4 strips bacon instead of bacon bits, light red kidney beans in place of 1 can of mild chili beans, 1/2 jalepeno and full Anaheim for chili peppers, double the garlic, sambal oleak in place of hot pepper sauce, full can of lite beer.  I browned the ground meats together, then browned the cubed steak, then fried the bacon, then partially cooked the celery, bell peppers, chili peppers, garlic, and onion in the leftover oils and juices.  I did drain each individual meat as it came off the pan.  Then everything into a dutch oven and simmer for 3 hours.  I cooled overnight, then heat and simmered another 2 hours the next night before serving.  It's spicy for some, but a can of crushed pineapple (or portion thereof) really helps cut the heat.
