text:
This is my go-to chili recipe! I'm from the east coast, so chili with beans is what I'm use to. I make a few modifications though. I omit the sausage, celery, bacon bits, beer, bouillon, and Worcestershire . All that is unnecessary if you want some down to earth chili (saves a lot of money too). Sometimes the tomato past (I don't think it does anything other than thicken the consistency). I also add a whole bell pepper for a half recipe (6 servings feeds a 3 person family for 2 days). I add 1 tablespoon unsweetened cocoa powder, and add more seasonings to taste (I may go overboard on the cumin - love that stuff). I add garlic powder as well as the minced garlic because it just tastes better,  honestly. I also cook the peppers and onions before adding to the chili. Drain the canned tomatoes, not the chili beans. Serve with shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream, saltine crackers and some red wine. Everyone loves this chili! I give it 4 stars because sausage and beer? Seriously? Save that for some other meal, or drink the beer with your chili.

text:
So, I made this tonight for the Super Bowl party and it was an absolute hit! The lights are out in the stadium now, so I decided to give my rendition of this recipe. I first started by cooking thick cut peppered bacon from Whole Foods and used the grease to cook the veggies (I added a teaspoon  minced jalapeo) then added all of the dry ingredients to bloom the flavors. I  also added 2 teaspoons of cocoa, molasses and Dijon mustard. Then I made a well in the Dutch oven and browned the Italian sausage, then the hamburger (I used 1/2 the amount of hamburger) and then added a pound of finely diced stew meat. Once that it was browned I brought it up to a very high heat and deglazed with beer until there was no grease left. I added the tomatoes and Bush's medium chili beans, half of the cans drained. I let it simmer for 5 hours and it was delicious!! I believe that this will be my go to chili recipe from now on.

text:
This is the best chili recipe ever! My family LOVES it and my kids ask for it over and over! I do modify it a little. I use 1 lbs lean ground beef and 1 lb lean ground turkey sausage to reduce the fat. I also blend the tomatoes as my kids don't like chunky tomatoes. I use chicken stock in place of the beer. And I just leave out the chili peppers as it is already plenty "HOT" for our liking without them. Very little modification but very, very tasty! Don't be afraid to give it a try! I always make it in the crockpot and let is simmer all day. It's always better that way and even better the next day! Makes a very large pot . . plenty of leftovers!!

text:
Since I only prepare this dish during the cooler months, somehow I forget just how delicious it is until we have it again. 
The only thing I purposely omit is the chile peppers. Besides that, I make adjustments for our personal preferences, such as an additional onion. A bit heavier on the seasonings and sugar, with the addition of garlic powder. I also put some seasoning on the meat as it browns.
We pair this with grated cheddar, cornbread, and sour cream. 
If I were making this for a potluck, I would definitely make a day ahead, as it tastes better the longer it sits in the refrigerator.

text:
Outstanding chili, enjoyed by all!  I made this for 4 Purdue Boilermaker students that were on their way back to Purdue from a collegiate water-ski tournament.  Not sure I've ever made a recipe that had 28 ingredients.  I used all of them, and the only change was to add the entire can of beer rather than 1/2 cup.  I don't like beer, but didn't want to waste it.......in the pot it went.  I put all the ingredients in the crock-pot about 7:30 am.  I took the lid off for 1 hour in the afternoon to thicken the chili while it cooked and then put the lid back on.  At 5:00 pm in the evening, the chili was perfect thickness.  I served this with 'Waikiki Cornbread' from AR and it was a wonderful side to this chili.  The kids loved it and all took leftovers home.  There is a reason there are over 2,600 reviews, still holds a 5-star rating, and one of AR's top 20 recipes.  This chili is just that good.  Don't take my word for it, try it for yourself.

My husband picked this recipe after he signed me up for a chili cook off at his squadron. We took 2nd place and I was told it was the first empty pot. I did make a few changes (because my husband is picky). I used busch's chili beans so I think they were 16oz cans. Here is the method I used. All ingredients in the pressure cooker, except meats and beans. Cook for 20 minutes. Release pressure according to instructions. Puree if you like. Add meats, beans and cook until done. Taste, readjust seasonings. Serve or let rest until next day!

text:
I enjoyed this dish, however I'm not the kind of man who places beans in my chili.  I would suggest using breakfast sausage because it's a hint sweeter and adds a unique flavor.  I didn't feel "bacon bits" would do justice, so I cut into 1cm x 1cm "extra thick cut bacon" and fried it.  The key is to drain the fat and not use it.  Makes for a mess if you don't and I learned from experience on that one.  This is why only 4 of 5 stars.  Aside from that, it was delicious.  Thank you MightyPurdue22 for this one.

This is the best chili ever. I followed the recipie pretty much as written except I increased the ground beef to #3  and used 4 cans of hot undrained chili beans. Also, I put all the ground beef and Italian sausage in 1 crockpot to warm up enough  so I could the drain the fat then chopped until crumbly and added it to a larger crockpot where I already had all the other ingredients warming. Once everything was combined, I let it cook for about 6 hrs. Then unplugged and  sit overnight. It's customary in my family that we have chili for Christmas eve family gathering, so I made this the day ahead, but several people have been sampling this throughout the day and I'm holdinig out hope there is enough for tonight's dinner? This recipie is a keeper...nothing wimpy about this at all. Now the big decision is weather I want to share the recipie with everyone????? Hmmmm, always something to decide. Thanks for the great recipie and Merry Christmas.

text:
This chili is AMAZING! I changed it up though since my husband and I don't eat red meat - and it was still amazing! We used lean ground turkey instead of beef, eliminated the sausage, beef bouillon cubes, and bacon. Also eliminated the celery, used a small can of chopped green chilis (couldn't find fresh ones at small market), and I was a little over-generous with a full cup of cheap light beer. The result was an AMAZING, incredible, LOW-FAT, lean chili. Of course, none of our guests were told it was a "healthy" version, and were none the wiser. I cooked it in my Crock Pot for 8 hours - it was gone 2 hours after that!

text:
This is my go-to chili recipe and it is always well received.  I use a combination of 1 lb. boneless New York strip steak that I cube, 1/2 lb. ground chuck and a 1/4 lb. hot bulk sausage for my meat.  I like things spicy, so I definitely add chopped hot peppers and I use Rotel diced tomatoes for extra flavor.  I top mine with shredded pepper jack cheese, sour cream, cilantro and diced avocado.  Instead of the corn chips, I thinly slice and fry in oil corn tortillas...adds a lot of authenticity!  Really great base recipe for all the spices and seasonings that chili needs!  Yum!  Yum!

Also for the beans I used 1 can black beans, 1 can of dark red kidney, and 1 can of light red kidney. The sausage added a really nice flavor! It's well worth breaking out all the seasoning. I measure and mix them together ahead of time so I can just add them all at once.

text:
I was talked into a chili cookoff and received very positive feedback.  I picked this recipe to start with.  In addition to the ingredients listed, I added the following: 1 lb of regular sausage, 6 oz tomato sauce, an extra chile and celery stalk.  For the bacon I used 2 slices and let the onion and garlic heat in the drippings while I was prepping the rest.  I didn't have beer, but didn't miss it.  I made it in the slow cooker the evening before and just put the crock in the frig at bedtime.  It reheated nicely and I think even improved the next day.  The spice combination is very nice and I like all the veggies which provided a nice texture and presentation.

This chili is superb. I changed it to suit my family's tastes by draining the cans of tomatoes and adding bloody mary mix in place of the juice. Also, we don't like lots of tomatoes in ours so I used only 3 14oz cans. I used 3 cans chili beans and one can red kidney beans. We don't like it quite so spicy/hot so I omitted the Tabasco and it is still plenty hot and flavorful. I also added 1Tbs fresh corriander (cilantro) and this gave it a very yummy flavor. I will be making this chili again.

I have made this chili over 20 times now and it is the best. The key in this recipe seems to be the boulion cubes, ground italian sausage, and sugar to keep down the acid. One twist I do with my chili is use bush chili beans with medium chili sauce instead of the drained cans chili beans, and I use 1 16 ounce can of dark red kidney beans instead of the can of chili beans in spicy sauce. I also add 1/2 pound of sirloin or filet steak bits.

text:
This is a great basic chile recipe.  I mix up the ingredients based on what I have on hand....If I don't have chile powder, I just add extra cayenne.  If I don't have beer, I don't add it....I personally like alot more garlic, so I add lot more.  Use whatever canned tomatoes you have on hand...Tomato paste, tomato sauce, crushed tomatoes, etc... If you like a thicker broth, add Masa Harina (avail. in the hispanic section of grocery store) Add about 1/4 cup to 1 cup of water and still and add to chile and bring back to boil and cook for about 5 extra minutes.  Real authentic tex mex flavor by doing this.

text:
This is perfect chili! I made it as written as much as possible. I didn't know how hot it would be so I used Aneheim peppers and cut back on the cayenne, black pepper and Tabasco. I didn't drain the chili beans and I used Ranch Style beans in place of the chili beans in spicy sauce. I left out the beer. I used smoked paprika. The result was fabulous! It might have been a little thicker if I had drained the chili beans, but it wasn't too thin either! I cooked the meat, drained it and added it to a crock pot with all the other ingredients to cook for 6 hours on high. Even though this recipe has a lot of ingredients, it's easy to make.

This was the first recipe I tried from this website and absolutely loved it!!! I made a few changes-I drain all the cans of beans, substituted half of the ground beef with cubed chuck steak that I browned first and took the easy way out using canned chopped green chilis and added canned diced jalapenos ( I like spicy chili). I used a dark beer ( Guinness one time, Sierra Nevada the next) and after cooking it according to the directions, I put it in the crockpot on low for 3-4 hours to tenderize the cubed chuck steak and allow the flavors to blend. I have been invited to three Superbowl parties this year on the condition I bring this chili!!! The best chili recipe EVER!!!!! I wasn't a Purdue fan but I am now!! :)

text:
I used 1lb. each of lean ground beef, lean ground turkey, and Italian turkey sausage in an effort to cut some calories and fat. Honestly, you couldn't tell by the taste. I used a 4.5 oz. can of green chiles instead of fresh due to availability. Other than that, I followed ingredient list exactly. Two things to keep in mind: this is a little hot for kids (but they did like it) so you may want to add hotter spices a little at a time. Also, this is a big batch!! After browning the meat, I combined everything in a very large bowl and immediately froze half. I put the other half in the crockpot and cooked on low for 10 hrs. It was delicious.

Ok, I'm a born and raised Texan and I would say this is a pretty decent chilli. Well I'm FROM Texas and this is a GREAT chili!!! It was really easy to make, just cook the meat and onions, drain, and toss the rest in a pot to simmer for the afternoon.   For anyone who complains about the ingredient list, it's pretty much the majority of the savory spices in your spice rack. I didn't really measure (never do) so it didn't take long at all to dump it all in and start it simmering. I did add a splash (tbsp?) of liquid smoke on a whim, but it didn't NEED anything. I didn't have bacon bits so I left that out, but next time I'll toss it in if I have it. Definitely will be making this again, what a hit! Oh and for the 'traditional' feel, try it with sweet cornbread instead of corn chips. SO GOOD!

This is the BEST chili recipe ever... 2nd time I made it, I made a few changes (just becuase I had the stuff in the house) and the results were even better! Changes I made: increase sausage to 1.5 lb; instead of 1T bacon I use 6 slices (cook it and crumble it); add in a can of corn niblets, use 5 fresh frozen basil leaves chopped up instead of dried basil, and use a whole can of bud (instead 1/2). I cook the chili the night before the game, simmering for 5-6 HOURS (Stir occasionally). Reheat at your tailgate party, and top with shredded cheddar.  YUM!

text:
I thought this recipe had a great foundation and then I played with it to suit my own tastes. I cooked everything on the stove in a huge pot. I used 1 1/3 lbs. ground chuck, 1 lb. Italian sausage and 1/3 lb. chopped bacon. I did not use bacon bits, real bacon has much better flavor. I only used one 28oz can of diced tomatoes, 2 cans of chili beans in medium sauce, 1 15oz can of diced tomatoes and green chiles, 2 jalapenos- 1 seeded, 1 not seeded, 3 cubes of beef bouillion instead of 4 and then did all the spices and veggies the recipe called for and adjusted the spiciness to suit my preference and I thought it was great. I know some people will say to follow the recipe if you're going to review it and I'm sure it's good the way it's written as well, but the fun in cooking is making it your own. Great recipe!

text:
Fabulous chili. Even though the ingredient list is long it comes together quickly. I almost-sorta even made it into a healthy chili without too many changes. I omitted the bouillon, replaced the bacon bits with liquid smoke, replaced the ground beef with ground turkey. Also did not serve with Fritos or cheese, and used low sodium canned items. Drained the tomatoes instead of the beans (didn't want to lose that great gravy) and used 3 jalapenos for the chile. This recipe went to the rim of my biggest slow cooker. Started on high to get all that volume up to temp, turned to low and cooked for about 8 hours. I ended up adding more of all the seasonings over the course of cooking. This is a very meaty chili, and next time I make this (which I won't need to for a long time cuz my freezer will be full of it!) I think I will replace one pound of ground meat with more beans. Loved the sausage in this and the blend of flavors.

It wasn't too spicy, but still had a kick to it so you know you're eating chili.  Just a note, if you are cooking this in your crock pot, you need to have a big one!  My crock pot was full up to the rim and I had to take out a bowl in order to close the lid.  I made the following changes: 1) used 2 lbs beef chuck steak instead of ground  2) pulled the italian sausage out of the casings, cooked and patted off the oil  3) used 1 can (15 oz) refried black beans with chili peppers in place of one of the chili bean cans (thickens it up nicely) also used 2 cans chili beans w/spicy sauce, but kept the total number of cans the same 4) sauteed all the onions, peppers, and celery before throwing them into the crockpot which gave them a nice, roasted flavor

text:
I give the recipe 4 stars because most of it comes out of a can instead of being made from scratch.  That said, it's got a good mix of spices and mine came out great!  I will note I made a lot of changes, though.  For one, I used a slow cooker.  Ingredient wise, I used hot italian sausage, omitted celery, green bell pepper & cumin.  Used 1 cup of beer instead of 1/2.  Also only used 3 cans of beans instead of 4, and I mis-judged the amount of tomatoes; I thought they were supposed to be regular 14oz cans instead of 28oz. This turned out to be a good thing, otherwise there would have been WAY too many tomatoes and beans and not enough meat in the chili.  Plus I don't think my slow cooker would have fit all of it.  The tomatoes I got were fire roasted.  I used just one poblano pepper, though next time I think I'll use two.  Started out with just 1 tablespoon of chili powder though I kicked it up to the full 1/4 cup toward the end.  Also used Duck Butter hot sauce instead of Tabasco.  I let it simmer for the better part of 10hrs and it turned out very good.  Of course letting it sit overnight after that made it at least twice as good.  Really brought all the flavors together; if you don't let it simmer enough it just doesn't taste right.  Overall, very good!

text:
Done this one several times. It's one of the best chili recipes. I agree with many reviewers; for folks with non-discriminating taste, it's hard to justify the effort involved. However, I've made several modifications which reflects the consensus of many reviews and my own spin. Try this one and you'll always get an A+ review by your guests and family.

2 pounds ground beef sirloin (leanest possible)
3/4 pound bulk Italian sausage (boil for 3 min and then cut into small cube)
3 (15 ounce) cans chili beans, drained
1 (15 ounce) can chili beans in spicy sauce
2 (28 ounce) cans diced tomatoes with juice
1 (6 ounce) can tomato paste
2 large yellow onion, chopped
4 stalks celery, chopped
1 green bell pepper, seeded and chopped
1 red bell pepper, seeded and chopped
2 poblano peppers, seeded and chopped
1 chili jalapeno pepper, seeded and chopped
4 cubes beef bouillon
1/2 cup beer
1/4 cup chili powder
2 tablespoon minced garlic
1 tablespoon dried oregano
2 teaspoons ground cumin
2 teaspoons hot pepper sauce (e.g. Tabasco)
1 teaspoon dried basil
1 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon ground black pepper
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 teaspoon paprika
1 teaspoon white sugar

Wow, this was fabulous chili.  My neighborhood had a Halloween chili cook-off and I won with this recipe.  There was also a dessert contest which I won with Iced Pumpkin Cookies - also a recipe from this site.  For the chili, I chopped up all of the veggies until they were something close to minced. text:
I went with using 2 pieces fresh cooked bacon, crumbled.  I also cut the beans in half (I hate beans...but love chili...and my boyfriend loves them both, so it was a compromise.)  I also used a jalepino and yellow chili pepper rather then 2 green chili's, only because the store was out of greens.  I completely omitted celery.  After browning the meat I threw everything into a crockpot stirred and set for 6 hours.  It tasted fantastic even better the next day.  It seemed a little soupy, mostly because I didn't sub extra meat for the lack of beans...but by cutting the diced tomatos next time or adding more meat I should be good to go.  This was the first time I've ever tried making chili, and though the recipe list for this one is endless...I found it worth it.

text:
This is easily the best chili recipe I have tried. I did make a few modifications, but this is a great base recipe. Instead of 2 lbs ground beef and 1 lb ground Italian sausage, I used 1 lb ground turkey, 1 lb ground Italian sausage, and 1 lb of stew meat (which makes the chili thicker which I prefer). I also used the juice from only one can of the diced tomatoes, as opposed to using it from both cans as the base recipe suggests. I added an extra 1/4 cup of beer. I think this gives the recipe the perfect consistency, with a better taste. I skipped the celery (seemed odd to put celery in chili) and the green pepper. I used 1 yellow pepper and 1 red pepper which gave the chili a better color, for the presentation. I added a bit more chili powder (maybe an extra tablespoon) and a bit more hot pepper sauce. This gave it the perfect amount of heat; even my semi-picky fiancee said she thought it was perfect. I cooked the chili over low heat for 8 hrs. stirring occassionally, giving the flavors an adequate amount of time to meld. I skipped the Fritos, added the cheese and a bit of sour cream at the end. This was a really good dish that I will make often this winter!

text:
I thought the fat and cholesterol content of this recipe was just out of control so I made a few changes to make it healthier.  Instead of ground beef chuck I used Yves ground round simulated beef.  For those who don't like soy and can't give up the meat, try using ground turkey instead which is only about 1/3rd of the fat and cholesterol.  Instead of regular italian sausage, I used spicy italian turkey sausage.  I also added mushrooms to bulk up the chili and use less of the meat products.  I also cut out the cheese and chips since it tastes great without these extra calorie items.  With these changes, I don't feel so guilty eating this while watching Sunday and Monday football since it makes such a large portion!  Overall, really great taste!

This is indeed great chili!   The only issue I had is by the time it was done cooking, the canned chili beans were disentegrated.  It was barely simmering too so I know the heat wasn't too high.  Next time I'll add the juice of the beans, but wait to add the actual beans until it's done.  Because I always get requests from my husband for "that El Tovar Chili" (awesome Chili at a Grand Canyon Restaurant), I used cubed chuck roast instead of the ground beef.  Be alerted if you do this, it ends up more "soupy".  I guess because the ground beef takes up more space.  We ate this all weekend and we're not tired of it yet!  Tonight I'll freeze the rest after making Taco Salad with this great Chili.   Thanks so much for the awesome recipe!!

What a great recipe!  I did vary it a little due to personal preference and availability of ingredients.  I didn't use chili peppers or beer.  For beans, I used two cans of red beans, one can of kidney beans, and one can of refried beans with chilies.  I also halved the quantities of tabasco, cayenne and cumin.  Even with all that alteration it still came out great!  I got 12 good-sized servings out of it, and I'm eatin the leftovers for lunches this week.  The only thing I'll do differently next time is to cut the celery a little smaller.  It remained a little crunchy, and it is a little disconcerting to someone who isn't expecting it. ;-)  Thanks for the recipe!

Awesome, full body recipe. I split this recipe into two and had half the batch in a slowcooker and the other half in a dutch oven on the stove. I made one really spicy and one sweet. To the spicy, I doubled all the spicy ingredients in this recipe-tabasco, green chiles, etc. To the sweet, I added 1/2 cup of dark brown sugar and 1/2 the spicy ingredients listed. I am a newbie to cooking and decided to try this recipe after reading all the reviews. I was a bit intimiated by the list of ingredients but I didn't let it stop me. All I can say is WOW!!! I had to register to this site just so that I could RAVE about this! Prep time was a bit over an hour for me but I had chopped everything...if you have a chopper you can cut down on prep time I'm sure.I made enough to give to my boyfriend and a co-worker and they both begged for more. The only things I did different was that I skipped the beer  (just because I  had none handy) and for the meat I used 1lb hot italian sausage, 1lb mild Italian sausage and 1lb group beef. This has an AMAZING " heat chaser" and such a great flavor. Here it is 2 weeks after I mad my first batch and I am simmering another batch! I defrosted a container from the first batch yesterday  and I swear it's hotter now....the taste gets SO much better. Don't pass this up!

Way too much spice for us; even my husband that likes things spicy.  I did not use the chiles, and I only used about 3/4 of the chili powder.  Before we shared it I added another can of diced tomatoes and another can of kidney beans to absorb some of the spiciness. Changes 1) mild italian sausage 2) plain chili beans 3) added a can of tomato sauce 4) added two cans of mexican corn (we like corn in our chili) 5) used 5 strips of bacon chopped up.  FABULOUS Recipe -- nice and thick and hearty.  This time I did use the whole 1/4 cup of chili powder.

text:
Loved it!  I made a few changes based on personal pref. I used only 1/2 lb. Italian sausage to try and cut a bit of fat. Used only 1 can of diced tomatoes and subbed a can of tomato sauce for the other. My kids prefer more sauce and less chunks of tomatoes. I used one can of kidney beans in place of one of the cans of chili beans to just add some texture and color. Omitted the celery, red bell pepper, chile peppers, bacon bits and tobasco (sorry we are wimps). Reduced the chili powder to 2 Tbsp. (holy cow 1/4 cup is A LOT!). With these changes everyone at my table loved it. I served it with shredded cheese, chopped green onion, chopped tomato, sour cream, and tortilla chips. I think the leftovers will make great nachos.  Important note - with my mods it fit perfectly in my dutch oven which is what I always use to make chili. If you make it as written be sure to use a stock pot as directed or it will never fit. It will make a very large amount.

This is a very good combo you can adjust it to your liking. I used 1 lb ground chuck and 1 lb chuck tenderloin (stew meat). I love the added texture! This recipe is amazing!
I have to admit that I made a few changes though. I've never been a huge chili fan, but this felt like a fun recipe to tackle and I was making it for people who do love chili.
I personally don't like very chunky chili, so I put all the veggies (peppers, onion, celery, and tomatoes) in my Cuisinart and made a pulp out of them.  They gave the chili a great flavor but in a smoother sauce.
I browned the meat on the stove and then threw it in my crockpot (5-qt for the full recipe) with all the other ingredients. I cooked on high for about 3-4 hours. 
Other than that, I stuck to the recipe.
Fantastic! The Nittany Lions approve :)

I would definitely recommend this recipe to others; I felt that the flavors were good and absolutely memorable.   I added 1 can of tomato paste (2 cans in total) to the recipe; I thought the consistency was a little loose without the additional paste.  Because of the added acidity from the additional tomato paste I also added a few more teaspoons of brown sugar (3tbs in total).  Even though I am not a chili fan, I will keep this recipe in my arsenal to use at a later date!  Update 2: I used a 12oz of tomato paste, 28 oz of diced tomatoes, 28 oz of petite diced tomatoes, 1 tsp. italian seasoning, 4 tablespoons of chili powder, 2 jalapeno chilis, 1 serrano chili, no beer, 2 cans of mild beans, 1 can of zesty chili beans, 3 teaspoons of brown sugar, 4 chicken bullion cubes and the rest of the ingredients were the same.  I let it simmer for 2.5 hours, put it in the fridge overnight and the next day and then served it.

text:
THIS CHILI ROCKS!!!!!  I use 2 lbs ground sirloin in place of the ground chuck. Two cans of spicy chili beans (1 undrained) and 2 cans of medium spicy beans (drained). We like our chili SPICY, so I use 1 28 oz can of diced tomatoes, 2 14 oz cans of diced tomatoes with jalapenos. I also use 1 habanero, seeded and diced, in place of the green chiles. Dark beer works best, and I prefer Fat Tire. For the hot sauce I use Frank's Extra Hot and Tobasco Habanero.

text:
I made this for our office Chili 
Cook-Off and came in 1ST! There were 7 other chili's. I used real bacon crumbles as someone else suggested and left out the Tabasco as I didn't know how hot it would make it. I used a serrano pepper and 2 Jalepeno peppers for the green chiles. Start off with a 1/2 tsp of salt and add more as you go(after you've tasted it), mine came out a bit on the salty side with the 1 tsp of salt. This chili had the best flavor out of all 7 that were at the chili cook-off. It didn't taste like a bunch of meat, beans and chili-powder. HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT! If you don't have the spices on hand, shop at Whole Foods or Central Market where you can buy just what you need. It will help reduce the cost significantly.

text:
I tied for 1st place at a chili cookoff with this recipe.  I changed a few things slightly. I omitted the chil beans in spicy sauce, the red bell peppers and the green chili peppers.  I also forgot the chili powder but doubled the amount of minced garlic (maybe even tripled). I cooked 3 slices of bacon and crumbled them into the chil (for 20 servings).  Finally, I used seasoned diced tomatoes- 1/2 with basil/garlic/oregano and 1/2 with mild chili peppers IN ADDITION TO the spices listed.  Many people mentioned that it was a little sweet, which they liked and I did not(matter of personal preference) and said it was not spicy- which I disagee with- it was the kind of spice that sneaks up on you.

Amazing!!  Great recipe!  
Being a Minnesotan of Scandinavian descent, I simply don't have things like Tabasco lying around...most Norwegian food is white and bland (lutefisk, lefse, kringla, fattigmund, etc).  I cut out most of the spices like the fresh jalapeno, mostly because I didn't have the money / desire to run to the grocery store. To make up for that slightly, I added some red pepper flakes. 
Since I also didn't have any tomato paste,  for the base I added in a Family size can of cream of Mushroom soup (any other cream of ___ soup could work also).  So the color isn't exact, but it's a pretty close match.  Really tastes good, and made enough to freeze and reheat! Thanks for this recipe, MightyPurdue22

text:
Yummy! However, the Boilers in this household are a bit whimpy when it comes to spiciness. So for my family, I replaced the spicy chili beans with kidney beans and added a small can of tomato sauce. Also eliminated the jalapeo pepper. Everything else was the same. I also did this in a crockpot on low for 6 hours. I did find that the chili was not as thick as we like it, so in the last 1/2 hour I added another can of tomato sauce with 4 tablespoons of flour mixed in. It ended up thick and yummy, with just a little kick. A sprinkling of cheddar and dollop of sour cream....yum! Added sour dough rolls....perfection! BOILER UP!

text:
I've been wanting a break from my normal recipe, so I made this tonight. This isn't a bad recipe, it just wasn't for us. The only things I changed was using all spicy beans (instead of the 3:1 ratio of regular chili beans to spicy) and I used Melinda's hot sauce instead of Tabasco. We like heat (still wasn't hot enough for us). I'd say besides the lack of heat, which is easily remedied with a little Carolina Reaper powder, our only complaint was the Italian sausage. To us, it dominated the flavor and just didn't scream "chili" to us. However, it isn't bad, so give it a shot!

text:
Our "go to" chili recipe with a few alterations to our taste and preference. We use poblano and anaheim peppers vs chili peppers. We do not use bacon bits but saute and chop an entire pound of smoked bacon (I know, I know... trust me though) One whole tall can of guiness vs half a cup. We switch up the beans mix and use some nontypical types. 1 can of each, chili beans, garbanzos, and black beans (I am not a huge bean fan so we lose one can and switch them up as a compromise between me and my husband) . As for all the rest of the ingredients we leave them as is. Don't be afraid to fuss with this very versatile recipe to make it just right for you.

text:
Let me start with this disclaimer:  I am a decent cook, have a terrible tolerance for spicy foods (though I love them), and have never made chili before. 

I followed this recipe to the tee, except used 1 jalapeno in lieu of both hot peppers. After only an hour of simmering, this dish tasted wonderful. It had plenty of umami and the italian sausage gave the flavor a huge boost. The heat was just right for me, hot with a little lingering but not overpowering as to take away from the flavor.  The flavors mixed like it had been simmering for a day or two already...I can't imagine what this is actually going to taste like after that time. 
Not everyone is going to like the level of heat, but AT MINIMUM this is an awesome starting recipe. Cater it to what you like. I'll be making this again. And don't listen to the negative reviews, unless you're a food snob, you'll at least enjoy this succulent chili.

Update:  This recipe won 2nd in my company cook off out of 30 entries!  I used Magic Hat #9 for the beer. 

Update2:  I made the following additions the second time I made this, based on what I like and the feedback from my company cook off. 
Original -> Change
1 Jalepeno seeded -> 1 Jalepeno & 1 Serano w/seeds
2 Large garlic cloves -> 2 Medium garlic cloves
Beans:  2 kidney, 1 pinto, 1 hot -> 1 pinto, 2 hot
Tomatoes not drained -> Drained tomatoes in strainer
2 tsp hot sauce -> 4 tsp hot sauce
1 tsp cayenne -> 2 tsp cayenne

The heat on the second batch is still manageable for us

text:
Best chili recipe I've found yet!  Family loved it! Very flavorful, thick and had a kick to it! Here's what I did differently: I cooked the Italian spicy sausage on the stovetop, drained the grease from it then threw that and everything else in a crockpot, cooked on low  overnight. Left out the bouillon cubes after seeing it's almost 900mg of salt per cube! Still tasted VERY, VERY GOOD! Added a full can of beer instead of a 1/2, used stew meat pieces instead of ground beef chuck, cut up 1 and 1/2 green cayenne peppers instead of 2 and didn't add the hot sauce for fear it would be too hot, but might have been fine.  It turned out spicy, but not overly spicy so that you couldn't taste the flavors, it was the perfect amount of spice in my opinion.
( On a side note, wear GLOVES when handling the cayenne peppers! No joke, I didn't know you could burn your hands, found out the hard way, the rest of the night I was GOOGLING how to stop my hands from burning, it was awful, soaked my hands in everything and nothing stopped the burning.)It filled my large crockpot to the top, had lots of leftovers which was still very good reheated the next day.

This recipe is great! I love that the heat sneaks up on you. I changed just a few things. I added a pound of Italian sweet sausage in addition to the two pounds of beef. text:
Dynamic, flavorful chili! Spicy without the "burn your lips off" factor. I simplified a little by getting pre-diced celery, onion and tri-colored bell mix from my market. I also used a 28 oz. Can of Ro-tel diced tomatoes with green chili (Mild) and two 14 oz cans of diced tomatoes with lime and cilantro. I also used only 1 can of mild chili beans and 1 can spicy chili beans (because we tend to like meaty instead of beany chili). Following the advice of others,  I cooked 5 strips of bacon until crispy, then cooked veggies in that. Transferred them to a bowl while I browned the ground beef and sausage. Then I mixed the crumbled bacon, veggies and meat together in my crock pot.  I cooked it on low for 2:30 hours, then let it rest until cool, refrigerates until morning, then cooked on low in crock pot for 4 more hours....wow and yum! DH says it's perfect. Will be using for a chili "cook off" party next week, for sure!

text:
I have made this chile 3 times and am more impressed with it  after I create new batches. The one I made today included a few habanero peppers, 2 without seeds and 1 with seeds. I saw some reviews that referred to this recipe as a vegetable soup type chile but for me, all of the peppers and onions pretty much dissolved into the chile after cooking it in a crockpot on low heat for 8 hours. Whether or not this was the intention of the recipe, it turns out to be a great chile when all of the flavors meld together! I left out  the celery, subbed steak for sausage, used 1 can of chile & 1 can of red kidney chile beans, and used a full can of beer. Other than that, everything was pretty much true to the recipe. I really haven't tried other chile recipes as this one is sooooo good! Yeah, it's a lot of ingredients but adds to the fun of cooking and doesn't add that much prep time.  I strongly recommend that you try this and tweak the recipe to your desire.

Great recipe!  I did follow the advice of some, and used cubed steak instead of ground chuck.  I also adjusted the spice just a little, and I'm glad I did because had it been any spicier my kids wouldn't have been able to eat it.  I used real bacon instead of bacon bits and omitted the beer only because I didn't have any. text:
I made this chili for a Christmas dinner at work and it made me famous at the shop. After I refused to give out the recipe a few times, I literally had a co-worker offer me fifty bucks for it, (which I also turned down). I did make a couple small adjustments to this recipe. I left out the can of spicy chili beans and added another can of mild because I was worried about the chili being too spicy. I also used two jalapeno peppers instead of the green chiles, simply because I prefer the flavor of jalapenos.  I was completely blown away by how fantastic this chili is.  I was glad I left out the spicy beans, because it had just absolutely the perfect amount of heat. (It may still be a little too spicy for some, though, so if you don't like spicy, I would leave out the cayenne and hot sauce also). Hands down the best chili I have ever even tasted, let alone made myself. This is my new go to recipe when I want to impress a large crowd.

text:
I have made this recipe at least 10 times. I always cook the onions in a little oil or bacon grease first, then add to that the celery, then the bell peppers, cooking a few minutes between each addition. Then I get the flavors off of the bottom of the pot with about one quarter cup of beer, scrapping the pot with a flat wooden spoon. While doing this, I brown the meat in a separate pan with a little dash of each of the spices. When the meet is brown and the veggies are soft, I drain the meat and add it to the big veggie pot with the beef broth and spices. While that heats up, I add in the other ingredients a little at a time so that the temp in the pot stays up. Sometimes I use a de-seeded jalapeo or two instead of the green chili peppers (cooked with the other veggies at the beginning). Sometimes I use a few pieces of thick bacon crumbled into it. I don't usually use the hot sauce.

text:
Made it with Founders Porter instead of a lager, pilsner, or stout. We didn't have chili beans in my local grocery store - so we used the following: 2 cans light kidney beans, 1 can pinto beans, 1 can pink beans.  Slow cooked it - 3 hours on high. ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS served with french bread for scooping and cheddar cheese and sour cream. Made a (mostly) vegetarian version for the (many) friends I had giving meat up for lent (still added bullion and Worchestershire and a dash of bacon bits, with everyone's approval) that was also really delicious - I posted the recipe as a variation on this one, with suggestions on how to match if the flavor if you want to go full veg. The recipe as is, sans additions like bread, corn chips, sour cream, or cheese has 11 WW points. Reducing the meat to leaner varieties only really saves you a point - however if you try the veggie variation I posted, it has only 8 WW points per serving!

Tomorrow I am going to try it with italian flavored chicken sausage. Can't wait to see how it tastes, and if that goes well will swap out the beef chuck for lean ground beef on the next go round.

By FAR, the best Chili I've ever tasted.  ridiculously good and the leftovers taste even better.  I suggest that you make the full recipe because you'll absolutely love it and wish you had leftovers.  The only substitute I made was to use ground turkey instead of chuck to lower the fat content. I did use the Italian pork sausage but went with about 3/4 lb instead of the full pound, again to lessen the fat content.  Oh, I also omitted the bacon bits.     I used a Dutch oven instead of a large stock pot.   Will make again soon!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Won my company chili cook off with this recipe as the base, but made some very important changes. 

Additions while making 2x the recipe:
1. Added 1-2 lbs of cubed steak. Fully browned with garlic powder and black pepper. 
2. Added 1 full pouch of real bacon bits
3. Added 4 Habeneros + 10 small thai chili peppers + 4 serrano (remember this is for 2x the recipe) peppers blended in a blender with some chili broth and added to the pot. 
4. After boiling for 1.5 hrs, transfer all the goodness into a large crock pot (As I transfer every other ladle full has broth since this recipe is too watery with celery and diced tomato juice). Cook on low over night and everything else in the pot goes into tupperwares to freeze. I was actually left with a lot of chili liquid since I like chunky chili and redid the proportion of liquid to meat and beans. The heat will mellow out greatly by noon the next day and turns from front heat (tongue) to back heat (throat). 
5. Serve with cheese, sour cream, and chives with frito scoops on the side. 

Use stought beer like Guiness and serve next day to allow peppers to mellow. My goal is to make chunky style chili and with above changes it is excellent chunky steak chili with decent back heat.

I've read the critical reviews and can only suggest that their disappointment is a matter of comparing apples and oranges. This is the kind of chili I grew up with in Canada ... only better! Hopefully one day I'll make it to Texas and have a chance to try the Texan version of chili!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent base recipe. I made a few modifications, specifically, I used 1.5lbs of ground sirloin beef and 1.5lbs of sage sausage. I also used one can dark red kidney beans, one can light red kidney beans and one can of pinto beans instead of 3 cans of plain chili beans for variety. Regarding the peppers, I used 1 green and 1 red bell, a jalapeno and an Anaheim pepper for a decent amount of heat without aggravating my stomach.

 Other suggestions: make sure that you mince your own fresh garlic. Also, making your own bacon bits from fresh bacon is best. There is no excuse for imitation bacon.

 And, finally, the beer. First off, I am not a big fan of beer in general (I prefer whiskey), but if I'm going to consume beer, I prefer Light Lagers. That said, I used Bud Select in my Chili and the way to do this (regardless of your choice of beer) is to buy a 12 pack. As soon as you get to the kitchen, open your first beer and take two big gulps directly from the bottle (you'll cook off any bacteria), then pour your half-cup. Now, make sure that you have an non-empty, open bottle until you are to the simmering stage. I was on my fourth, but I'm 6'8" and 350lbs; you should have a nice buzz by the end of the recipe.

text:
Awesome recipe!  I adapted to our likes/dislikes and serving size by adding only one can of beans (we prefer a meatier chili), using diced tomatoes with green chiles, increasing the beer to one cup, two beef bullion cubes, a little extra bacon, only 1 lb of beef and 1 lb of sausage and two large cans of green chiles.  Didn't add the hot sauce, Worcestershire sauce, green bell pepper or paprika.  But kept all the other spices and ingredients the same serving. Cooked it all over the stove to blend the flavors, then tossed in the slow cooker for 8 hours on low.  Served with corn bread, sour cream and Mexican cheese blend.  This is a keeper! Thanks.

text:
This is the best chili I have ever eaten! More-so, this is the only chili my finicky wife has ever eaten, and she's a plain grilled chicken, white rice, and unseasoned green beans kind of gal. Simply wonderful!  

Here's my changes: I fried 4 pieces of bacon , crumbled them into the pot, and then saved some of the fat to saute the garlic, celery, and onions. I used one can of chili beans, one can of dark kidney beans, and one can of black beans- all drained. I used one can of the Chili beans with medium sauce (think the brand with Duke the dog). I could only find spiced Italian sausage so I chose a mild spice. This is why I didn't use the chili beans in spicy sauce but it was perfect! I was fretting using the 1/4 cup of chili powder but don't fret! It all worked out in the end. FYI, an Anaheim pepper is a chili pepper, and after humming and hawing, I finally figured it out. I followed the remaining recipe exactly recipe with cooking, ingredients, and measurements, and then let it settle overnight in the fridge. WOW! I had it the day of and then the day after, the best got better!

Two tips, get more Frito's and use the biggest pot you have. I have a cast iron dutch oven and that did the trick. I also had a can of pineapple ready for pureeing in case the chili was too spicy but never needed it. It was just enough kick to let you know you had a flavor explosion in your mouth. 

Thanks MIGHTYPURDUE22 for this super recipe!

text:
Super Yummy Delicious. I don't think it's too spicy at all.
I omitted the tabasco, and used only one chili pepper. I added extra green and red peppers.
I also added 1/2 cup of water, when it cooks for 2 hours and is left to stand, the consistency ends up perfect!

What made mine extra good:
using hot italian sausage
one teaspoon of red chili paste
one teaspoon spicy brown mustard
one teaspoon of CLOVES!!! The cloves addition is superb.

What I recommend doing is first brown the meat in sautee pan or wok, save half of the grease, in the soup pot that you will be making the chili, warm the grease from the meat, sautee the onions and garlic for 3 minutes, then add the veggies and worcestershire and a bit of olive oil, sautee all together for 5 minutes or so. Then add the beer, water, and all of the other ingredients (spices last).

I've made it twice now, and this time forgot to add the sugar and bacon bits. (The first time I fried bacon and crumbled it in). I can barely taste the difference.

I serve over elbow noodles with lots of sharp cheddar on top and extra fritos on the side!

text:
I am eating this as we speak. I did change the serving size as I only cooked for myself, or two people at most in case my boyfriend wanted some. So I cut everything by roughly 1/3. As far as the beans go, for the regular chili beans, I put in all "mild" beans, and then for the spicy ones I put in "medium" ones. Then I added a lot of Frank's Red Hot Sauce, more than the recipe called for. I also guesstimated all the seasonings. I did add some frozen corn kernels, which gave it a nice sweet flavor. I had a block of white cheddar and shredded it myself, also served it with some sweet cornbread and sour cream. Delicious!! My rendition  of the recipe has the perfect heat level, and I do love spicy food but sometimes I like to keep it at a comfortable level when I'm about to pig out.

text:
I have made this chili numerous times and I love it. Of course, I have made changes here and there. I leave out the sausage and instead sear a steak, sirloin or ribeye; your choice. I cut it up and put it in along with everything else. I also add jalapenos to my recipe, I use a good quality beer and some red wine, Before I put the veggies in I saute them in bacon fat along with garlic. I also add more variety of beans, kidney, garbanzo, pinto, northern. We love beans at my house! Instead of using just diced tomatoes I use 2 big cans of san marzano whole plum tomatoes. I usually cook my chili atleast twice as long too. Very, very yummy!! everyone raves about my chili and people who aren't veggie lovers like my husband still love it too! Just make sure to sautee those veggies and cook i extra long.

text:
I made this, minus the hot peppers due to daughter not liking the heat, this was delish! We topped it with cilantro, tabasco and sour cream.

Update: 

Second time making this and I made several changes. I browned 1 lb ground turkey instead of chuck and 1 lb petite sirloin diced instead of sausage in 1 tbl oil. Then I added the recipes seasonings including 1 tsp each anise and fennel seed and 1 tbl steak seasoning. I then added half a bottle of beer and cooked it down while deglazing the pan. Then I added all chopped vegetables including 1 cup diced butternut squash for color. I also added a 15 oz can of pinto beans and 2 cans of kidney beans/drained and rinsed. I omitted one of the cans of tomatoes and instead used just 1-29 oz can of crushed tomatoes with basil (I don't like tomato chunks in my chili). I also added 1/4 cup smoky bbq sauce. My changes made this recipe very different which is why I like the boilermaker recipe so much. You can make it your own with adaptations to your liking. This turned out to be  a great pot of chili.

text:
Wonderful chili and worth the prep time (read: 30 minutes of chopping/dicing!).  This recipe is really flexible - for instance I shopped for the ingredients at WalMart and couldn't find a can of chili beans in spicy sauce, so instead I just got 4 cans of chili beans in regular sauce and bought 2 cans of diced tomatoes *ready for chili* (what it said on the label - it had extra diced chili peppers, etc.).  I also didn't have beef bouillon cubes and used chicken cubes instead and you couldn't tell.  The great thing about this chili was that it manages to capture BOTH a great, full flavor PLUS a nice afterburn.  So many chilis are just HOT with no good flavor or flavorful with no spiciness.  This is a win and will be in our weekend rotation all football season.

text:
So delicious. I had an extra 1/2 lb. of beef so I added 1 can of pinto beans, 1 can of kidney beans, 4 cloves garlic, 2 onions and 1 can of tomatoes and I simmered it for maybe 6 hours. Man was it good. I froze half for future leftovers but had the rest with Fritos on top (on the bottom and they get soggy). The cheese is entirely unnecessary with this chili (about the only time in my life where I would say that).

Update: I have made it a few more times and it keeps getting better. 

I usually add one extra can of pinto and one of kidney beans. I crumble in 3-4 slices of crisp thick bacon and saute the onions, peppers, 3 jalapenos (with seeds/veins), and 1/2 of celery in the drippings of the bacon and sausage. I don't drain any of the cans. I also use 12 oz. of Mexican beer and 4 large cloves of garlic. This last time I used only 2 beef bullion cubes and 1/2-3/4 tsp. of liquid smoke and it was the best one yet. 

Let it simmer for 6-8 hours and the flavors will really come through.

text:
This was the BEST chili I have ever made or eaten anywhere ever..in my whole life & I'm 40!! ...I tweaked the recipe a little to fit my family.  Started off with 1/2 lb chopped bacon & cooked til crisp. Remove from pan & add 2 lbs. beef stew meat.  Brown in hot bacon fat.  Remove stew meat from pan ..add sausage & brown.  Then add all meats back into pot & follow recipe exactly from there except omit bacon bits (obviously) ...and because of my little ones I also omit the chile peppers.   I have also made this recipe following directions exactly & was also FANTASTIC!!  ...but very spicy hot!  ..DO NOT forget the Fritos!   ..stew meat makes it HEARTY!

text:
I made this chili tonight and it was fantastic!! The only changes I made were to reduce the amount of meat - I used 1 lb of ground beef, 2 Spolumbo's mild Italian sausages and no bacon bits. Since kids don't appreciate this much heat, I would reduce the cayenne pepper next time, omit the Tabasco (Tabasco or chili oil can be added at the table by those who like it how) and use just one or no green chili peppers. We had it with nacho chips and grated cheddar cheese. Sour cream on top would be great too - especially if you have little ones who need the extra calories. Thanks for the great recipe!!

I thought this recipe was exceptionally good.  I was surprised that I actually had ALL of the ingredients except one can of beans, Paprika, and Chile Peppers...      My Modifications:  I used 94% Lean ground beef.  Instead of Italian Sausage I used Smoked Turkey Sausage.  I thought the smokiness of the sausgae added some nice depth.  I also pureed a can of Pineapples like someone else had suggested, this helped cut the heat but didn't make it sweet.  I used 1 can of Kidney beans (drained) and one can of Chile Beans (with sauce).  IMO 3 cans of beans would have been too much. I did not add bacon bits.    My husband loved it and said it had Just the right amount of spiciness.  Enough to feel but not too much that you can't eat it.

I am having some friends over for superbowl and thought this sounded rich and flavorful--and it is!  I did add 1 tblsp Ghiradelli unsweetened cocoa powder and about 3/4 cups beer instead of 1/2 cup.  My pot isn't super huge (7 qt dutch oven) so I only have 3 cans of chili beans-1 hot, 2 reg--did not add that last can. I think it gives a more aromatic flavor overall.  Hubby is loving it.  I will simmer for a while today and then freeze until Superbowl sunday---should be melded and even fabulous-er by then!

When I looked at this recipe, it had a lot of the ingredients I used to make my chili, just a lot more of them....so I tried it. OMG!! What an awesome recipe. Don't let the long list of ingredients scare you away. Most of the ingredients are small amts of this and that, but together they make the best chili ever. Whenever I make it now, we invite friends over and they all rave it's the best they've ever had, and we agree. I pass this recipe along to everyone. I have altered it a bit everytime I make it. Now I increase the ground beef to 3 lbs and leave out the sausage. I just put 3 cans of plain kidney beans, drained. I use the red pepper occasionally, but it doesn't make a difference in taste if you just use green peppers. We don't eat it with Fritos, or add cheese....just dip in hot buttered toast. The only way to eat chili!!

I omitted all the peppers, bacon bits, beer and hot pepper sauce.  I did add one can of ro-tel on top of what tomatoes the recipe calls for.  All my beans were regular kidney beans.  I omitted the pork and used 1 1/2 lbs deer meat and 1 lb of ground beef.  I used chili powder, but only about 1 T. or so.  This was just spicy enough for my family. My husband likes hot and I like mild. This recipe made us both happy.  This is my new chili recipe. Thanks for posting.

text:
I made this chili for a chili cookoff among friends on October 31, 2009. I searched the internet and came across this one and decided to make it due to the stellar reviews. I wanted to win this cookoff since my friends are such good cooks and thought I might have a chance with this one. Anyway, made the recipe exactly except used 2 cans dark red kidneys and 2 cans hot chili beans. I also used a whole 12oz. beer (Bass Pale Ale) instead of recommended 1/2 cup. This took longer to prep than 30 minutes for me because I fine chopped everything. Anyway, my first sample was incredible. All of the flavors stood out and left me wanting to eat another bite. I browned all the meet and sauteed all the vegetables and then put everything into a crockpot to cook about 4 hours. There were about 10 different chilis at the cookoff. I was very suprised to hear that my chili took first place. I did not tell anyone that I had just grabbed the recipe from the internet that very same day. I figured they didn't need to know that. HAhA. Awesome chili. I am making it again for this weekend.  Cheers

I made this recipe again in 2011 for a neighborhood Chili Cook off competition during Halloween. There were 17 other chili recipes entered and guess who won? Yep, the boilermaker won this one too. I was just amazed. What a great recipe. Only downfall is the prep time but really worth it.

text:
AWESOME!!!  We loved it!  Finally a chili that my husband would not change. I altered the recipe a little.  He is not a fan of tomato-ie chili and doesn't like a thick chili, so here is what I did...  I did not add the tomato paste. I left out the celery.  Instead of the green chili's I just added a can of chopped green chilis.   I added 4 Tablespoons of bacon bits.  I added a whole can of beer.   I added about 2 Tablespoons of chili powder instead of the 1/4 cup. I did not add the hot pepper sauce.  I thought it was a little thick, so I added a 12oz can of tomato juice and 12oz of water.   It was perfect for our family.  Even my son ate it up!

text:
This was pretty good. Made a HUGE batch (did I mention, this makes a TON???) of chili for the recent U of IA vs. Penn St. FB game. Since fall has made its presence here in the "Windy" City, I thought chili would be the the perfect game watching food! My friends liked this, but my fiance didn't (he prefers chili w/o beans; I thought this was so-so...). I did make a few ch. to suit my/our tastes. Here's what I did: a) cooked everything in my sc on low for 4 hr., b) used 1/2 mild & 1/2 spicy sausage & c) subbed 2 cans of tomatoes w/ green chilies for plain ones & fresh peppers. I used a good quality smoked Spanish paprika (purchased at my local spice shop) instead of the generic store brand stuff. My beer of choice was Leinenkugel's red (lager). I must say, leftovers (last night's dinner) were much better (IMHO). The beer taste & a subtle smokiness which was absent in the initial batch came thru nicely. I'd like to try this again, but when I do, I will use real bacon (I used Hormel bacon pcs. this time), & sautee my veggies in the drippings. I will also only make 1/2 since the full amt. yielded WAAAY more than 12 servings (my 5 qt. sc was full to the hilt!). Served w/ cheddar, Frito's, scallions & hard cider, this was very filling. I still prefer 3 Bean Slow Burn Chili (JACOBS40K), but b/c this is milder & more suitable for all palates (i.e. kids, etc.), I'll stick w/ this recipe instead. Tx. MIGHTYPURDUE22 :)

text:
Delicious and hearty chili recipe!  It called for a lot of things I already had on hand, but it was still a little pricey to prepare.  We used ground turkey and it was still scrumptious!  Don't forget that you can adjust ingredients to suit your own taste, it is chili after all.  Also, I think the negative reviews had to be from people who didn't let it cook long enough.  There is a HUGE difference between chili that has cooked for 2 hours, and chili that has been cooked for 6-8 hours.  I used an entire bottle of beer and no beef bullion (bc I didn't have any), skipped the paprika, added a little sriracha, jalapenos, habaneros and honey. WONDERFUL recipe!

This was hands down the best chili I've ever had! i made a couple substitutions based on what I had on hand. I used three regular cans of chili beans instead of a spicy one and just added extra hot sauce to replace the spice. I also added half a zuchini and some fresh corn from my garden as well as a small garden bell pepper. I didn't use the beef bullion because I didn't have it but I didn't feel it needed it. I used an italian seasoning mixture instead of adding all the herbs individually and it was great! And as a lot of other reviewers did, I added a full bottle of beer (hefeweizen) to give it more flavor. i followed the recipe for everything else. I carmelized my onion before adding it in, and cooked this in the crock pot for about 5 hours prior to dinner time. It was so hearty and satisfying with shredded cheddar and corn chips... I will be making this one often! Thanks so much for the great recipe!

text:
I made this chili a few weeks ago, and ate it for lunch and dinner the whole weekend! The list of ingredients may seem exessive, but it is incredibly easy, and the flavors are so complex and layered, it's okay if you're missing a few of the components. For example, I omitted the dried basil and beer bc I didn't have it, and used just 1 bouillon cube instead of 4 to cut back on the sodium. Also, I used 2 cans of chili beans and substituted the third for a can of no salt added pinto beans and an extra can of rinsed and drained kidney beans. My boyfriend absolutely loved it too and when I brought some into work and heated it in the microwave everybody walked over to my desk to see what the wonderful smell was. Best chili ever!

text:
Excellent!  I made this lowfat by substituting ground turkey for the ground beef and sausage and omitted the bacon. I used a full can of beer....much better.  Also rather than all that chopping....I used 2 bags of frozen diced onion, celery, green and red pepper mix. ...much easier.   I took advice of others and eliminated the hot sauce, but it was still a little too spicy.  After some research, I found that if you add 2-3 peeled whole potatoes to the chili and leave in for approximately 30 minutes and then remove and serve,  it really does tone down  the spicy heat. This is my new chili recipe!!

text:
I hate to sound redundant, especially because I rarely review the recipes that I use, but this is the best chili we have ever had...and I am a Hoosier!  A couple of tweaks that others have done and some new:  I used three pieces of crumbled bacon, doubled the beer, used fire roasted diced tomatoes and substituted a bag of frozen "fresh" corn for the red and green peppers (due to allergies).  The corn added some really nice texture. I also mixed up the beans a bit, 2 cans of black, 1 can of kidney and 2 cans of chili (didn't drain the "hot" can of chili beans as the recipe suggests).  Served with shredded sharp cheddar, light sour cream and chopped green onion.  Fabulous!

With a few picky adults, and 14 children running around I was worried about it being too spicy so I did add the chile peppers but omitted the Tabasco and Cheyenne pepper. text:
This really is the best chili recipe I have ever tasted. And everyone that tries it absolutely loves it. Here is a tip - to make it healthier, go for the "low sodium" beans and other ingredients. You can also try turkey sausage instead of pork and use the leanest ground beef you can find. You will never taste the difference and it will trim out a lot of the fat and sodium in this recipe. Also - make sure you make extra. This only gets better as it ages and you can enjoy it for a week.

text:
This was awesome. I have used other chili recipes, but this will become my main one.  Left out the sausage (preference), used 3 lbs of ground beef and adjusted the tomatoes and paste and beans accordingly. I used kidney beans and black beans. Left out the bacon (again preference). Used O'Doul's beer as that is all I had, couldn't tell the difference.  I eyeballed the spices thought that as written it sounded a little too hot for our taste, so I went easy on the hot sauce and cayenne, and I only used one hot pepper. It was perfect. After about an hour, I found  I did need to add a little more cayenne. The taste does get better the longer it simmers. Enjoy!!!

text:
I had only made chili like 2 times before and this was was definitely the best!!  I did make my own real bacon bits, then sauteed the onions, peppers, celery, and garlic in the bacon drippings. I browned the hamburger meat and sausage. The rest is simple, just add everything in the same pot! I used one big can of diced tomatoes and one big can of diced tomatoes with the basil seasoning. I also only used 3 cans of beans (one with the spicy sauce and 2 drained) instead of 4....3 was plenty to me. I also used brown sugar instead of white as others had suggested. We couldn't wait till the next day to eat it cause it smelt too good so we ate it that night and it was delicious....even better the next night, and the night after....and so on! haha  This is very good and will be my chili recipe from now on. You should definately give this one a try! Thanks!

I've had a really hard time finding a good chili recipe since becoming vegetarian. Chili was my husbands favorite meal of mine before we stopped eating meat, and he's been really disappointed in the vegetarian versions I've tried. I made this recipe tonight (with reconstituted TVP -- 2 cups dry, soaked in 4 cups water -- instead of beef/pork), and it was a total hit. I didn't find this recipe too spicy, though I did omit the cayenne and chili peppers (I didn't have either). I will continue making it this way, considering how well received it was by my husband and three picky kids. I served it with homesteader cornbread.

text:
I love this chili recipe!!  Everyone raves about it.  It is really easy, too!  It has a long list of ingredients, but don't let that fool you into thinking that this is difficult to make.  I don't make any major changes to the recipe, although I do leave out the sausage.  Just a personal preference.  I have tried it with ground turkey, ground beef, and a mixture of the two.  I think that the beef or the mixture is the best.  Also, I sometimes make changes based on what I have in the pantry.  I use 2 cans of chili beans with sauce, and more tomatoes.  It is a little spicy, so if you're sensitive to spicy food, cut back on the cayenne.  We love the spice!!  In the summer I like to serve this with lots of shredded lettuce, fresh chopped tomatoes, grated cheese, cilantro, and corn chips.  It lightens it up a little for the hotter weather.  Try this chili.  You'll love it!!

text:
I made this for our guests today. I doubled the recipe, making one pot mild and the other spicy. For both, I used ground turkey & ground turkey sausage, beef broth rather than beer, black beans, chili beans, pinto beans, ranch style beans, and chili ready diced tomatoes. For the mild, I used canned, mild green chiles, omitted cayenne and hot pepper sauce. For the hot, I used fresh roasted green chiles, crushed red pepper and chipotle sauce. I cooked on high in the crockpot for 4 hours. I served the chili with frito's and topped with cheddar cheese, diced onion, sour cream & jalapeno's. Most everyone went back for seconds and some thirds...everyone raved how good the chili was! This is the perfect dish to feed a crowd. I'll definitely be making again. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Though I did change quite a bit, this was a great recipe and it made my first attempt at beef chili a huge success. I omitted the onion and celery and added 2 cans of mushrooms at boyfriend's request. We love beans, so I did add a few cans... used 2 cans of chili beans with sauce, 1 can drained kidney beans, 1 can drained red beans, and 1 can of drained/rinsed black beans. I also didn't have any fresh peppers, so I used 2 cans of diced green chilis, along with using 2 cans of Rotel instead of just diced tomatoes. After combining everything, I split this into 2 pots so I could make my boyfriend a really spicy chili (he is a spicy food addict). To his I added 2 or 3 more tablespoons of Frank's Red Hot sauce, 1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, 1/2 cup of sliced jalapenos, and an additional teaspoon of cayenne. To my surprise, he actually didn't add more hot sauce to it... he said it was perfect (yay!). I left mine as it was and it was great... and even better reheated the next day. Thanks!

text:
The best chili ever! Made a few changes to cut some fat and calories. Here they are: used lean ground beef, hot turkey sausage, 2 cans of drained/rinsed kidney beans(couldn't find chili beans in spicy sauce), one 28oz can fire roasted diced tomatoes, 1 28oz crushed tomatoes, 1 14oz diced tomato in its juice, 1/2 can paste, used turkey bacon instead of bits, reduced the cayenne and hot sauce slightly, kept everything else the same. Omitted fritoes completely (although they would have been fabulous), and used reduced 2% fat shredded cheddar. My family loved this chili and it was worth all the work and adding all the ingredients. This made a huge amount, so I froze a lot and cant wait to eat it again. Comfort food at its greatest,will definately make for a crowd. Thanks for a great new chili recipe.

text:
this is definitely a good chili. for those of you who thought it was too tomato-ey or not beefy enough, I would recommend not draining the grease from browning the ground beef and sausage.  I made my own bacon bits, which made a difference too.  I also added a can of corn and the sweetness compliments the spice really well.  Lastly, I would recommend simmering for at least 4 hours - at 2 hours, the flavor isn't quite there yet.

text:
Funny to see this as the recipe of the day as I just made it for the first time two weeks ago. Many more ingredients and more trouble than the recipe I learned from my mom, but worth it. 
I don't think the canned spicy chili beans are available in my area, so I used 4 cans of kidney beans and one can of pork and beans, for a touch of sweetness. I was a bit intimidated by the list of spicy ingred. and since I wanted my kids to eat it I cut back the jalapeno and tabasco quite a bit and left the cayenne out altogether. It had a bit of bite - I wouldn't have minded a bit more- but we all liked it. 
Sounds weird, but we served it with a dollop of potato salad on top, and it was a great combination! I will definately make this again.

I'm not much of a reviewer. But I've made this recipe 4 times now and it is the best chili recipe ever. What do I like about it most?
1. It doesn't have any crazy spices or weird things that I can't pick up at the local grocery store. 
2. I can easily remove portions (I usually only use half the beans) without degrading the recipe.
3. It uses beer, and you have to put beer in your chili.
4. It looks and tastes like chili should. Not in the "traditional" chili cookoff sense. But normal "I'm having a  super bowl party and I'm making chili" chili.

I would give this recipe my highest recommendation!

text:
This chilli was fantastic!  I made this for my trip to the Meadowlands for a Giant's game and I had everyone around me asking me for the recipe! I did however use White beans and regular red beans instead of the hot beans.  Instead, I added some special hot sauce that I picked up on my last trip to North Carolina.  I also added white pepper to taste.  I simmered the entire batch for about 3.5 hours and then cooled it quickly on a plastic wrapped sheet pan for about 30 min, occassionally mixing to release more heat. Works great when you make a big batch so you don't heat your fridge up and it doesn't take 8 hrs to cool down.    Either way, WOW, what a great tasting and hearty recipe!  Thanks; I'll be using this one for years to come!!

text:
I made this for 30 people, so I tripled the recipe. I omitted the bacon, used dark red kidney beans, black beans and spicy chili beans, only put one pound of bulk Italian sausage even though I tripled all the other ingredients.  It was the best chili I've ever made - and I usually make excellent chili.  I made it on a Friday night, simmered it for 2 hours in a large pot, then transferred it to a slow cooker, let it cool off, and placed in the fridge until Sunday morning.  then I put the slow cooker on Sunday morning and let it simmer all day until 5 pm.  it was the BEST!!!.  I already want to make some more.

text:
Followed everything to a T except instead of two green chili peppers, I used one Poblano Pepper and one jalapeno, and instead of Tabasco I used Gator Hammock's brand Gator Hot Sauce. I made it the day before, everything in a Crock-Pot after browning the meat, cooked on low for 3 hours, then on "keep warm"/simmer for an hour, then cooling in a container on the counter for an hour, THEN reheated on the stove the next day.  It was perfect.  People who rated this low probably ate it right after the suggested serving time, before the flavors could marry.  
Made a huge yield and tasted amazing.

text:
I loved this recipe, my kids loved this recipe, people who weren't huge fans of chili loved this recipe and it won first place in a chili cook-off at my place of employment so I'm not sure what better endorsement there could be.

Unfortunately, I did make two small changes so none of what I'm writing is STRICTLY for the original recipe... However, of those changes one was accidental (I used three jalapeos instead of one due to a failure of my own reading comprehension) and the second change was to add 1.5 tsp of Chipotle chili powder on top of the 1/4 cup of regular chili powder. I personally prefer more of a smoky flavor so I tweaked it to suit my tastes. Other than that this recipe is perfect and makes plenty, I heartily recommend it.

I've made this countless times for home and contests. I've won just about every chili contest I've entered with this. I cook it overnight in a slow cooker.
I only make a few changes. I use serrano peppers vs Chile peppers. 1/4 cup chipotle chili powder vs dark chili powder. I add 8 Thai peppers, chopped not seeded. 
It turns out perfect every time!

text:
I've been using this as a base for years, so I'll give it credit as an origin. It's very flexible. I like to add more fresh ingredients, so I up the produce, use a whole rainbow of bell peppers, and sometimes add a cup or so of frozen corn after it rests to get it cool enough to store in the fridge. I use a smaller amount of *roasted* diced tomatoes instead of 56 oz of plain canned, and instead of all 4 cans of chili beans I mix it up and use chili, black and kidney. I think it ramps up the color, texture and taste. I never have bacon bits but they're not necessary by the time everything else is added in. I pack it so full that I usually just use two pounds of meat, like ground italian turkey and ground italian pork. I've also swapped meat for a can of garbanzo beans and/or vegan crumbles for vegetarians. My company held a chili cook-off and I made a variant of this just as an excuse to make dinner without a ton of leftovers, and the head of our company picked mine (an older Texan couple; as a Texan myself, I like rejecting the idea that chili has to be limited to meat soup). Feel free to experiment and toss in a bit of flavor sitting in your fridge (mustard, bbq sauce, you name it).

text:
I leave out the beer, sausage, and hot ingredients.  I use a pound of lean (97% fat free) ground beef and a pound of lean turkey so that I don't have to deal with pouring off any grease.  I use three kinds of mild chili and kidney beans for color.  I do not drain off the canned bean or tomato juice. Red, green, and yellow bell pepper also give nice color to the chili.  Very easy to make.  Ready to eat after a full boil for 30 minutes.  Tastes best with a dallop (tablespoon) of sour cream on top of each bowl.  Taste great over a baked potato or as a chili cheese dog.

text:
VERY VERY spicy and we like spicy stuff, but this is a little too extreme. I hardly get heartburn and man this did me in and my husband was literally sweating from how hot it was. We even added sour cream, but didnt help much. We followed the recipe exactly except we didnt add jalapeo peppers and Im glad we didnt or it wouldve been worse. I would say if you like spicy stuff, but want more flavor instead of burning your nose hairs off, just do all mild beans instead of one can of hot beans because thats the only thing I can think that overdid it. I used one can of the Meijer brand hot & spicy beans. Ive definitely had better chili, surprised it has such a high rating.

text:
MAKE THIS CHILI ALREADY!! I did make some changes as other reviewers suggested and some of my own. I used what we had on hand. Instead of ground beef we had ground venison so we used that and one pound cubed stew meat with the Italian sausage. After two hours the cubed meat was still fairly tough. I don't know if 6 more hours in the slow cooker will make it tender but tomorrow I'll remove from pot into slow cooker and cool some more. I used 4 slices of bacon, not bacon bits. 1 16 oz can chili beans with mild sauce and 1 with medium sauce. I don't care for beans so that's all I added but another can of beans probably would have been good. I used 3 cans diced regular tomatoes and 1 diced tomatoes with garlic, oregano and basil. I omitted the celery as hubby doesn't like it. I substituted 1 jalapeno instead of the two green chilies. I used one whole can of Lonestar beer. I omitted the hot sauce and used brown sugar instead of white. We served with cornbread. It was pretty spicy still so glad I didn't add the extra heat. Best chili I've ever had and I used to judge chili cook offs.

text:
I have made this chili at least a dozen times. I dont always follow the recipe to a T- but I ALWAYS use it as my grocery list/base recipe. There are a few things I always do differently- I add kidney beans, I use several different cans of tomatoes for all of the flavors (roasted, garlic added, habanero added etc.), I replace the celery with carrots (trust me, its amazing), and I add jalapeos. Sometimes when I dont have bouillon cubes I use beef stock which actually comes in handy because I like to slow cook this chili for 10-14 hours. This time I added fresh minced garlic and some roasted whole garlic cloves I bought from Whole Foods. I used to make several different recipes for my chili but my husband says this one is the winner.

text:
A great chili as is, but of course, there's always that one person who must do it 'their' way.
I'm not a fan of canned anything, so did the beans the day before in the slow cooker.
For the Diy Crowd:
     If you have fresh herbs, hot peppers and garlic - try Sarah's Chili Seasoning Mix by Sarah Dipity, 3 Tbsp fresh oregano (or to taste) 3 tsp fresh Basil,  the Homemade Worcestershire Sauce by mlally, fresh garlic from the garden, or in the spring - garlic scapes.
     I will post a homemade Cayenne hot sauce recipe and Chipotle hot sauce recipe  (both very easy)
Do you can your own tomatoes and tomato paste? we make over 100 jars of canned tomatoes each year, and  use the tomato machine, and process and freeze paste, so if you got it use it.
A lot of work to make, but for the truly homemade crowd...... why use canned?
If you have the time and a dehydrator, make your own paprika..... so easy.
Family amazed at the work we put into homemade, but why not?
Thank You MIGHTYPURDUE22 - great recipe!

text:
This is a great chili base to go from, which is what I did, I love big bold flavors and this is the perfect recipe to go with to make that happen. So I Frankensteined this recipe and made it essentially into a 4 meat chili. I used swanson beef broth instead of bullion as I find it too salty,  ground chuck as in the recipe, omitted the italian sausage for Breakfast sausage, added some thick chopped Linguica sausage, omitted beans in the recipe for black and white beans, added a serrano chile on top of the jalapeno instead of the tabasco, and will be adding a nice Firestone Walker- Easy Jack IPA.

text:
This is my go-to chili recipe and it is fantastic. it has just the right amount of kick to it. I use 1 lb ground beef, 1 lb ground pork like chorizo, and 1 lb turkey. After cooking the meat, dump it in a strainer to get the grease out and then return it to the dutch oven. I don't put the bacon bits in. I don't think it adds anything to the flavor and is kind of a junky product. 
You can't go wrong with this chili.
