text:
This was my first time making chili and after reading the reviews I had to give it a shot. I followed the directions with the exception of 2 items, I left out the cayenne pepper and the spicy beans. The chili had a nice spice but was not hot. For the bean I used 2 cans of chili pinto beans, 1 can of kidney beans and 1 can of black beans. The recipe yields a lot. It easily feeds 10-12 with extra helpings for all. I made a double batch for 20 people and had plenty to send home with a couple of guests and I have lunch for a couple days. I cooked this on low for  a total of about 8 hours. I've found my forever chili recipe.

text:
This has been my go-to chili recipe for years so thank you to the poster for posting it. The thing I love about this recipe is the number of ingredients and the versatility of the recipe.  Because it has so many ingredients, it doesn't suffer if you are missing some. I have made this in many variations depending on what I have in the kitchen. My family doesn't like green and red peppers so I leave those out.  I only include the beer if I have something crappy someone brought over.  Sometimes I add a can of corn.  I usually use a little more cumin than called for, and sometimes I add a little heat with jalapeo peppers....
Overall this is an amazing basis for killer chili.

text:
This is my go to recipe for chili for a crowd.  My biggest change is doing this in the crockpot. I usually start preparing it the night before, while I'm cooking dinner.... throw it all in the crockpot overnight.  It really does get better made ahead. I saute the meat separately, then also saute 4 pieces of bacon (instead of bacon bits).  Add the beans at the end.  Also, my kids are whiney about spicey food, so substitute the hot things to your taste.  I use one or two serrano chiles depending on size, chili powder as noted, and then let people put their own pepper sauce in  after.

text:
I have been making this chili for years, and we have a preference for a meatier chili so here are my adjustments. I use two packages (usually about 1 1/2 pound each) of stew meat beef that I then cut into smaller cubes, still add a pound of ground hamburger, and I find it easier to just use a 1 pound package of ground Italian sausage. I use 2 cans of chili beans in regular/mild sauce and then 2 cans of chili beans in spicy sauce. I have made it with three before but thats incredibly spicy, and although we do love spicy food that was a little too spicy for most people so we do half and half. I do cheat on the green chilis by adding a small can of Ortega or old paso diced green chilis. Other than that I follow the recipe to the letter. I will say they are right about simmering it for hours. I generally start at 11:30 in the morning putting it together and start simmering it around 12-12:30 and let it simmer on low heat until 5-5:30 for dinner. Its great reheated but be prepared this is a large recipe I give half of it away.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent starting recipe with little mods for the household.  I do a leftover Christmas prime rib chili recipe every year and decided to change from the norm for this batch.  The family has voted this one the best.  These were my mods to this...
Used a 6 quart Insta-Pot.  Browned the Sausage on Saute and removed.  Sauted all the vegetables with the garlic (used a couple of big Anaheims as the green chilis (not roasted just sauted).  Add the remaining ingredients on slow cook high for an hour.  Recipe mods - 3 cans of chili beans with sauce, 1 can 28 oz of diced tomatoes.  Reduce beef bouillon to 2 cubes. Delete celery.  Up the cumin amount by taste (I used 1.5 TBSP).  Substitute 1/4 cup light brown sugar for the white sugar.  Add back the sausage and cubed prime rib and set on medium slow cook for 6 hours.  Stir every hour (and taste of course :) ).

text:
Hello from Texas!  We know our chili.  This is a great twist on combining several types of chili into one bowl.  I've had sausage chili, beer chili, bacon added chili, spicy chili and so on.  This recipe nicely blends these types of chili into one.  I only made 5 small changes, 2 out of necessity.  For beans: (2 cans) BUSH'S Kidney Beans in a Mild Chili Sauce and (2 cans) BUSH'S Pinto Beans in a Hot Chili Sauce.  I like the look and taste of kidney beans in my chili. I am not fond of how strong tomato paste can be in a chili, I switched it for a standard can of tomato sauce. Added 1 cup of Shiner Bock instead of 1/2 of a cup.  My supermarket was out of fresh Chili peppers so I subbed a 7 oz. can of Chopped Diced Green Chilies, Fire Roasted and Peeled, Medium spicy. My final change was a goof on my part.  I did only 1# of ground beef instead of 2#.  Came out just fine, but I will be adding in that 2nd # next time.  In my opinion one ingredient above all else must be of good quality, the chili powder.  It changes the entire taste.  McCormick Gourmet Collection Chili Powder is really good.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This chili was amazing. It may look like there are a lot of ingredients but it is well worth the extra few minutes. I doubled the recipe with the following changes.
Our family doesn't love beans, so when I doubled the recipe I used a total of 6 cans of beans, two cans in spicy sauce and 4 cans in the regular sauce. In addition, instead of doubling the ground chuck and Italian sausage, I used a 3-pound pot roast that I shredded once cooked through. Having the different meat textures was a great addition and I would definitely add that again. The chili gave a nice kick without it being too hot for the younger children. I will definitely make this again!

The first thing my wife said (as I was browning the italian sausage) was "You don't use italian sausage in chili!"  Etc., etc., to the point where I was regretting haven ever undertaken the task.  This went on until she got tired of telling me how everything I was doing was wrong.  Until she tasted the finished product.  Very humbly, she informed me that it was the best chili she had ever eaten!  I did kick it up a bit as we both love spicy food.  I used Serrano peppers in place of the milder chili peppers. I almost added Habaneros but decided that might be imprudent.  This is definitely a keeper.

The first time I made this, I followed the recipe exactly except for adding another Tbsp of chili powder.  The flavor was great, but I prefer a bit more soupier chili and thought it needed more liquid.  This time I ran the vegetables through the food processor (added bonus: no picky eaters asking "what's that?") and didn't drain the beans.  To compensate for the extra sodium in the bean liquid, I used Herb-ox salt-free beef bullion.  I still added the extra chili powder.  Perfect!

text:
I thought it was way too spicy (I don't like spicy food), and my husband thought it was just right (he likes spicy).  So that goes to show it's all a matter of taste.  I made it with two jalapenos, and two tsp tabasco.  If I make it again I might cut down to just one jalapeno and one tsp tabasco.  However, those of us ketchup-is-too-spicy folks can tone it down by adding cheese, fritos and sour cream.
It makes a TON of chili.  I have large stock pot, not sure the dimensions but it might be 8 quarts.  It filled almost to the top.  I like that it makes so much, because I plan to freeze it in little portions.
I used two cans of Bushes Chili Beans Red Beans in Medium Sauce and two cans of Bushes Chili Beans Kidney Beans in Mild Sauce.  
The prep didn't bother me.  I does take like 30 ingredients and I felt like I was chopping forever.  But most of the spices are common spices that I will use for other things. Considering how long this chili will last, the prep time was worth it.
Overall, my husband loved it, and I liked it but thought it was too spicy.  But I will probably make it again.

text:
Unless you are a vegetarian, this is the perfect base chili recipe. I have been using this recipe for six years. It is excellent for a novice, just follow the directions and check off all the ingredients and you are guaranteed to have a great chili. More often than not, I make it in a crockpot.

Over the past several years I have customized this recipe to my own taste. I no longer eat pork, so I omit the bacon bits and use turkey sausage. I wouldn't recommend using turkey bacon. It tastes fine, but it throws the texture off. I like things spicy, so I add lots of Tabasco and sriracha. I also add mushrooms, black beans, spicy brown mustard and just a pinch of cinnamon. 

I used to make it with bouillon cubes, but now I just drain all canned ingredients really well and add some beef broth in addition to the beer. This recipe has a ton of prep work, but it is absolutely worth it. I have won a couple of chili cookoffs with my modifications and a few marriage proposals (many from complete strangers). 

I definitely recommend it.

text:
I make this ALL the time, it is a family favorite. I dont use fake bacon bits, I cook up 3 or 4 slices of bacon so it is nice and crispy then I cook the veggies in the bacon grease until they are tender and the onions are translucent and I add the garlic for the last minute of the veg saut. Also I drop the tomato paste on the bottom of the hot pan after I brown the meats and stir it around until it is nice and fragrant then add all the other ingredients. I let it simmer away all day on the stove top low and slow and usually serve it the next day if I can keep my family away from it.

text:
This chili turned out AMAZING!!! Seriously best chili Ive ever had or made for that matter!! I tweaked it just a tiny tiny bit cause I never follow a recipe exactly as it says haha. Included with the ingredients I added a packet of McCormick Original Chili Seasoning. I also used two cans of the chili beans in mild sauce instead of just one (I like spice) & then only one can of the regular chili beans. I used 2 regular sized cans of the diced tomatoes instead of the 28 oz cans and the ones I bought were seasoned in a chili sauce (I believe the cans say chili ready or something along those lines.). For the beer I used 3/4 of a can of bud light (yum). For the Tabasco sauce I used Franks Red Hot. I used tomato sauce (6oz) instead of tomato paste. I held the cumin, basil, celery, Fritos, and the sausage (the sausage was only because I forgot to add it to my grocery list but chili still turned out so  good!!). To serve I put it in a single serving sized bowl and topped with about another tbsp of shredded mild cheddar cheese, 1 1/2 tbsp of sour cream, and a few saltine crackers!! My girls who are extremely picky eaters LOVED this chili!! My oldest whom is 19 doesnt even like chili until she ate this!! I do plan to do this recipe next time adding the sausage and also the Fritos as it calls for but I will do everything else the same. This would be great to make for a Sunday football game gathering!! I will tell you that mine did come out with a spicy kick! Enjoy!

text:
Nice chili, needed a lot of extra spicing-up to bring it to tailgater-standards for me. Rather bland the way it is (kind of like Purdue football!).  Main problem for me was that it just made too much chili for my pot and slow cooker. When MightyPurdue22 says use a large pot, he's not kidding...a giant pot!

Here's what I had to add to bring it up to the proper spice-heat: 2 seeded/chopped jalapeos, 2 extra tsp. cumin, 1/2 extra tsp. ground black pepper, 1 tsp. ground ancho chili pepper, 1 tsp. ground chipotle chili pepper, 1 tsp. ground mustard. I also added 4 slices of chopped, cooked bacon.

This is a good starting point for a chili that is a bit spicier, more SoCal style. Fight On!

text:
So, we have a member of the household that doesn't do well with too much spice, so... One Anaheim Chili, one dried Poblano Chili. instead of 1/4 cup chili powder I used 1/8 cup chili powder and 1/8 cup smoked paprika. Throw a carrot (chopped) into the mix. I served it with molasses cornbread and it was a hit. 2 lbs ground beef and 1 lb mild italian sausage. Instead of bacon bits I rendered some bacon ends and pieces (about 1/4 lb.) down and drained off the grease. I didn't drain the grease from the ground beef and sausage. It gives the product a richer flavor.

text:
Spicy, rich and meaty, and so good!  This recipe has a lot of ingredients to it, but it doesn't take long to throw it all together.  And the end result is a great tasting spicy chili.  This recipe is up there with my top favorite chili recipes.  I didn't have sausage, so I left it out, but it would of been great in it.  I also didn't have any beer to use up, so I just added in water for the liquid.  I doubled the garlic and worchestershire sauce, and waited til the end to add the beans.  For the beans, I added 1 less can than stated, and used regular kidney beans.  I cut the serving size down to 6 to make a smaller batch for us, and it was almost eaten all up with just the two of us.  This chili is more on the meaty side and not real saucy like we normally have our chili.  But it is perfect with the toppings added.  Along with the shredded cheese and corn chips, I also garnished with a dollop of sour cream.  So good!  This had the perfect spice level for me, but it was too much for my hubby.  So next time I may have to cut down on the cayenne and chile's for him.  I will for sure be making this again!  Thank you for the recipe!

text:
Delicious!! I used regular kidney beans, as we dont have spicy ones in Canada (that I could find). I used half spicy Italian sausage and half regular. I used four (4) jalapeo peppers in lieu of cayenne and hot pepper sauce. I found the pot a bit dry, so I also added a cup of water before letting it simmer for 3 hours on low. I found that the chilli didnt need extra salt, so I omitted that ingredient. You can always add salt after the pot has simmered, but you cant take it out if you find its too salty at the end of the cooking process.

I added about 1 pound of stew meat and used 2 serrano and 2 jalapeo chilis. Also substituted 2 14oz cans of fire roasted tomatoes for one of the 28pz diced tomatoes and a can of garbanzo beans for one of the chili beans. Added 1 6oz can of diced green chilis.

Bottom line is the chili is delicious and I will make it again.
Unless youre making this for a large crowd Id suggest reducing the ingredients by 1/2. As written this make a huge pot of chili and youll need two crock pots or a gigantic stew pot

text:
My husband and I LOVED this recipe!   I had some ground venison that I had no idea what to do with.  I had never cooked with it before and a friend gave me some to try so I chose this recipe for it.  I am SO GLAD I DID!
I did pretty much everything the recipe called for with the exception of not really measuring out my spices.  I was pretty heavy handed with the cayenne and hot sauce because we like our food with a bit of a kick to it.  I also used a jalapeno Italian sausage which also kicked it up a notch.
The results were incredible.   I am SO making this one again even if I have to use ground beef instead.  It will be delicious no matter which meat I choose... Beef  or venison, this recipe is a keeper!
Thanks MIGHTYPURDUE22,  for this recipe!

PS...   I used the entire bottle of beer ;-)

I've been reading some of the reviews and now, I can't wait to see how it tastes tomorrow!  I simmered it on the stove for almost 3 hours, but letting all of those AMAZING ingredients develop overnight are sure to keep me dreaming about tomorrow!

ALSO, the reviewer from Texas that gave this a terrible review...  I lived in Texas for YEARS and NEVER had chili there that was as good as this and I went to MANY chili cook offs wile living there.   Don't get me wrong...  I LOVE TEXAS food!  AMAZING and if you have never tried it, you should!  HOWEVER, THIS chili will rival anything I ever tasted there.

I love this recipe!! I have been using it as a base for years.  We're having a snow day and this chili was all I could think about. I love it so much. Now I know people hate when reviewers mess with the recipe, but I feel it's one where you can. Especially if you're using whatever you have on hand or if you/your family can't eat certain things. Which is normally what I do. I had a leftover yellow and red pepper so I used those, the last of my celery and some shredded carrot. I must have run out of jalapeos  so it's not spicy this round.  This time I had like 5 lbs of beef (this is going to last us a few days which I wanted), so I doubled the tomatoes, but still only one can of paste. Since I am eating LCHF, I left out the beans and the others in my house don't mind that. I add the chef's base seasonings and then from there, season to taste.  I also never add the beer. I don't keep it in the house so never have it when I make it. One day I will add it to see how it tastes. OH and I added Better Than Buillion b/c that was all we had around.  I also left out the sugar.  It's a great chili!

I love smothering it in sour cream, cheese, and jalapeos.

This is one of the best chili recipes I've ever tasted, and I say this as a casual chili, taco, nachos, etc enthusiast.  Now, mind you, I love chili, tacos, etc, but haven't deviated much from the common preparations until I followed this recipe to the letter.

/n

 This chili is THE BEST chili I've eaten in a long while. Unless you hate beans in your chili , if you come onto Allrecipes.com and do NOT try this chili at least once, you've failed to provide your own tastebuds and those of your friends, family, strangers, and guests you're feeding with true chili. 

/n

I've since incorporated much of this recipe (especially the spices, sugar, etc and the small amount of celery, then cook slowly on lower heat until ALMOST browned, then put in the taco mix for 5 min at high heat) into my taco recipe (which isn't too different from following the recipe on the back of the box that gives you the dinner kit, except I use 1/2 a pound of ground beef lean and half pound of chorizo), and it's delicious and much much much better.

/n

Again, as someone who isn't a culinary extremist or career chef, I call this true chili. Some on here (look at the tiny amount of 1 and 2 star reviews) think that because you use a lot of the powered variants of many hot peppers and franks red hot, it's not "authentic". I do not like super hot foods so the only change i made was to use medium hot chili beans instead of hot. This has a "little" kick to it which is just fine. It is a wonderful, hearty chili, but be warned - this will not fit in an average crock pot. I had to make it in an extra large pot. It will probably fill two standard crock pots. Otherwise, great recipe!

Turned out wonderfully! Perfect for a icy and cold day in Minnesota. It just happened to help me win the Chili Cook Off at work!!! Thanks All Recipes!

Made some changed based on what I had. Used two pounds of spicy Italian sausage and only one pound of ground beef chuck. Also, I used a whole bottle of Guinness instead of just a the portion of a cup that it recommended. This made the Chili a little more liquidy, which I enjoy. Also helped so you could actually taste some of the beer. My two chili peppers consisted of one jalapeno and one poblano to add the heat.

Would definitely make again!

This chili recipe is one of my favorites. I love to try new ones and last night I made this one and I'm very happy with the results. Typically the first time I make recipe, I follow it to the tee but this time I made two changes that I don't believe hurt it at all. text:
I made this last night at 7pm, cooked it until about 10pm, let it 'rest' in the fridge until today.  Into the crockpot at 9:30am this morning and into three chili judge's mouths at 11:45am.  At 1pm my chili was the 1st place winner of this year's chili cook-off!  

I made just a few changes to the recipe but stayed true to most of it....HIGHLY recommend this chili as it was excellent.  Most talked about one at the cook-off.

1)  I did 1.25 pounds ground chuck (thick grind for chili), 1.25 pounds mild Italian sausage, and 1.5 pounds of cubed top round (about 1/2" square pieces).  I also went with 6 pieces of crispy bacon instead of the small amount called for in the recipe.  My goal here was different sizes and textures of meat.  Achieved!

2)  For the beans I used 4 different bean types all Bush's beans: 
- 1 can of Chili Beans (Red beans) in medium sauce
- 1 can of Chili Beans (Black beans) in mild chili sauce 
- 1 Can of  Chili Beans (Kidney beans) in mild chili sauce
- 1 can of Chili Beans (Great Northern beans) in mild chili sauce
The recipe called to drain the beans.  I did NOT drain any of these beans.  Goal on this was different color variation and flavor combo...Goal Achieved and it was a great choice!

3)  I used an entire bottle of IPA beer vs. the little bit it called for.  Again a good decision!

4)  I used 1 standard red chili pepper, 1 Chilaca (Pasilla) pepper, and 1 Serrano pepper.  There definitely was some heat on the final dish but definitely not too hot at

text:
Giving this four stars since I made changes. I cooked this the day before, refrigerated, and then threw in crock pot the next day. I used less spicy ingredients - half chili beans in (mild) sauce and half regular pinto beans (drained). I used 1 can rotel diced tomatoes (chiles included, mild) and 1 can regular diced tomatoes. I left out the celery, chile peppers, black pepper, and hot pepper sauce. I cooked 1/2 package of bacon and threw it in. Then I cooked the onion and bell peppers in the bacon grease and added. Mine ended up way too salty, but I think it is because my chili powder (1/4 cup is a lot!) contained salt. I would be careful and add the boullion and any salty ingredients LAST, and slowly. I think I only used 2-3 cubes of boullion.

text:
So far, it's not bad. I cut the recipe in 1/2 (6 portions total), used 1/2 lb ground chuck and 6oz mild sausage. Added more garlic, veggies & beans.  I seasoned the veggies with salt & fresh garlic, then partially simmered them down. Added a little more than 1/2 of the spices to the veggies.

I then seasoned the meat with salt & cooked it down with onion & garlic. Half way through cooking the meat, I added the remaining spices & cooked it through. Then I added the partially cooked veggies, beer ( pumpkin leinenkugels) beans with chili sauce (omitted spicy chili beans, since I put in 2 large jalapenos In the veggies), tomatoes dark & light kidney beans added as well. When I tasted it, it didn't need the bouillon cubes at all. I also added a heaping tbls of white sugar, rather than a tsp.

So far so good. It's simmering now, and may need tweaks at the end prior to serving, but it's a good chili starter recipe.

text:
Delicious! I followed the modifications of some of the other reviewers and made some adjustments of my own, 
Halved the recipe, used 1.5 of beef chuck steak, 1lb of italian mild sausage and used 4 strips of bacon (substituted actual bacon for the bacon bits), added a cup of beer- used Hanger 24 Double IPA, and a 1/2 cup of beef broth. The added liquid made it super soupy which I'm not personally a fan of so thicken it up I added 4 cups of beans- 1 pinto beans in hot sauce, 1 kidney beans in mild (drained the kidney beans), and 2 additional cups of mixed chili beans- also drained- , 2 cans of tomato paste, omitted the spoonful of hot sauce, added a tablespoon of brown sugar, used a green chili and a jalapeno both seeded and cut, also omitted the bell peppers and sauted the onion, garlic- 4 cloves- chilies and celery in the bacon drippings prior to throwing them in the crockpot along with everything else

text:
This is a basic recipe but I change a lot.Yes use 2/3 beef and 1/3 loose pork sausage. 2 lbs of meat makes ALOT so you can do 1/2 of this recipe. So...-Only 2 cans of regular beans of your choice. I like pintos1 big can diced tomatoesYes 6 oz tomato paste2 jalapeo peppers finely chopped instead of hot. No beef bullion cubesEither 1/2 cup beer or red wine No oreganoNo hot sauce ( let people who want killer spice put it in )I didn't use black pepper and cayenne. You can use a little if you want more heat. More cuminNo basilNo sugarYes 1/4 cup chili powder or less if it is VERY spicey Yes to some bacon chopped up if you have it. Or saut in bacon fat. I first saut meat and some onion with some of the spices till brown and then take it out and saut the other veggies and add spices then. After they are soft I add back the meat and all the liquid and canned tomatoes and let simmer 2 hours. One more 15 oz can of tomatoes might be added if low in fluid and tomato.  Serve over rice.

text:
This is hands down the best chili I have ever tasted or made! I used my favorite import beer (more for later!) I did not use the 2 green chile peppers. I used a lot of chili powder (6-7 TBSP), freshly ground black pepper and cayenne pepper, as well as extra basil, oregano and garlic. I used almost a full bottle of beer, fried 6 strips of bacon (lightly browned. Itll continue to cook in the broth - some bacon fat in the broth adds flavor) then crumbled. Instead of 2  28oz. cans diced tomatoes, I used 4  14.5 oz. diced tomatoes  NOT drained.
I took the advice of other reviews and used 3  15oz. cans chili bean in mild sauce NOT drained; 1  15 oz. can chili beans in medium sauce.
I cook this in a slow cooker for at least 8 hours. Ive taken it to parties and made for my collage age boys for winter break. It makes a ton of chili and never has any been wasted. As a little change up, I sometimes serve leftover chili over medium shell or elbow noodles (with a little water to give it more broth) and shredded sharp cheddar cheese, delicious too!

text:
I've made it several times, and entered a few chili competitions (at work)  ....   I won every time!
I modify the recipe, 
3lb of beef / venison / bison
2 Red Jalapeno's  (or a habanero)
1 green chili 
2 cans of Bushes medium chili beans
2 cans of Bushes mild chili beans
28 oz can of crushed tomatoes with oregano and basil
no bacon bits... 
sometimes add chopped carrot 
no beer  (doesn't fit in my pot)
check heat (spice)  before adding pepper  black or cayenne
sometimes use all green peppers instead or red or yellow $$
this stuff is yummy, even following the as presented recipe.

text:
I made a few changes -- just because -- but I think the original recipe would be excellent as well. I used two cans of spicy red chili beans (one drained) and two cans of mild white chili beans (both drained). Made sure I used no-salt-added diced tomatoes (there's plenty of salt still). Substituted one pound of stew meat for one pound of the ground beef. Used spicy Italian sausage. Substituted a small can of mild diced chili peppers instead of the fresh pepper (my roommate can't handle spice like I can -- I'd use the fresh pepper, seeds and all, if it was just for me).  I made my own bacon bits with four slices of bacon and used the grease to sweat the vegetable mix until most of the onions were translucent. I omitted the hot sauce. 

As others have noted, the ingredient list is huge (I spent more time at the grocery store than making the chili... well, almost) and the prep time is pretty significant. Can't argue with the results though. I cooked it on low for 8 hours and then let it sit overnight in the fridge before reheating for lunch the next day. 

BTW, this makes a lot of chili. I literally filled my big pot to the VERY top (stirring was an interesting endeavor). I'll get a bigger pot before I make this again. For those that said they made it in a crock pot... HOW? Where in the world did you find a crock pot that big?

Overall, this is my new go to chili recipe when I have the time and resources to put into it. It's not something I would just "whip up" though.

text:
I'm giving this recipe 5 stars despite the fact that I've never made it exactly as stated.  I think it's got a lot of great elements and so I give it "5 stars" as a great place to start.  I don't add everything that the recipe calls for and I don't add what it does call for in exact proportions. for example,  I tend to start with 2 tablespoons of chili powder and work my way up from there.  Although I do a lot of changes I do have three strong recommendations . . .1. replace the sugar with swiss miss chocolate powder (I know.  sounds strange. you'll thank me later) 2. add chopped chipotle peppers and some of the sauce. (you can find this is the mexican food isle.  comes in a short can.  adds a smokey flavor.  they are spicy so start with 1tblsp and go from there).  3. use a flavorful sweet beer like guinness not a bitter IPA or flavorless pale ale.   That's all .  have fun.

text:
This is a great basic chili recipe. It's easy too whip up, easy to tweak the spiciness to your liking, the veg, bean, and meat ratios are perfect for a hearty chili. Barely visible Tweaks:) I used Nina Italian peeled tomatoes because the flavor is outstanding for a canned tomato, not sour like some brands, though you have to chop them up before adding them to the pot. I used two cans of kidney beans and two cans of Bushes black beans in chili sauce. I added Sierra Nevada Torpedo IPA because the flavor is BIG. And added the bacon at the end after I tested the existing saltiness. Next time I would cut back the bouillon (in half) and add all the bacon because... it's so tasty.  If you have BIG flavors in your pot then you can use less salt or bouillon bring out those flavors. Viola delish. We served it with jalapeo cheddar cornbread. Jiffy, of course.

text:
THIS IS THE BEST CHILI EVER! My family really enjoyed eating this especially my husband who is not really a chili eater. I read through the reviews and made a few modifications that were suggested. I reviews I read mentioned it yielded, which I didnt want, so I didn't put all the amounts recorded in the recipe.... I used beef stew meat (close to 2 lbs) and sweet Italian sausage (1lb) instead of ground beef. Cooked real bacon (4 strips) and sauteed the celery and onions in the grease before adding. I used less beef cubes (3), beans (1 mild and 1 spicy) and diced tomatoes (2 cans of oregano and garlic diced and 1 can of regular diced tomatoes). Used 1 jalapeno pepper, we did want a lot of spice and instead of the hot sauce, I used red pepper flakes. And instead of beer I used beef broth. Letting it sit over night really does the trick. I will always reference this recipe again. It is really, really good!!!!!

text:
Yes I will make this again!! Perfect for a large crowd and you do need a very large pot. This is a great recipe, easy to adjust to your tastebuds or to adjust to the ingredients available at your grocery store.
I sauted 2 lbs of lean ground beef, mild sausage, one chopped medium yellow onion. Since I didn't have Italian sausage, I  added to the meat an extra tablespoon of each of the following: oregano, basil, minced garlic. 
Here are my other adjustments/substitutions.
I did not drain any of the cans of chili beans in the mild sauce (beans in mild sauce was all that was available at our store).
Substituted 2 serrano peppers for the 2 chile peppers.
3 tablespoons bacon bits.
5 cubes beef bouillon in 5 cups of water. Omitted the 1 teaspoon of salt.
1- 12oz beer.
1.5 tablespoons Turmeric.
3 teaspoons cumin.
1 teaspoon coriander.
Omitted cayenne pepper because we didn't want it too spicy.
Omitted the white sugar.

Some reviewers criticized the canned goods, so if you want to make fresh tomato sauce and use fresh beans it is easy to substitute and make those adjustments accordingly.

If you like it spicy hot, use the beans in spicy sauce plus more tabasco, chile peppers, and/or cayenne pepper.
This is a delicious recipe and was fun to make!

This Chili here is very close to an exact recipie Ive came along with. By years of tweaking amounts of the different herbs salts. Kind of tomatoes spice used for heat is different as is the use of hot sauce itself. I use dried ted pepper flakes.  And i do not use much at all. A great pot of Chili!!  Just a bit too much heat for my taste
To me Chili doesnt need to be spicy , it does need the southwest flavors cumin chili pwd etc though!
Hence my four stars

I made this almost exactly as it was written except I didn't have chili beans, and substituted red kidney beans. It was very tasty, but when I asked my husband to rate it, he said it was one of the top five he has had... not the best. Better luck next time - back to the stove !

The only change I made to this the first time, was to use ginger-ale instead of beer as I had no beer in the house. to this the first time and it was a huge hit with both my family (all big boys) and co-workers.

The second time i made it, I first sauteed the vegetables in just a little bit of pork fat (bacon grease) in the pot i was using, then cooked the meat in it and then added 1 Cup of Dr. Pepper and boiled that down by half before adding everything else. Another huge hit with my family and at a potluck. I doubled the recipe the 3rd time and froze containers of it for quick dinners throughout winter.

text:
I've made this one about 20 times now and it never fails to impress my family and guests. This time I switched it up a little and threw a pound of bacon into the grinder with a 2lb flank steak and browned it all with the sausage, then added all of the chopped veggies for a big saute. Then I added all of the tomatos and beans (of which I used black, chili, spicy chili, great northern, pintos, and kidneys).  Simmered over night, froze it in a cryo bag, took it camping and reheated in boiling water. Served over Fritos with shredded cheddar and Greek yogurt on top.

Probably the best one yet. I credit the extra bacon.

text:
My first thought was "Da@#, that's good chili!" Then my husband tried it and he said, "Da@#, that's good chili!". Seeing as how we've been together over 20 years, we often think alike... The kids still said "Blech, what stinks?", but at 5 & 7, food connesuires they are not so we ignored them. I made this exactly as written and it doesn't need a tweak. It has a really deep flavor without being "fusiony" or sweet. Just really great, honest chili. I don't use bouillon cubes, so used 4 tsp. Better Than Bouillon and diced up 2 serranos since "green chiles" leaves an open interpretation. I also couldn't find chili beans without sauce, so just used 4 undrained cans of medium spicy beans. Watch the oz. directed on the diced tomatoes, i had to add extra later since I assumed regular 15 oz. cans were called for when it should be 28 oz. cans. This one's officially in The Book! Oh, and you'll need a HUGE pot. It nearly rimmed my 7 qt. Dutch oven pot and the leftovers freeze beautifully.

text:
Ok so I tweaked this a little but majority of what I did stayed true to the recipe. First I used cubed stew beef that I cut into smaller chunks instead of the ground beef. I then seasoned them well and set aside while I prepped everything else. I combined all the spices together in a bowl so I didn't have to do it while I was cooking. I didn't have beer so I just made a strong beef stock by using korrs concentrated beef stock in 3 cups of water and adding 3 of the beef bouillon cubes (the other was crushed into the seasoning mix that i combined in a bowl). I had a ton of canned beans so I used those instead of chili beans. So I used kidney, black, pinto, and white beans. I also used two different types of diced tomatoes. I used one that had oregano and basil in it and another that had green chili's. I still chopped pabalno and jalapenos into the chili so it had a little kick but not too bad. Lastly I followed the advise of other reviews and did a 2 day cooking process. I cooked via stove top the day before for about an hour then transfered it to my crock pot insert and chilled. Then the following day I cooked it on low for 6 hours and let it sit for awhile before dinner. It came out so yummy. It was a bit of a process but worth it. My sister said it reminded her of Wendy's chili. Not sure if that's a good thing or not lol but all in all will be keeping this recipe. Hope the tweaks help out any others.

text:
This is my go to chili recipe for a starting point, and have made it many times! I love being able to control the spices vs.just grabbing a salt ladened chili seasoning packet from the grocery store. The flavors are amazing together, and I love the addition of beer (I use a whole bottle), but you can adjust it to your taste - if you like it more spicy (which we do), add a bit more chili powder and/or hot sauce; if you like more beans, add more (we add black beans & red kidney beans); you can use what ever meat you like, but I like the hamburger/sausage combo, or use none at all; I typically add cilantro, but a lot of people don't like that flavor - the point is, this is a great recipe that you can adjust to your liking. Thank you for posting it!

Very very delicious and will make this several more times in the future. Thanks for sharing!!

text:
This is the recipe i've been building off of for years.  I don't bother using beef boulion or bacon because it doesn't seem to matter.  The biggest thing is the dried ingredients need to be as fresh as possible.   Also the meat needs to be high quality, which may seem counterintuitive when you're making chili, but it makes all the difference.  I use a short rib/brisket/chuck blend.  

I've messed around with the liquid content quite a bit until I'm happy with it.  Sometimes I use more tomato, sometimes I use half the beans drained half not.  The sweet peppers and garlic and celery are totally worth the extra prep time.  

It all sounds really basic but no joke I've been tweaking mine for 5 years.  This is just the base recipe.

A few adjustments and substitutions: 1 lb spicy Italian sausage, 3 15oz can medium spice chilli beans NOT drained, 2 14.5 oz diced tomatoes in juice, 1 14.5 diced tomatoes in oregano with juice, 1 bottle Alaskan amber beer, 1 tsp brown sugar.  Cooked on the hob for 1 hr, refrigerated overnight, then kept on warm on the crock pot for 6 hrs. Best chili I ever made, delish!!!This makes for a huge batch, I ended cooking in two pots.

text:
This is a very solid chili.  I followed the directions exactly but my kids were not crazy about the chunky vegetables.  The second time I made it, I changed the recipe slightly, and everyone really loved it.  I added an extra LB of ground beef, I used a full beer (it calls for 1/4 cup and I used Guinness)  I also added a 1/4 cup unsweetened coco powder, and 1/4 cup brown sugar.  I also pureed all of the tomatoes, peppers, onions, and celery before I added it to the pot.  The only chunks were from the meat and the beans and the whole family loved it.  It did increase the spice level a bit so If you want less spice, you may want to use only one Jalapeno instead of two, and back off of the chili powder a bit.  Enjoy!

text:
I've used this recipe three times in a company-sponsored chili cook off and won twice. Yes, it's made with can goods (beans and tomatoes) but if you buy a good quality canned item (Red Gold, Luck's, or Bush's), it's really not horrible. I do tweak the recipe a bit  from the recipe, I use Serrano peppers with seeds, hot Italian sausage, actually fry a pound of good quality bacon (chopping it up and using the entire pound), and Shiner Bock beer. I also add a pack of Aidells andouille sausage. I know you are thinkingholy cow at the protein, but the crisp bacon and andouille sausage adds texture and flavor. I actually crock pot the chili and prepare it two nights before the competition. After mixing, I crock it on low for about 4 hours  stir occasionally. After cooking, it rests in the refrigerator on day two and I bring it to work the morning of the competition and heat it on low/simmer for about four hours. I like to say this recipe with my tweaks offer the taste buds a residual spicy heat.

text:
Fantastic!!  I won 1st prize in a chili cook-off against 15 other chilis!!   Made some very slight modifications, based on what I had on hand. I used 1/2 amount regular paprika and 1/2 smoked paprika and used 3/4 can of green chili's, instead of fresh..Also used fire roasted red peppers and diced tomatoes.   I made the chili the night before in a crock pot and left on warm overnight.  I planned on adding the beer and REAL bacon in the morning,  after I could get a better sense for the taste and choose the right beer.   The chili was PERFECT as is and I didn't want to mess with perfection,  so I omitted  the beer and bacon, entirely. I will try adding these vital ingredients next time when I'm not being judged,  however, I liked the consistency without the half cup of beer....I'm afraid it might be too watery with any more liquid.  This chili was a WINNING HIT!! Thank you!

text:
I was in the kitchen probably for an hour prepping all the veggies and cooking the meat. It was a LABOR of LOVE that is for sure and you can tell in the taste. 
I will have to say this reading the recipe from the app I missed a few ingredients that could have played a major role in the taste profile. My suggestion would be to open/read through the website. 
1. I could not find chili beans in SPICY SAUCE. (I figured I can add spice to the recipe since I could not find in my local Stater Bros supermarket here in CA) 
2. I did not use cayenne pepper or paprika which I did not have nor did I see it on the app version of the recipe. 
3. I used fresh bacon that I cooked and crumbled into the meat mixture 
4. I used Tecate light for the beer. (I am sure that you can use any beer)
5. I added Cajun creole seasoning because I didn't have the cayenne or the paprika. 
6. I did cook the chili for 4 hours in total 
7. And it was quite expensive to make once you add the cost of ground beef, Italian sausage and canned items. 
8. I did not use a crockpot for this. I used a large deep round pan with a lid and cooked on low. 
9. BEWARE THIS MADE A LOT. I was shocked by the amount it made. 
10. My family really enjoyed this recipe. Everyone went back for seconds. I would suggest like others have said make the day  before and allow the flavors to blend more together. 
11.

text:
The only thing I did differently was not to add celery but it wasn't a deliberate choice. Don't be intimidated by the amount of ingredients, this really is a very easy recipe to put together, just remember to leave AT LEAST 2 hours for simmering. If you are super organized, make it the night before you plan to eat and then gently reheat, this way all the spices have plenty of time to get friendly with each other. I tried it the first night and thought it was ok, reheated for the fam the second night and was blown away.  I will use this recipe from now on, just perfect.

text:
Absolutely delicious!!  Whenever  I try a new recipe I usually stick to their instructions and then tweak from there to my family's tastes.  BUT THIS does not need much tweaking at all!  Made this for the first time for my partner and his employees (small auto body shop) so I decided to tone down the heat a bit (served cayenne and Franks Hot Sauce on the side for those who like a little more kick) so that everyone can enjoy it..  

Only minor changes were:

1.  Green chilies substituted for one jalapeno; minced, seeded and spines removed.  

2.  I couldn't find "spicy chili beans" so I just used regular chili seasoned beans (seeing as I wanted to keep the heat to a small kick) and I reserved the sauce from the first 3 can of beans, in case the chili reduced too much and I needed to add some liquid (better than water!).

3.  I seasoned the meat with sea salt, black pepper, garlic powder and onion powder when frying it.  The amounts are not not precise but rather by my own tastes.  

4.  I slightly sauteed the veggies in the pot (after draining the excess grease from the meat) then added the meat and tomato paste and let that cook a minute or two before adding the beans, tomatoes and seasonings.

5.  I also used "no salt added" whole canned tomatoes and crushed them by hand to reduce the salt content (salt can easily be added by the diner)  

Served with hot corn-on-the-cob, fresh soft sourdough buns and of course lots of butter! ;)

I made this yesterday for a get together of about 9 people and everyone loved it. Only used 2 cans of chili beans in medium chili sauce (1 drained, 1 not) as we aren't huge bean people and it was the perfect amount. We also added a small can of diced green chiles (not drained) instead of fresh green ones. But everything else was exactly as written, cooked in a Dutch oven on the stovetop. It came together quickly and I let it simmer for about 3 hours before serving over elbow macaroni with shredded cheddar and sour cream. Delicious! Relieved we have some leftover to enjoy again! Definitely a keeper.

text:
Excellent chili. Nice range of seasoning. Many chilis just add chili powder and cumin. The additional seasonings in this one really add a nice balance. Also, the consistency is excellent. Not overly thick, nor too watery.

For others trying this, If any of your tasters don't like it too hot, start off with about half the chili powder and tabasco called for in the recipe. Then add some additional after cooking it for awhile if you'd like it hotter. The full complement of spices does have a nice kick to it--not really hot mind you--but enough to pop and eyeball or two from folks who don't like it too spicy.

text:
Made a triple batch for crowd tonight and it was a HUGE hit!
The flavor is just amazing - you get the Hot when you eat it, but it doesnt burn going down or linger.  Just great heated taste!  
For tripling I used 1lb ea mild, sweet & hot italian sausage, a  16oz beer, and  chipolte hot sauce.   Sauteed the onions & garlic in a little oil til clear, then added all the spices & sauces to the hot onion mixture for a few minutes before adding to the whole pot.   I made it the day before serving and let the flavors marry in fridge for 12 hours.   Cooked in roaster oven on high an hour, then low (200) for 6 hours.   I sealed the roaster with heavy foil entire time cooking and got a very juicy chili.  If you like it thicker I would just use lid or leave open last couple hours.  Will definitely make again!!

text:
I personally don't like chili.  But my husband does.  So, this is the third time I've made this recipe.  A lot of work, but they (hubby and his friends) say it's well worth my effort!  Too hot, as written, in my guys opinion....So I just shake in a little Tabasco til they say when!  And cut out the spicy beans (use only red kidney beans...no spices) and cut out the Chile peppers.   And it's absolutely true that it tastes better the second day.   Or the third day.  Or a week or more later!  I double batch and freeze individual containers for them, so it can be enjoyed for weeks.  If you're gonna spend all that time with all those ingredients, chopping, chopping, chopping.....you might as well do a double batch!  They love it!  Great recipe!

text:
This is the best chili I have ever had. I made a few changes according to what I had read in the reviews as well. First off, I used about 1.5 lbs ground beef, and 1 lb of pork sausage, and .5lb of turkey sausage. I also added pork sausage rounds. Instead of bacon bits, I cooked and chopped some of my own bacon. Instead of 2 chili peppers, I used 1 serrano pepper and added a anaheim pepper. I didn't add any tabasco or any hot sauce, and only drained 2 of the cans of bean, the others I just dumped in sauce and all. Instead of paprika, I used smoked paprika. Also added extra diced garlic. This is fantastic! Had a church chili cook off and out of the 17 chili's, after trying all of them, I had 2 bowls of my own because I really thought it tasted the best. I also added a full cup of beer instead of half cup. Fantastic chili and wasn't too spicy!

text:
Delicious recipe!  Made a couple minor changes that add some more fire:
1) Sliced and pan-fried spicy Italian sausages.  Added them to the browned ground beef.
2) Used 4 finely chopped Indian chili peppers (instead of Jalapenos or other less spicy varieties).

I think this creates a perfect amount of heat paired with melted cheese and tortilla chips.

Will make again!

p.s. The chili thickens after sitting in the fridge for a night.  Don't be worried if it seems soupy right after cooking.

text:
Refrigerate and eat the next day should be a mandatory part of this recipe. Honestly, you can't go wrong with this one. You can easily substitute beer for chicken stock and the result will be about the same.

FYSA: You might need two crock pots for this recipe, so I always use the tool to cut it in half.

Thank you MightyPurdue22 for the awesome recipe! Made it yesterday for Superbowl and it was a big hit. I did make some changes to suit the family "preferences" with no celery or peppers added and reducing the spicyness with only 1 tbsp of chili powder, 1 tsp cumin, no hot pepper sauce (had it available on the side) 1/2 tsp cayenne added. Used 2 cans of chili beans (molasses and maple flavored), and added 1 can of kidney beans and 2 cups of frozen corn (2 hrs before serving time). I made the chili in the morning and transferred everything into a crock pot to simmer on low all day, stirring every hour or so.  So yummy!

The spice mix was what made it. Thank you for the recipe and all the reviews that helped me.

text:
While I am no chili connoisseur every time I make this recipe I get nothing but rave reviews. Make sure you use a large stock pot and bring an appetite cause this recipe makes a ton (great for leftovers as it tends to get better as the week goes on and it soaks up all the yummy flavors in your fridge)! I do switch up the meats sometimes using more pork than beef or sometimes doing a mix of beef, turkey, and beef (and more often than not get the spicy versions of them). I use real bacon (2-3 strips) cooked and chopped up instead of bacon bits. I also sub a couple jalpenos for one of the anaheim peppers. Adding an extra teaspoon or so of sugar really counterbalances the spiciness quite nicely. Also adding extra veggies helps and never hurts anyone. I still find it can be quite spicy but it doesn't seem to bother anyone else, though I live in the heartland of spicy food. I add more beer or broth as time goes on and sits on the stove and people dip into it and suck all the juices out of it, I find it hardly affects the flavor. Just the other evening I did a can of black, a can of white, and a can of kidney chili beans and I honestly think there is no going back! Other than that I follow it exactly and people love it! Yes it can be time consuming fishing out all the spices but it is so well worth it. Will be making this recipe every football season from here til eternity :)

I started by smoking the meat and veggies on the Traeger with Mesquite pellets. This added a great new dimension to the already great flavors. I like it hot so I also added a couple of coarsely chopped Jalepenos seeds and all. I also use dark brown sugar as opposed to the white sugar the recipe called for and added a few ounces of good whiskey. Wow! My guests were all raving and begging for the recipe. This one is a keeper!

text:
We just made this (with some mild modifications) and it was the absolute best chili we've ever tasted.  We did 1 lb of ground beef, 2  lbs of chuck cut into small cubes, and a small package of fresh cooked bacon that we chopped after cooking (rather than bacon bits). We also used pinto, kidney, and black chili beans. We sauted the onions, peppers, and celery separately (so they wouldn't get that soggy taste), browned the meats separately, then added it in. And the first 28 ounce can of diced tomatoes was regular, the second was fire roasted with jalapeos. We didn't include beer. Seriously, this will be made for the next potluck we attend.

I have made this chili about a dozen times and made these small changes. All turkey meat (don't overcook during browning), twice the garlic, half the cumin, a half bottle of Beck's Dark beer, instead of 3 cans of pinto beans I mix it up with 1 pinto, 1 dark red kidney, and 1 can butter beans.  Maybe throw in a small can of green chilies as well.
Great recipe.

text:
Fantastic recipe to use as a launch point. 
I've used this as my base often and received heaps of love in return.
The only alteration that I feel qualified being... 
use a decent beer in the mix.
My favorite being Boddington Scotch Ale. The malt allows a sweetness that buffers the heat (I always crank up the peppers, most folks on this site tend to shy away)
By far my favorite variation. An Octoberfest works as well if you can get it in season.
Good eats my friends!

I fry the duck with garlic and onions till the breasts are slightly pink in the center then add to the chili mixture in a crock pot and cook on low for 6-8 hours.  So tasty!

I've made this for about 2yrs now and have gotten rave reviews from it. I must say that this recipe is pretty extensive in the ingredients but is honestly the best base chili recipe on this site if you follow the ingredients exactly. You can easily build off this recipe and personalize it a hundred different ways. I myself use fresh ingredients and dice up my tomatoes, omit the oregano, add a dash of lime and cilantro, use 3 habanero peppers, add a tsp of mustard, and use italian hot sausage, turkey and ground chuck.  It tastes amazing! 

In summary: Great starting point to really making your own personalized chili. Be adenturous :)

text:
so good! I used to make a chili that had a lot of beans but this has more balance with the meats. I had a few alterations... I make a half recipe first of all. plenty for a family of 4. make sure you drain your beans, and leave juice in the one can as directed. if you use all the juice it will be too much sauce. like others, I grilled bacon and saute my veges (I used red, green and yellow pepper) in the drippings. I used extra garlic. didn't have a green chili pepper so I used hot italian sausage and extra Frank's red hot sauce. it still had a kick but lacked a little in heat for me (I like it hot). my 8 year old who doesn't like chili loved it.  I omitted the beer and replaced white sugar with brown. still had amazing flavor. I serve mine with cheese, sour cream and banana peppers. insanely good. try it with banana peppers! this has been my thing since I was a teen and everyone loves it. they really compliment this recipe.

text:
Outstanding.  I have made this for a few functions to great reviews between young and old.  To appeal to my family, I have to take out the heat.  To get the best results I use freshest ingredients I can.  Go to the butcher counter and get a few slices of good wood smoked thick cut bacon, along with hamburger and ground sausage.  If you have fresh basil, garlic and oregano you can back off on the quantities slightly.  I prefer to cut up Roma tomatoes rather than canned.  I use 2 cans of black beans, one can kidney beans, and 1 can chili beans.  For the beer, a dark beer, like a stout works best, compared to a lager or pilsner.  Since my family thinks black pepper is "too spicy" I made this one week ago for a football game party.  5 qts. and no left overs.  Turned out fabulous.  Not too spicy, but enough to tingle the back of your throat.  Adding cheese really mellows out the heat.  Can't wait to make it again.

text:
Well, I'm one of several thousand reviewers who loved this chili. If you've found this review, than you already know all the variations people made to enhance/improve it. I replaced the ground beef with steak, cubed it and removed the fat, used flavored canned tomatoes instead of plain, used 2 Tbsp brown sugar instead of the white, and sauteed the veges and garlic in the bacon fat (I cooked 4 strips). Be sure you know the flavor of the beer you add as it will be noticed. I was afraid of too much heat so I reduced the chili powder to 1/8 cup and it was only slightly "hot." I entered our local chili cook-off contest and it won first place in the meat and bean category however, all the other entries were much spicier. For our taste buds, I'm glad I cut down on the heat. It is time consuming but worth it!

text:
Everyone in our family loved this chili, and we're all TEXANS (fifth and sixth generation, at that)! I have some trouble making a recipe just as it's written, so I left some things out (bacon bits, red bell pepper, Tabasco) and substituted some things (canned green chiles for the fresh ones). I also left out the bouillion cubes. I didn't want all the added sodium. I played with the spices a bit to make sure it had enough flavor. The Italian sausage helped in that area and was a great addition to the ground beef. I think this will be my go-to recipe that I'll use as a guide with my own modifications. 
Even Longhorns and Aggies can get along with Boilermakers, especially when food is involved.

I have been using this recipe for years and finally decided to give it a review. This is an excellent recipe that can be modified to taste. The corn chips go perfectly with the dish.

I loved this.  I made a few changes based on what I had in the pantry (i.e. no bacon or celery and used canned diced chilies instead of fresh chili peppers) but it was fantastic.  I wasn't sure of the taste alone, but when I served it over noodles with cheddar cheese and sour cream it was amazing.  My parents raved that it was the best chili they ever had, better than my step-dad who makes some good chili.  Almost as good as Real Chili in Milwaukee, WI.  Don't let the long list of ingredients scare you.  The hardest part is browning the meat and chopping the peppers/onion.  All the rest of the ingredients you dump in.

text:
I love this recipe as a really good base.  I will of course tweak it for my taste and my mood at the time.  Sometime I will substitute corn for the cayenne pepper, green chile peppers and reduce the hot sauce for those in my family that can't take the heat. Other times I double the cayenne pepper and use serrano peppers and jalapenos for the green chiles add a little more beer and GAME ON!  The point is, if you don't like this recipe exactly then tweak it, to make it your own, if you don't like canned ingredients then use fresh, this recipe is still the makings of great chili.

I lost my original Award winning recipe somewhere and was freaking out! I came upon this one in my search for something similar. I actually used 2 different recipes (what I liked from each) to get my own. Anyway, This has currently been simmering for a little over 2 hours now, and it is AMAZING! Better than my first. However, I did make some changes. First, I used only Ground Chuck. I omitted celery, but cooked 1/2 lb of Bacon and sauted the onions and a jar of Roasted Red peppers with Minced Garlic, followed most of the rest, with the exception of using Guiness beer (the whole bottle) 1 can of light kidney (Drained) 1 can of Dark kidney (undrained) 1 can of Chili beans (undrained) I added 2 tsps of Cocoa (Unsweetened) Brown Sugar & White, I also added one half cup of Brewed dark coffee. text:
This is one of the first recipes I tried from Allrecipes and it's one of my faves. I've been making this chili for years now and it always gets raves.

I make this just as stated with only a few changes... changes that fit my tastes... YMMV.

1. I use a good bratwurst instead of Italian sausage and it compliments the flavor much more! I've made it several times with Italian, but it's never as good as when I use good brats (the family completely agrees).

2. I did use a can of chili beans once, because we had it, and it added a nice spiciness. But I prefer to use 5 cans of beans: 3 dark red kidney and 2 black beans because I think it just tastes better and I like beans! (but I won't hesitate to use Chili Beans to replace one can of Dark Red kidney if the opportunity allowed)

3. I tried it with 'regular' beer and dark beer and, IMO, it tastes much better with dark beer.

4. I always add a Tbs of red pepper flakes and use "Better than Bullion" Roasted Beef flavor.

text:
This is a great recipe, however, I made it as is, and it was way too spicy. After researching how to cut down the heat, I added three more table spoons of sugar, a couple squirts of ketchup, some shredded carrots and squeezed an orange on top. Oh, and I threw in the rest of the beer. This cut down on the unbearable heat, but still kept the great flavors this chili has. It ended up with just a little kick, rather than a ton. I will definitely make this chili again, but maybe next time with a little less tobasco sauce, hot chili beans, chili powder, cumin and  peppers and add more veggies, sugar and beer. My very picky chef husband loved it and said I had his permission to make it again if it tastes that good.

text:
I made this recipe last night for our church chili cook off and was given many compliments.  That said, I did make a few small changes to tweak it to my personal taste and preference. The meat consisted of cubed stew meat (chuck), a tube of mild pork sausage, sweet italian sausage and beef chorizo all browned and grease drained when finished. Separately in another pan, I added four diced bacon slices and as it began to cook and render the fat I added the onion and celery and half a stick of butter.  Once the onion was carmelized I dropped in diced jalapeno chile and green bell pepper to soften them a bit.  Instead of fresh red bell pepper I used a fire roasted variety from a jar. Once cooked al dente, I added them to the meat and included the remaining ingredients.  Instead of diced tomatoes I used fire roasted from a can and instead of the chili powder I used a cocoa chili powder and substituted smoked paprika in place of regular.  I also added an additional can of kidney beans and four small cans of diced green chile as well as a full beer instead of half. Hot sauce was substituted with Sriracha with the addition of 3 TB of course ground mustard. it was a bit hot so I added a small can of diced pineapple chunks to mellow the heat. The result was the best chili I have ever eaten if I do say so myself!

text:
An excellent meat-lovers chili (especially since I halved this recipe but still used 2 lbs of meat).  NOTE: for those who find it too spicy, it gets milder the longer it sits. TIP: do not drain excess grease if you can help it and only use 80/20 beef if you want the authentic taste of chili houses.  

Also, I had no beer, only frozen bell peppers (no chili pepper), better than bouillon instead of cubes, no bacon bits and it was still wonderful ~ especially with my own cornbread!

text:
This chili is so very good. I followed the recipe as written using all the spices and added a few more dashes of tobacco and a few dashes of ancho chili pepper powder.  I used a 4oz can of diced green chili peppers and skipped the green and red peppers (just personal preference). We don't care for a ton of diced tomatoes so I only used one 28oz can and then added a large can of hunts tomato sauce.  I also used 3 cans of drained and rinsed pinto beans and 1 can spicy chili beans. I increased the beer to just about a cup. I put it in the crock pot and let it cook for several hours.  Served it with corn chips, sour cream, shredded cheddar cheese and some homemade corn bread. This is a nice change from my regular chili I have made forever, glad I found this recipe.

text:
I've made this recipe quite a few times and it is very versatile.  I interchange ingredients as I go, usually substituting in black beans and adding ground turkey and trying different beers every time.  I've tried Modelo especial, Tecate, Pabst and today I'm trying an IPA.  Modelo has so far been the best complement to the flavors.  The base ingredients are spot on and I recommend after you try the original recipe to tweak it any way you see fit.  I make it in the slow cooker and usually use at least 24 oz of beer, so this recipe is very easy to make in the slow cooker also.

text:
This is my "go to" chili recipe, i was asked to enter in a chili cook off at work and found this recipe here, won second place, not bad for an unexperienced chili maker. Now I make it every year. I make mine in the crockpot on low for 8 hours just cook and drain the meat and sausage and put everything in the crockpot, I do use 3 14oz cans of the tomatoes that have seasoning already, i like the ones with garlic and cumin on it. I don't add any sugar,worcestshire or tabasco sauce.
I add a chopped serrano pepper and  blend 1 chipotle pepper with the tomatoes. By the way I live in Texas and all my Texas friends love this chili.

text:
I tried this recipe tonight and my husband says, it's the best chili he ever had.  I followed the recipe almost exactly, just added some of my own little "twists": I used 1.5 lbs hot Italian sausage and 1.5 lbs 93% lean ground beef.  Added 2 habaneros in addition to the other veggies (we like our chili hot)!  Sauteed all the veggies (using olive oil cooking spray) prior to adding them to the pot. (I always do this when adding veggies to sauces, think it adds a great flavor). Put the 4 beef boullion cubes in 1 cup of water, boiled it, and threw that in the pot.  The beer I used was PBR.  Also I only used about 1.5 tbsp of chili powder (thinking I could always add more later if need be, but that turned out to be enough for me).  So just a few small tweaks, other than that followed the recipe exactly, and it's a keeper!  Thanks!

text:
I'm using this recipe for my 5th annual family chili competition. I did a lot of searching around and experimenting with different ingredients and this one looks pretty promising. I just finished my first trial batch and have to say I am not blown away. Although it does taste VERY good. I switched it up a little bit so its probably my fault. I used 2/3 of a serrano pepper and added some cajun spice to it.I used half yellow and then a white onion. This is a VERY good recipe but Im competing with people who are using exotic meats etc. After tasting it from simmering for awhile I am prepared to go to war with it. I would say that maybe 4 boullion cubes is too much because it seems a little salty. maybe 3 cubes or 2 1/2 or grade down from the salt requirement. i thought maybe since this is a tailgate chili that everyone would be drinking beer so the salt would be a good thing. there will be alot of drinking going on during this competition so maybe it works out. overall i would like to say thank you for this recipe and i apologize for mixing it up a bit but down south here we need some more spices. I think i will win 1st place if not place 2nd or 3rd out of 8 entries. this is a good recipe just go easy on the salt. merry christmas... time to eat some chili!! BTW I won 2nd first year 2nd second year 5th 3rd. no entry last year. Completely going in with something different this year. thanks.

text:
This has been a great recipe for me to use as a reference when making my chili, though I've never followed the whole thing. I always skip the bacon bits, usually the beer too, and just started dumping the spices in instead of measuring. This turns out GREAT every time, and just as good in a fast pressure cooker. I also use a pound of ground turkey instead of the beef and italian sausage. I usually don't have small peppers around, but I love adding a can of black beans with jalapeos, one can of chili beans, and one of kidney beans, just for variety.  If you want to add something to make up for there being less meat, you can add garbanzo beans for more protein (and you can easily make the whole pot vegetarian).

text:
Really good! Here is what I did: I cooked 3 ckn breasts in a slow cooker with half a huge onion chopped/1 can cream of ckn soup, then shredded it.  In giant slow cooker I threw in the shredded chicken, 1 cut up smoked sausage, 2 cans rotel, 1 28oz can baked beans with bacon, 1 30oz can brooks hot beans with chili, 2 15oz cans wolf chili no beans, 1 15oz can hot hormel chili, 1 small can green chiles, other half of the huge onion chopped, 1 green pepper chopped, 1 red pepper chopped, i kept adding the seasonings to taste until it was hot enough (I think I probably doubled the seasonings, and added hot sauce to taste and saracha). I did NOT add any extra salt because the chili beans have a ton of salt already. I set it on low in the slow cooker for a couple hours, then set to warm the rest of the day until dinner.  The chili got a little soupy, but taking the lid off the slow cooker made it thicken back up! Will def make again thank you! *I totally forgot to add in turkey bacon as planned, will do that next time. Men like bacon it pleases them lol

text:
I won a chili cook off with this recipe.  I did make some changes though.  I only used 1 lb of ground beef (or ground sirloin) instead of 2 lbs.  Make sure you use Jimmy Dean italian sausage.  I also added one can of black beans and reduced the chili beans to 2 cans.  Also, add 1/3 a cup of ketchup to the mix.  I added one can of hot rotel as well, to give it some heat.  As stated in the recipe, the longer you can let it stew, the better it will taste.  I usually go a minimum of 4-5 hours of stewing.  It's even better if you cook the night before, then refridgerate, and reheat the next day.

text:
Really REALLY REALLY GOOD!

Although I did change a bit in this recipe. I added more celery and instead of ground chuck--I used 2 1/2lbs of chuck steak cut into  small cubes (I tried to stay the same size as all the veggies as well). I didn't have any beef bouillon so I had to omit it. Instead of bacon bits I used two strips of bacon. So... lets do a bit of changing.

I began by cutting up the two strips of bacon into smaller pieces then putting it in the stock pot with a bit of vegetable oil. Fried it a bit until slightly brown. Put the diced onions in and cooked until transparent. Then added the chuck steak. THEN I added the Oregano, basil, and garlic. Stirred it up a bit then added all the vegetables (celery and the green+red bell peppers). Didn't use green chili peppers or Jalapenos. Let them cook a bit in the bacon fat and added everything else. And as a little treat I threw in some sweet corn (drained) yum~~~

Turned out super awesome!

I made this chili, as-is, for a chili cook-off at work and took home first prize. I usually make my chili with jalapeno peppers, but I went with this recipe since not everyone likes that much kick. I think I'm a convert to not having jalapeno's in the chili.

Overall, it's been one of the best chili's I've had and the pot I took to work was gone in minutes. Everyone loved it.

text:
This is the best chili to make if you have lots of time, and lots of chili lovers. The leftovers keep well, and can even be served over hot dogs. I usually let this simmer for 4 hours, even though the kids start eating it after 2. Although I usually make a much simpler chili with very few ingredients, this recipe is our very favorite. This recipe is also very forgiving, and substitutions or additions can easily be made. I saw some reviews saying this is too spicy: please don't forget that the chili powder is the chili spices, and not chili pepper. They are not at all spicy. If you add 1/4 cup powdered chili you will have an extremely spicy chili (that's how much I use when I make 10lb of kimchi, which is extremely spicy)

I chose this recipe for my very first attempt at making chili and it was a success! I loved how hot and spicy it was, very flavorful. I was a bit frustrated when this rather large batch wouldn't fit into my large pot when I began, but I split it into two pots and it turned out just fine. I topped my chili with sour cream, french onions, tortilla chip crumbs, and cheddar cheese... delicious! And very hearty. I also made corn muffins to go with it as well. I have so much leftover! But it'll make a good quick meal for the next week and I froze the rest. I definitely look forward to making this again. And even better, you can follow the recipe but also cater it to your own taste. Thanks!

text:
I was definitely skeptical with 26 some ingredients but it was actually pretty good.  At first, after I put all the ingredients in my crock pot, I thought it looked "dry" (not much liquid in there) but after simmering in the crock pot all day, it made plenty of rich "sauce." Also VERY VERY VERY zesty!!!!!  I think next time I might use the same spices, just less of them.  The heat was spot on (just right).  Also next time I might put the bell peppers in the food processor to get them smaller (I liked the flavor of the bell pepper, just not the big chunks).  The combination of beef chuck with italian suasage and bacon bits really put it over the top.

text:
I made adjustments to account for Gluten Free necessities and some other adjustments. I used andouille sausage instead of the bulk italian sausage, used 3-4 pieces of cooked crumbled pepper bacon instead of the bacon bits, used GF beer, used 1 teaspoon kitchen bouquet instead of beef bouillon cubes, used crushed tomatoes instead of diced, did not use the green chiles and kept everything else the same.   I'm not one that eats chili on a regular basis and I don't usually like it, however this was AWESOME! Just the right amount of heat/burn without too much.  I was almost wishing I wouldn't like it since it requires alot of prep work, however it is WELL WORTH IT! I did just brown & drain all the meat and put everything together in the crockpot (no real rhyme or reason to the order) to try and make it a little easier.

text:
instead of using ground beef and sausage, I used 3 pounds of round roast/ or the cheapest beef that is on sale. i cut the beef into bite size pieces (about a half a inch). Brown the meat on the stove pot then i add all of the other ingredients.I use a whole package of bacon. cooked the bacon until it is crisp then broke it up into pieces.  Also i use 1 1/2 cans of beer. I've used anything from bud lite to rouge dead mans beer. the poppyer the beer the better. I used to cook it on the stove top but now i brown the meet then throw everything into a crock pot. I usually put it in the fridge but i think i might let it cook in the crock pot all night. That way the beef will be extra tender and melt in your mouth and the longer you cook It the more flavor there is.

text:
I really like the recipe and have made it several times. A few of my modifications: I only use 1 lb of ground meat (It makes so much you really don't need two pounds). Sometimes I'll use ground turkey and turkey sausage to make it a little healthier. There is already so much flavor, it doesn't make a noticeable difference. I add 2 cans of tomato sauce or condensed tomato soup because it is so thick. If I don't have beer around I replace it with water. You can always add more liquid, depending on how thick you like your chili. I also make it the night before and reheat the next day. I wanted to try cooking it in the slow cooker, but it didn't fit! It goes great with Jiffy cornbread on the side.

text:
This recipe makes a great chili that has room for customization. I like to skip the Italian sausage and substitute more beef. I recommend using chuck roast instead of ground beef. I've tried it cubed and browned before adding and I've also tried it with slow cooked chuck roast. I prefer the latter while my wife prefers the former. If you do try it with slow cooked chuck roast, try not to shred it too much or you'll lose all those nice chunks during the simmer.  I also recommend adding additional spiciness if you like it hot. The stock configuration isn't really that spicy and I'm a wimp. I use crushed red pepper to heat mine up. Hope that helps.

This chili is EXCELLENT. I thought italian sausage in chili sounded bizarre, so I did not use it. However, once all the flavor came together I can see it being excellent. This is a VERY unique chili, very good though.  The changes I made were a bit more onion and pepper. Fresh diced tomato rather than canned. More fresh garlic, used about 6 cloves. Writing the review now as it's been simmering 90minutes, so has more to go, as is at this moment it's just incredible.  5 stars and then some.

text:
Great recipe.  Prepared exactly as written the first 2 times (great) but did some adjustments (better).  Mostly in technique, but some substitutions (minor) in ingredients.  After cooking the meat and setting aside to drain, I sauteed the onions, celery and bell pepper in a little olive oil until half cooked.  Then added dry seasonings (except chili powder) to 'bloom' flavors for a few minutes and then added wet seasonings (ie mix of chicken and beef bouillon cubes already dissolved in 1/3 c. boiling water; beer; Worcestershire sauce; Tabasco).  Added chili powder (New Mexican) with all the canned ingredients.  Used 2 cans of no-salt tomatoes (there's plenty enough salt already) and used 2 cans of chili beans (in sauce) and 1 can drained/rinsed red kidney beans. I thought a total of 4 cans of beans was a bit much; 3 made it a better balance.  I added a large can of mild diced green chilies in addition to the jalapeno pepper.  I've made this with and without bacon (when I didn't have any) and both are good.  I use the pre-cooked bacon easily available these days and throw them in while I'm sauteing the onions.  Am not Jewish, but have found kosher bouillon cubes to be excellent (I'll never go back to the regular ones).  Depending on who will be eating the chili I may cut down on the cayenne a little.  Best served a day or two later and really yummy with Mexican crema (sour cream) also easily found at the supermarket.

I made this chili for my work's Chili Cook Off and I'm currently in the lead with only 3 competitors left.    I made the following changes: 1.5 lbs of ground chuck 1.5 lbs of spicy italian sausage 1 40 oz can of mild beans 2 15 oz cans of spicy beans No celery Minced the green & red pepper to be really fine so it wasn't so chunky. 12 slices of fresh bacon chopped 1 bottle of beer No tabasco because it was too spicy already   I served with Pasta, Fritos, Sour Cream, and Cheddar Cheese.  I offered pureed pineapple to tone it done, but everyone liked the spice.  It was delicious!

text:
This is the best chili I've ever eaten or made!  I did make a few minor changes.  Instead of Italian sausage, I substituted regular hot pork sausage.  Also substituted 2 cans of Rotel chopped tomatoes with chilis added, then omitted the 2 green chile peppers. I fried 3 pieces of bacon reserving the drippings to saute the onion, bell peppers and celery before adding to the mix, then crumbled the 3 pieces of bacon (substituting for 3 T of bacon bits).  I used Hot Mexican chili powder, a whole can of beer, 1/2 teas. cayenne pepper and an extra teas. of sugar.  I ended up not using the 2 teas. hot pepper sauce because with the chilis, hot sausage, hot chili powder and cayenne, it was VERY spicey (just the way we love it) although hot sauce can be added later.  Definitely THE best chili ever and even better the next day!
