I am SO proud of myself for making this and for making it taste good - great flavors!  Makes it look like I know what I am doing!  I used 1 lb lean ground beef, 1 lb ground turkey, 1 lb turkey sausage.  I used an anaheim chile pepper and no celery.  I sauteed the onions in the pan I made the bacon in before adding it to the mix.  I used beef broth instead of beer.  I also used only 2 cans of beans - not the biggest bean fan, and also not enough room in my pot for more!  I will be serving this tonight for dinner and also entering it tomorrow into a chili cook-off.  We'll see how it goes.  My advice - unless you have the time, prep your veggies in advance - chopping and such.  Also measuring your seasonings in advance.  I was going to do all this Friday night as I was prepping other food and just didn't - wish I had.  Plus I wish I had a bigger pot!  UPDATE - I had great response in the chili competition today.  Mine was the only one that was completely eaten, BUT I didn't place in the top three.  Someone said that the ones that won were bland and mine was more flavorful and probably scared people.  It's Ohio, so maybe a bit of kick doesn't appeal to people.

This is the ultimate "everything" chili! I've made this 20+ times this year alone and I always get a fantastic response. I do make the following adjustments though .... I use only 1 lb of ground beef (2 lbs was too much for me), I use a full cup of beer, and I use 2 cans of chili beans, 2 cans of black beans (rinsed), and 1 or 2 cans of kidney beans. text:
I love SPICY foods, however, my husband cannot take the heat.  So I simply cut down on the cumin, hot sauce etc., and he can handle it that way.  I always make a HUGE batch of it in the biggest stock pot they sell at Wal-Mart.  The 1st night we eat the chili as is as a soup.  The 2nd night we eat it with sour cream and shredded cheese on top and use tortilla chips or doritos to scoop it and eat like a taco salad.  I freeze enough for an additional 2 nights of supper and I give some away to his grandparents for one night of supper.  So when I make chili, I go all out and it will feed us for 4 nights total (family of 4) and someone else in the family.  I love this recipe, although I leave some things out altogether according to my liking.  But this recipe is GREAT!  Also, I would like to say, that I use the Rotel Brand of diced tomatoes with green chilis original and mild version and it really helps boost the flavor.

text:
Because Madison and I don't need enough chili to feed the whole block we cut the serving size down to 5. That was still enough to feed more than five of us watching the football games and still have plenty left over. We did make a few modifications to the recipe. First of all instead of using bacon bits we fried up three strips of bacon and crumbled them. We then sauteed the vegetables in ther drippings before adding them to the chili. Madison doesn't like Bell Peppers very much so we left that out. That being said we prepared it the way the recipe directed us to. After simmering for about three hours the taste was OK. Left in the refridgerator overnight and reheated it had the best flavor and just enough kick. Spicey but not three alarm. We loved it. This will be a favorite at our Superbowl party!

text:
I've been making this chili for a few years now, and it's always a hit. I do a couple of things differently. I omit the sugar, bacon bits, celery, and usually the sausage. For beans I use 3 cans of kidney beans rinsed and drained because I've never seen "chili beans" in my grocery store. I've never measured the spices, but definitely am generous with the chili powder and garlic. Couldn't be easier, I do think the beer is super important. I usualky use a good heavy dark beer. I've made this without beer once and it wasn't nearly as good.

I am so excited about this chili! The first day it was a medium heat and seemed to be mild the next day. I cooked this in a 7 quart slow cooker with no room to spare on high for 4 hours.  I am only cooking for two people, but I made a full batch to freeze the leftovers.  I didn't overly alter the recipe as I usually do based on the amazing reviews.  I did add 1/4 c extra premium light beer, 1 small can chopped green chilies (couldnt find green chilies in the produce department, but saved work on chopping), and doubled up on the Worcestershire and garlic.  I used an amazing chopper so this recipe was extremely easy for me (I hate to chop).  Other than that, it did not take long at all since you are simply measuring 1t or 1T of several spices (all of which I had on hand) and dumping them, along with canned ingredients, into a pot.

text:
I've never made chili before, but I decided to try this recipe for my BF's superbowl party. He is a Purdue alum, so I braved the recipe despite my general lack of cooking experience. I made a few adjustments which might have led to a couple of problems. I must say that it turned out absolutely DELICIOUS and I gots tons of compliments on it! I just recommend that you stick with the recipe as is, because my adjustments made the final product a little more soupy than I had envisioned and it wasn't spicy in the slightest. First, I used canned green chilies instead of fresh chopped chilis. I also sauteed all the veggies in olive oil prior to tossing them in the stockpot. I followed the rest of the spices to the exact measurement, but I didn't detect any heat at the end. I also used a full dark beer instead of a half cup. Hence the soupiness, I'm sure, but it definitely added some nice flavor. I cooked it all evening the night before, refrigerated it overnight, and then reheated it on the stovetop. The flavors were very nice, I'd almost put it in a restaurant-quality category. The partygoers layered frito chips on the bottom of a bowl and ladled the chili over, followed by a small amount of sour cream and lots of sharp cheddar. Everyone enjoyed it and my BF took the leftovers to work so everyone could devour it the next day. It's definitely a keeper!

text:
I just won 2nd out of 28 entries in our church's Superbowl party chili cook-off.  I  followed the recipe except for the changes as follows:  3 lb. ground chuck, 2 cans spicy chili beans, cooked & crumbled 2 pieces of bacon for the bits, 1/2 bottle of Sam Adams brown ale, and I used fresh basil (1 tbsp) I had put up in the freezer from my garden last summer.  I simmered it for approx. 4 hours on the stove, refrigerated it overnight, then poured it into a crock pot where I cooked it on low from 9 a.m. until 4:30 p.m. - when I had to get it to the church for the contest.  It has the right kick to it coming out of the pot, and individuals can easily spice it up with Tabasco, if desired.

text:
This was very good.  I made a few tweaks to it and entered it into a cooking contest and won third place!  Word of caution though: I have a 5 qt slow cooker, and all of the ingredients fit in the pot ... I let the chili cook overnight, and when we woke up, the juices had boiled out of the pot and were all over the counter AND the floor.  So, make sure you have a bigger crockpot, or cook it in two separates batches!

While being very good, I have a simpler recipe that I usually use, and in the end I think the recipes are about equal.  So complicated doesn't always mean better!

text:
I made this for a Chili Cook Off at work today & won first place & $50. I did make a few changes mostly due to it originally tasting hotter than I thought I wanted it.  I will say to get your spices from a spice store rather than the grocery store. They really made the dish!
I deleted the green chiles (forgot to add) I  added 
one 15 oz can of dark red kidney beans-drained, 
an extra one tsp of Paprika,  
one tsp of ground chipolte peppers, 
an extra 14.5 oz can of diced tomatoes-not drained,
 2 tsp Hershey's 100% cocoa powder, 
1/4 cup pineapple juice, 
1 tbsp extra sugar, &
 1/2 cup or so of leftover shredded beef roast. I made the night before. 
It's very thick initially but cooks down much thinner & then thickens again nicely by next day. I also used 4 slices of real bacon baked to a crisp in the oven that I crumbled up instead of bacon bits. The flavor mellowed a lot over night & was spicy but not really what I would call too hot. I usually do not eat things that are too spicy & would call this a medium heat flavor. The flavors exploded in your mouth. It is a nice thick chili, not runny at all. I just put in crock pot this am on low for a few hours. Well worth the effort!

text:
This is a good chili.  My husband who's picky about his chili liked it.  But I found it wayyyyyyyyy to spicy for my taste eventhough I made I only used medium chili beans instead of spicy, jalapeno peppers instead of chili ones, and less than 1 tsp of cayenne pepper.  If I make it again, I probably will just mild chili beans, maybe 1 jalapeno and no cayenne pepper.  I'm only rating this recipe 4 start because 1) there's too many ingredients thus requiring more time for chopping (I prefer simpler recipes) and 2) I really didn't like having to stay close to my stove the whole 2 hours it was simmering to stir it.  If I didn't stir it 5-8 minutes, the bottom would burn and stick to the pan.  I think this recipe can be very good in the crockpot.

text:
This chili ROCKS!!! I was afraid it would be TOO hot, but it's not. Very Robust flavor, and the spicy aroma just lingers for minutes. Can't wait to taste it tomorrow. I deviated based on items on hand. I'm a bean guy, LOVE 'EM, Replaced 2 cans of chili beans with 1 can GREAT NORTHERN BEANS and 1 can of BLACK BEANS, Chiles were not available, substituted with 2 SORRANOs, 1 HOT FINGER, and 1/2 HABANERO, and used FRANKS extra hot sauce...also added 12oz of white mushrooms cut about 3/8"-1/2" thick. If you like mushrooms, they absolutely rock in chili. This recipe is 5 stars for a reason, it absolutely kills! Make it, and impress the hell out of your friends. The spicyness lingers, it's not a scorcher. This is a recipe for the ages. Nuff said.

I love spicy food and this is just the right type of spicy without going overboard since anyone can add all kind of spicy spices and peppers and make it spicy. text:
Wow!  I've been looking for a vegetarian non-vegetarian tasting chili and with a little tweaking this was it!  I eliminated the meat, bouillon cubes, and canned beans substituting 2 cups of dried pinto, kidney, and small red beans that I'd soaked overnight and boiled for 1 hour.  I also added 2 seeded chopped jalapenos, 1 teaspoon of salt, a bit more cayenne, a bunch of crushed red pepper flakes, and an extra 28oz can of diced tomatos.  I threw it all in the crock pot most of the day on high.  With my variations I ended up with about 18 servings but it still tasted great and I'm gonna freeze the rest so I can eat it all winter long.  It's man chili just like my dad used to make but without the meat.  Thanks MIGHTYPURDUE22.

I've done this recipe more than a few times now.  It is excellent as is, but I've definately fooled with the recipe a bit.  Most notably, using 4 strips of crispy cooked bacon instead of the bits.  Instead of sugar, I use half a lime squeezed in.  Finally, instead of ground chuck, I use ground sirlon, so I have little excess greese to drain off.   For a hot dog topping, I use only 2 cans of beans.  This is a great chili recipe as is, but an even better one to fool around with.

Tried this last week, the only change I made was using 2 chipolte peppers in adobo sauce (what I had) instead of the green chili peppers and I used 1/2 lb of bacon.  The end result was a quite good smokey chili with a nice slow "heat".  Will make again, husband really enjoyed, toddlers wouldn't even try....wonderful on hot dogs a couple of days later!
